}}
[[File:Godflesh logo.svg|thumb|Official Godflesh logo]]

\'\'\'Godflesh\'\'\' are a British [[industrial metal]] band from [[Birmingham]], England. They were formed in 1988 by [[Justin Broadrick]] ([[guitar]], [[vocals]] and [[programming (music)|programming]]) and G.C. Green ([[bass guitar|bass]]) and disbanded in 2002. Godflesh\'s innovative music is widely regarded as a foundational influence on industrial metal and [[post-metal]].<ref name=iht/> Broadrick and Green reformed Godflesh in 2010.

==History==

===Formation (1982\xe2\x80\x931988)===
In 1982, Green founded \'\'\'[[Fall of Because]]\'\'\' (named after a [[Killing Joke]] song)<ref name="FAQ">{{cite web | url=http://www.godflesh.com/faq.html | title=The Godflesh FAQ | date=31 July 2001 | accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref> with [[Paul Neville (musician)|Paul Neville]]. Broadrick, who had been playing guitar as a member of [[Napalm Death]], joined the group in mid-1985 as drummer and vocalist. He left the band in 1987. Broadrick then spent a couple of years (1986\xe2\x80\x931988) as a member of [[Head of David]]. In 1988, he contacted Green about reforming Fall of Because. Justin decided to take over on guitars and they chose to use a drum machine to help out. They also decided to change their name to Godflesh.<ref name="FAQ"/>

===Career trajectory (1989\xe2\x80\x932001)===
Godflesh established a presence in [[underground music]] with releases such as their \'\'[[Godflesh (EP)|self-titled EP]]\'\', \'\'[[Streetcleaner]]\'\' and \'\'[[Pure (Godflesh album)|Pure]]\'\', which demonstrated the effectiveness of [[lo-fi]] production values in heavy music. A brief flirtation with major label [[Columbia Records]] in 1994 for \'\'[[Selfless (album)|Selfless]]\'\' and the \'\'[[Merciless (EP)|Merciless]]\'\' [[Extended play|EP]] saw the duo take on a more high-end production approach. In 1996 Godflesh released \'\'[[Songs of Love and Hate (Godflesh album)|Songs of Love and Hate]]\'\', which featured the drumming of [[Bryan Mantia]] ([[Guns N\' Roses]], [[Primus (band)|Primus]], [[Praxis (band)|Praxis]]). The next album, \'\'[[Us and Them (Godflesh album)|Us and Them]]\'\', released in 1999, saw the group experimenting with a more electronic, [[drum and bass]]-oriented sound in which the guitar played a less central role. In 2001 Godflesh released the double album retrospective \'\'[[In All Languages (Godflesh album)|In All Languages]]\'\'. That same year they released an album of new material, \'\'[[Hymns (Godflesh album)|Hymns]]\'\', which featured the precise drumming of new band member Ted Parsons (formerly of [[Swans (band)|Swans]] and [[Prong (band)|Prong]]) and brought the band back to its slow and heavy roots while retaining elements of its experiments with [[electronica]] and [[Hip hop music|hip hop]].

===Dissolution (2002)===
Green left Godflesh in late 2001. The band announced that Green would be replaced by former [[Killing Joke]] and [[Prong (band)|Prong]] bassist [[Paul Raven (musician)|Paul Raven]]. In the interim, however, Broadrick\'s thirteen-year relationship with his girlfriend dissolved, and Broadrick suffered a [[nervous breakdown]] shortly before departing for a tour of the [[United States]].<ref name="mtv-Godflesh_Breaks_Up">{{cite web |first=Jon |last=Wiederhorn |title=Godflesh Singer Suffers Breakdown, Breaks Up Band |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1453723/20020501/story.jhtml |publisher=MTV |format=JHTML |date=2002-05-01 |accessdate=2009-10-20 }}</ref> Broadrick recalls the breakdown as a "real [[Brian Wilson#Reduced production role in the Beach Boys and mental fatigue|Brian Wilson]] moment" and said that he "felt paralyzed by the stress, which had been building for several months, and I literally couldn\'t get out of bed. I was numb and couldn\'t move, so when the car came to pick me up to take me to the airport, I ran and hid at another friend\'s house in Birmingham."<ref name="breakup-1"/>

The canceled tour caused even more problems for Broadrick. Bus companies had been hired; the groups [[High on Fire]] and Halo had been booked to support. And everyone who lost money came after Broadrick. He stated: "I was getting death threats from the bus company in L.A.. I lost close to $35,000, which I did not have at all. I was broke and had to sell my house and pay off all my debt on credit cards. I pretty much did nothing for four months besides drink heavily."<ref name="breakup-1">{{cite web | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1553090/metal-file-jesu-obituary-animosity-more-news-that-rules/ | title=Metal File: Jesu, Obituary, Animosity & More News That Rules | publisher=[[MTV]] | date=22 February 2007 | accessdate=19 May 2014 | author=Harris, Chris}}</ref> On a poster promoting [[Jesu (band)|Jesu]]\'s first EP \'\'[[Heart Ache]]\'\', the caption read as follows "Godflesh is dead, long live Jesu."

Broadrick issued a statement about the end of Godflesh:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.godflesh.com/articles/statement.html|title=Godflesh Disbands|date=13 May 2002|accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref>

{{bq|On April 10th 2002, I disbanded Godflesh. This was something I had painfully been pondering since GC Greens\' departure from the band in Oct 2001. Regrettably it took until the day of leaving for a lengthy U.S tour for the realization to finally take its toll on me. Unfortunately the finality of the decision and the responsibilities of making the decision proved too much for me to bear, and I collapsed under the weight. I found that without GC Green, Godflesh is not Godflesh, and him leaving proved to be an omen for me. I also feel that everything we originally intended or even imagined with Godflesh we have done. My only regret has been the hurting of both remaining band members Ted Parsons and Paul Raven, and disappointing those that believe in Godflesh worldwide... In the near future, my new rock project Jesu will surface. So this is by no means the end of my songwriting/guitar/vocalizing. Simply the end of a chapter. Endless gratitude to all those that have believed in and supported Godflesh throughout the 14 year history. You know who you are... Long live the new flesh...}}

===Reunion (2010\xe2\x80\x932013)===
In November 2009, a reunion show was officially announced for the 2010 edition of the [[Hellfest Summer Open Air]] ([[Clisson]], France).

Asked in a February 2010 interview about Godflesh\'s future, Broadrick replied, "Godflesh will not commit to anything but Hellfest currently. I am unsure as to where we will go from there, if we go anywhere at all." He also revealed that the band will not rule out the possibility of new material.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/godflesh-mainman-doesn-t-rule-out-possibility-of-new-material/|title=Godflesh Mainman Doesn\'t Rule Out Possibility Of New Material|date=2010-02-05|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>

Godflesh played at the 2010 Supersonic Festival in Birmingham, UK on 23 October, co-headlining with Swans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capsule.org.uk/supersonic/2010/page/supersonic-2010|title=SWANS + GODFLESH HEADLINE SUPERSONIC FESTIVAL 2010}}</ref> They appeared at the 2011 edition of the [[Roadburn Festival|Roadburn festival]] at the 013 venue in Tilburg, Holland, where they performed their first album, \'\'Streetcleaner\'\', in its entirety.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/godflesh-to-perform-entire-streetcleaner-album-at-roadburn-festival/ |title=GODFLESH To Perform Entire \'Streetcleaner\' Album At ROADBURN Festival |publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date=24 October 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-12}}</ref>

In December 2010, Broadrick told [[Decibel (magazine)|Decibel]] magazine that the band is slowly putting together ideas for a new studio album. He explained, "It\'s something we\'re discussing all the time, and I do have bits and pieces of material. But it\'s something we\'d really like to develop. It\'d be quite easy to knock out eight to 10 in-character songs and release it as quickly as possible to capitalize on the popularity of the group, but it would feel entirely wrong. If it\'s another two years until another Godflesh record, so be it. The most important thing is making a record that stands up with the rest of the back catalogue. I do have this in me again, though."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/reunited-godflesh-working-on-new-material/ |title=Reunited GODFLESH Working On New Material |publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date=4 December 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-12}}</ref>

In April 2012, Broadrick confirmed in the April/May edition of \'\'[[Rock-a-Rolla]]\'\' magazine that a new album is in the works: "We intend to release a new album, most likely in 2013, and to record it in late 2012. Probably an EP will come before the album. We will be taking our time with this album, we are not taking it \'lightly\'."<ref>\'\'Rock-a-Rolla\'\' Issue 37. Page 7.</ref> Godflesh performed as headliners at the 2012 Maryland Deathfest on 25 May 2012. It was their first North American performance in about 17 years.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} Godflesh released their first new recording in over 12 years through \'\'[[Decibel (magazine)|Decibel]]\'\' magazine\'s Flexi Series, which is a cover version of [[Slaughter (Canadian band)|Slaughter]]\'s "[[F.O.D. (Fuck of Death)#Godflesh cover|F.O.D. (Fuck of Death)]]". The flexi disc was included in the November 2013 issue of \'\'Decibel\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/godflesh-first-new-recording-in-over-12-years-to-be-made-available-through-decibel-magazine/ |title=GODFLESH: First New Recording In Over 12 Years To Be Made Available Through DECIBEL Magazine |publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date=2013-08-14 |accessdate=2013-08-23}}</ref>

Godflesh played at [[Roadburn Festival]] 2013 in Tilburg, Holland, featuring [[Robert Hampson]] on guitar for part of the set. They performed their album \'\'Pure\'\' in its entirety.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roadburn.com/2012/04/godflesh-to-headline-roadburn-festival-2013-performing-pure-in-its-entirety-for-the-first-time-ever/|title=Godflesh To Headline Roadburn Festival 2013; Performing Pure In Its Entirety For The First Time Ever - Roadburn}}</ref>

===\'\'Decline & Fall\'\' EP and \'\'A World Lit Only by Fire\'\' (2014)===
The band announced plans for a new EP, \'\'[[Decline & Fall]]\'\', which was released on 2 June 2014. \'\'[[A World Lit Only by Fire (album)|A World Lit Only by Fire]]\'\' followed on 7 October,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/godflesh-to-release-a-world-lit-only-by-fire-album-in-october-first-song-streaming/|title=GODFLESH To Release \'A World Lit Only By Fire\' Album In October; First Song Streaming|date=5 August 2014|accessdate=5 August 2014|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]}}</ref> with both releases put out on Broadrick\'s Avalanche Records. The EP includes 4 songs and 2 bonus songs on the Japanese edition. Broadrick commented on the musical style on \'\'A World Lit Only by Fire\'\':
{{cquote|It will be [musically] similar to the first two or three [Godflesh albums]. I just think, like we\'re playing these shows, we feel very pure about we\'re doing and honoring the initial intentions with what we originally set out to do. It will definitely sound aggressive and it probably won\'t sound like any of the other records we\'ve made, but it will have the minimalism of the first few records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.factmag.com/2014/05/07/industrial-innovators-godflesh-announce-first-release-in-over-a-decade/|title=Industrial innovators Godflesh announce first release in over a decade|date=May 7, 2014|accessdate=May 11, 2014|publisher=[[Fact (UK magazine)|factmag.com]]}}</ref>}} Broadrick also has a signature 8-string guitar coming out, which he used on both releases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theprp.com/2014/05/07/news/godflesh-to-release-new-ep-decline-fall-in-june-justin-k-broadrick-unsure-what-djent-is/|title=Godflesh To Release New EP "Decline & Fall" In June, Justin K Broadrick Unsure What Djent Is|publisher=[[ThePRP]]|date=7 May 2014|accessdate=11 May 2014}}</ref>

==Collaborators and side projects==
Several other musicians have recorded and played live with Godflesh. [[Paul Neville (musician)|Paul Neville]] rejoined Broadrick and Green for the \'\'[[Streetcleaner]]\'\' and \'\'[[Slavestate]]\'\' albums. [[Robert Hampson]], former guitarist for [[Loop (band)|Loop]], appeared on \'\'[[Pure (Godflesh album)|Pure]]\'\' and \'\'[[Cold World (EP)|Cold World]]\'\'. (In 1991 Loop released the split 7" single \'\'Loopflesh\'\' covering the Godflesh song "Like Rats" while Godflesh performed Loop\'s "Straight to Your Heart".)

Members of Godflesh have been involved in numerous side projects, allowing them to explore interests in other musical genres, including [[electronica]], [[ambient music|ambient]], [[dub music|dub]], [[industrial hip-hop]], and [[digital hardcore]]. Broadrick has collaborated with [[Kevin Martin (British musician)|Kevin Martin]] and [[Alec Empire]], among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.godflesh.com/encyclopedia/ |title=Godflesh A-Z |publisher=Godflesh.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-12}}</ref> Broadrick\'s other active projects include [[Jesu (band)|Jesu]] and [[Final (band)|Final]].

==Musical style==
Drawing influence from [[List of post-industrial music genres and related fusion genres#Power electronics|power electronics]] forefathers [[Whitehouse (band)|Whitehouse]],<ref>Kaye 1992, page 16.</ref> [[noise rock]] band [[The Swans (band)|Swans]],<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.metrospirit.com/index.php?ShowArticle_ID=11012410074046204&cat=1993101070588705|title= Justin Broadrick: Existing through risk|author= Ruffin, Josh|date= 2007-10-23|publisher= [http://www.metrospirit.com Metro Spirit]|accessdate= 2008-09-19}}</ref> [[ambient music]] creator [[Brian Eno]]<ref name=decibel2007>{{cite web|url= http://www.decibelmagazine.com/features/mar2007/justinbroadrick.aspx|title= Justin Broadrick|author= Bartkewicz, Anthony|date=March 2007|publisher= [http://www.decibelmagazine.com Decibel Magazine]|accessdate= 2008-06-19 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080223185218/http://www.decibelmagazine.com/features/mar2007/justinbroadrick.aspx <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-02-23}}</ref> and fellow [[Birmingham]] [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[Black Sabbath]],<ref>Pettigrew 1991, page 22.</ref> Godflesh were among the pioneers of industrial metal.<ref>Pettigrew, Jason. \'\'Godflesh: the Power of Positive Paradoxes.\'\' Alternative Press, 5(36), 1991, page 22.</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite web|url= http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2008/jul/18/electronicmusic|title= Till deaf us do part|author= Chick, Stevie|date= 2008-07-18|publisher= [[guardian.co.uk]]|accessdate= 2008-07-28}}</ref> Godflesh have also been described as [[post-metal]]<ref name="RoughGuide">{{cite book | title=The Rough Guide to Rock | publisher=Buckley, Peter | year=2003 | pages=908 | isbn=1858284570}}</ref> and [[experimental metal]].<ref name="TheQuietUs">{{cite web | url=http://thequietus.com/articles/02546-godflesh-slavestate-pure-cold-world-reissue-album-reviews | title=Godflesh - Slavestate, Pure, Cold World Reissues | publisher=[[The Quietus]] | date=21 August 2009 | accessdate=21 January 2013 | author=Gardner, Noel}}</ref>

Godflesh is known for their unique mixture of [[drum machine]] beats with droning, discordant guitar and powerful, intermittent bass. On their earlier albums, the [[rhythm]]s, [[synth]]s, and [[Sampling (music)|samples]] are credited to "Machine" or "Machines". Later, Godflesh made use of human drummers [[Bryan Mantia]] and [[Ted Parsons]]. Their eerie, slow, and repetitive style is commonly described as "apocalyptic".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.godflesh.com/articles/article2.html |title=Godflesh Interview |publisher=Godflesh.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-12}}</ref> The Godflesh sound was once described as "\'\'[[Pornography (album)|Pornography]]\'\'-era [[The Cure|Cure]] on [[Quaaludes]]".<ref>Thompson 1994, page 44.</ref>

Broadrick\'s vocals are often guttural, making use of something akin to the [[death grunt]] technique, yet they also at times show a softer, more melodic side, as in "I Wasn\'t Born to Follow" from 1992\'s \'\'Pure\'\'. Godflesh lyrics are terse, cryptic, and bleak, often emphasizing [[dualism|duality or opposition]]. [[Paranoia]] and [[martyrdom]] are also common themes in Godflesh\'s music and cover art.

Broadrick has also taken inspiration from [[Leonard Cohen]]; both artists have albums titled \'\'[[Songs of Love and Hate (Leonard Cohen album)|Songs of Love and Hate]]\'\'. In the song "Mothra" (from \'\'Pure\'\'), Godflesh borrows the lyrics "Your pain is no credential here / It\'s just the shadow of my wound" from the song "Avalanche" on the aforementioned Cohen album.<ref name="FAQ"/>

==Influence==
Godflesh has been cited as an influence by [[Korn]],<ref name= yates2001>Yates, Catherine (2001). \'\'Souls of a New Machine.\'\' Kerrang! 871: page 19.</ref> [[Metallica]],<ref>Alexander, Phil (1995). \'\'Alien Soundtracks!\'\' Kerrang!, 528: page 52.</ref> [[Danzig (band)|Danzig]],<ref>{{cite journal |url= http://www.the7thhouse.com/news/Articles/seconds44.htm |title= DANZIG - Seconds Magazine No.&nbsp;44|author= Blush, Steven |date=October 1997|accessdate= 2007-08-30}} Archived at [http://www.the7thhouse.com www.The7thHouse.com].</ref> [[Faith No More]],<ref>M\xc3\xb6rat 1990, page 14.</ref> [[Fear Factory]],<ref name=yates2001>Yates 2001, page 19.</ref> [[Converge (band)|Converge]],<ref>Converge FAQ [http://www.convergecult.com/] Access date: 25 July 2008.</ref> [[Isis (band)|Isis]],<ref name=iht>Jon Caramanica, "The alchemy of art-world heavy metal", \'\'International Herald Tribune\'\', 20 September 2005. [http://www.iht.com/articles/2005/09/19/features/heavy.php] Access date: 25 July 2008.</ref> [[Pitchshifter]], and [[Ministry (band)|Ministry]], among others. Justin Broadrick was asked to join Danzig and Faith No More as a band member full-time, but Broadrick wanted to focus on Godflesh.<ref name="FAQ"/>

==Cinematic connections==
The image on the front of 1988\'s \'\'[[Godflesh (EP)|Godflesh]]\'\' is a still from the cult 1966 [[John Frankenheimer]] film \'\'[[Seconds (film)|Seconds]]\'\'. The image on the cover of \'\'[[Streetcleaner]]\'\' is a still from the movie \'\'[[Altered States]]\'\', a 1980 horror film by director [[Ken Russell]] in which the film\'s protagonist, played by William Hurt, explores other states of consciousness with the aid of hallucinogens and an isolation chamber. Photos from the insert sleeve for the album are taken from [[David Lynch]]\'s \'\'[[Eraserhead]]\'\' (another major influence cited by Broadrick).<ref name=faq>{{cite web|url=http://www.godflesh.com/ |title=Godflesh-Crumbling Flesh |publisher=Godflesh.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-12}}</ref> The cover of [[Merciless (EP)|\'\'Merciless\'\']] is a still from the 1943 experimental film \'\'[[Meshes of the Afternoon]]\'\'.

Godflesh showed the video for "[[Crush My Soul]]" (by [[Andres Serrano]]) to [[Kirk Hammett]] and he loved it. Metallica later used a piece of footage by Serrano for their cover on the album \'\'[[Load (album)|Load]]\'\'. In a later interview with Hammett, he is asked where the band got the idea of the cover. Hammett tells the interviewer that he saw something on television about Andres Serrano and that is how it came about, not giving any credit to Godflesh. Justin says, "There\'s no copyright on Serrano. We\'ll be the first to admit that. But we planted the seed, and unfortunately we\'re not getting the credit, obviously." Hammett once gave Broadrick a custom Fender Stratocaster after his was stolen on tour, and has commended the band by stating that they are the "heaviest band in existence".<ref name=faq>[http://godflesh.com/faq.html/ ]{{dead link|date=January 2011}}</ref>

After Earache merged with [[Sony]] (Columbia), Godflesh began appearing on soundtracks. In 1995, they appeared on the soundtrack to the movie \'\'[[Hideaway (film)|Hideaway]]\'\'. They also appeared in the movie itself. During one of the club scenes, they are playing onstage in the background, performing the song "Nihil".<ref name="FAQ"/>
<!---Shouldn\'t this belong in Wikiquotes?
==Quotes==
{{quotation|I\'ve obviously got quite a fear of [[dying]]\xe2\x80\x94especially at the hands of other people. Then again, I\'ve got a fear of just about everything. [[Gang violence]] scares me. [[fixed-wing aircraft|Plane]]s scare me. I can\'t stand flying. Every second I\'m in the air, I just think that something isn\'t right, that the plane is about to crash. [[Fear]] is a really important factor in what we do. Godflesh is scared music, which is why it\'s so strong\xe2\x80\x94we\'re always trying to bring those feelings up to the surface.|Justin Broadrick|[[Rip (magazine)|Rip]], June 1992}}

{{quotation|Our music is about hitting an emotional core in people with brutal power. At first all we wanted to do was crush our listeners, but then we wanted to hypnotize them. It\'s hard to put that into words, and I really can\'t put it into words. The two of us [Broadrick and bass player G.C. Green] are rather [[introverted]] and reserved as people; maybe even sensitive. I find that I can convey our emotions only through the guitar.|Justin Broadrick|[[Guitar (magazine)|Guitar]], Summer 1994}}

{{quotation|There\'s a real beauty to brutality.  Even the most graphic violence can be beautiful if it\'s presented in an artistic way.|Justin Broadrick|[[Guitar World]], February 1995}}

{{quotation|I often ask myself how I can make things more sick sounding. [[Sickness]] is really a big part of our sound.|Justin Broadrick|Guitar, June 1999}}--->

* [[G.C. Green]] &ndash; bass, programming (1988&ndash;2001, 2010&ndash;present)

===Former members===
* [[Paul Neville (musician)|Paul Neville]] &ndash; guitars (1989&ndash;1991)
* [[Robert Hampson]] &ndash; guitars (1991&ndash;1992)
* [[Bryan Mantia]] &ndash; drums, percussion (1994&ndash;1996)
* [[Ted Parsons]] &ndash; drums, percussion (1996&ndash;2002)
* Steve Hough &ndash; guitars (1999)
* [[Diarmuid Dalton]] &ndash; samples, moog (1999)
* [[Paul Raven (musician)|Paul Raven]] &ndash; bass (2002)

 ****** Android Lust

b'{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}}
{{BLP sources|date=February 2008}}
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->
| name                = Android Lust
| image                 =
| caption            = "Stained" video
| image_size            =
| background          = group_or_band

| origin              = [[United States]]
| genre               = [[Electro-industrial]], [[Industrial rock]]
| years_active        = 1996&ndash;present
| label               = [[Projekt Records]]
| associated_acts     =
| website                 = http://www.androidlust.com/
| current_members     = Shikhee D\xe2\x80\x99iordna
| notable_instruments = [[Keyboard instrument|Keyboard]]s, [[Drum Kit|Drums]], [[Guitar]], [[Violin]]
}}

\'\'\'Android Lust\'\'\' is the solo project of \'\'\'Shikhee D\xe2\x80\x99iordna\'\'\', that combines elements of rock, electropop, electro-industrial and classical styles into a blend of music that she describes as "electronic and dark."

==History==
Android Lust is just one person and the brainchild of musician Shikhee in the same vein as auteurs like Trent Reznor.

Shikhee D\xe2\x80\x99iordna was born in Bangladesh, but grew up in England and the U.S.A.<ref name=bosphoenix>{{cite web |url=http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/events/state/documents/03281518.asp |title=Editor\'s Picks: Goth, not Goth |author=Freedberg, Michael |year=2003 |work=Boston Phoenix October 31 - November 6, 2003 |publisher=Phoenix Media/Communications Group |accessdate=May 23, 2011| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20110605135512/http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/events/state/documents/03281518.asp| archivedate= June 5, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>  In 1999, she moved to New York City.<ref name=bosphoenix/>

Her initial work was done entirely electronically, and attracted a goth/electropop/electro-industrial following.<ref name=WBM1340mag>{{cite web |url=http://www.1340mag.com/android_lust_interview.htm |title=Android Lust Interview |author=Fisher, Mark |year=2003 |work=1340 Magazine |publisher= |accessdate=May 31, 2011 |archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20030819094545/http://www.1340mag.com/android_lust_interview.htm |archivedate= August 19, 2003}}</ref>

After two independent label releases Shikhee released \'\'The Dividing\'\' on her own in 2002, bringing her to the attention of [[Projekt Records]], who signed her and re-released the album. \'\'Outburn\'\' Magazine calls \'\'The Dividing\'\' "unconventional and adventurous - 10 out of 10" while the \'\'Boston Phoenix\'\' says "The Dividing never misfires; it feels almost - but not quite - slick, its arranging smart, its themes ingenious." \'\'[[Jane magazine|Jane]]\'\' Magazine said "The Dividing is filled with intensely passionate lyrics delivered in low whispers and startling, penetrating screaming."  That album involved more live instrumentation, on the album all performed by Shikhee.  In the supporting tour she was joined by a live drummer and live keyboardist.  She felt that, while dark it was a more optimistic collection than her earlier work, and that her fanbase had become more diversified.<ref name=WBM1340mag/>

Shikhee\'s third full-length album, \'\'Devour, Rise, and Take Flight\'\', was released on February 21, 2006. "Dragonfly," the first single for the album, was released on October 18.  The album featured more live instrumentation than \'\'The Dividing\'\', but embraced a more aggressive electronic sound.  This album also saw some creative collaboration with Christopher Jon, Android Lust\'s live drummer, who co-wrote one track with Shihkee, performed on other tracks and helped mix the album.<ref name=ReGen109>{{cite web |url=http://www.regenmag.com/Interviews-109-Android-Lust.html |title=ReGen Interviews - Android Lust - Divide and Devour |author=Y&uuml;cel, Ilker |date=March 6, 2006 |work=ReGen Magazine |publisher= |accessdate=May 31, 2011 |archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20071110182047/http://www.regenmag.com/Interviews-109-Android-Lust.html |archivedate= November 10, 2007}}</ref> Also in 2006, a video for "Dragonfly," was directed by New York director [[Dan Ouellette]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Android Lust - Dragonfly|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f8nIvGEq-vg|publisher=Android Lust|accessdate=August 11, 2011}}</ref>

Her fourth album, \'\'The Human Animal\'\', was made available at androidlust.com on July 22, 2010, with an official street date of August 10, 2010. [http://www.androidlust.com/v5/?pg=news&item=/2010/07/human-animal-now-taking-pre-orders]

Shikhee is now working on a new release.<ref>http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/androidlust/android-lust-crater-vol1</ref>

==Discography==
{{main|Android Lust discography}}

;Studio albums
*\'\'Resolution\'\' (1998)
*[[The Dividing]]\'\' (2002)
*\'\'Devour, Rise and Take Flight\'\' (2006)
*\'\'The Human Animal\'\' (2010)
*\'\'Crater Vol. 1\'\' (2013)

*[http://www.mtvdesi.com/2010/11/22/coffee-with-shikhee-words-from-the-woman-behind-android-lust/ MTV Desi]
*[http://www.darkvisionmedia.org Dark Vision Media]
*[http://www.fiend-magazine.com/06/music-ivandlust.html Fiend Magazine]
*[http://www.regenmag.com/Interviews-24-Android-Lust.html Re>Gen Magazine]

{{DEFAULTSORT:Android Lust}}
[[Category:Electro-industrial music groups]]

[[Category:Women in electronic music]]'

 ****** Angelspit

b'{{redirect|Wreak Havoc|the English idiomatic expression|wiktionary:wreak havoc}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}}
{{Use Australian English|date=June 2011}}
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->
| name                = Angelspit
| image               = Angelspit 5piece hi.jpg
| caption             = Angelspit\'s 2011 5-piece line-up
| image_size          = 
| background          = group_or_band
| alias               = 
| origin              = [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]
| genre               = [[Electro-Industrial]], [[Electro Punk]], [[Industrial Metal]], [[Cybergoth]]
| years_active        = 2004\xe2\x80\x93present
| label               = {{flatlist|
* [[Dancing Ferret#Dancing Ferret Discs|Dancing Ferret Discs]]
* [[Black Pill Red Pill]]
* [[Metropolis Records|Metropolis]]}}
| associated_acts     = The Crystalline Effect, The Tenth Stage, [[The Cr\xc3\xbcxshadows]], The Gothsicles
| website             = http://www.angelspit.net/
| current_members     = 
* Zoog Von Rock
* George Bikos
| past_members        = 
* Valerie Gentile
* Chris Kling
* The Liar
* Destroyx / Amelia Arsenic
}}

\'\'\'Angelspit\'\'\' is an electronic music band originally from [[Sydney, Australia|Sydney]], [[Australia]] and currently based in the United States. The band was formed in 2004 by [[vocalist]]s/[[Synthesizer|synthesists]] Destroyx (Amelia Tan) and ZooG (Karl Learmont). The band\'s music combines unique and stylistic elements of horror, punk and electronic music as well as pop and their work contains imagery revolving around medical experiments and grotesque societies. The band is currently based in [[New York City]] and [[London]]. Angelspit has toured with Angel Theory, [[Ayria]], [[Ikon (band)|Ikon]], [[KMFDM]], Tankt and [[The Cr\xc3\xbcxshadows]], and have also shared the stage with bands such as [[The Sisters of Mercy]], [[Nitzer Ebb]], [[Skinny Puppy]] and [[Front Line Assembly]]. They performed with [[Lords of Acid]] during a 22-date U.S. tour in March 2011 and toured the United States with [[Blood on the Dance Floor (band)|Blood on the Dance Floor]] in October 2011.

==History==
Karl Learmont (ZooG) and Amelia Tan (Destroyx), met on an online [[zine]] forum.  They shared an interest in zines and started the distro Vox Populis in 2002.  They then started making zines for themselves which became the lyrical inspiration for releases to follow. Angelspit was formed in 2004, they self-released their debut EP, \'\'[[Nurse Grenade]]\'\' on 3 October 2004.

The band self-released their debut studio album, \'\'[[Krankhaus]]\'\' on 6 June 2006, and re-released it on 30 January 2007 with a bonus remix album, entitled \'\'Surgically Atoned\'\', and in the US on [[Dancing Ferret|Dancing Ferret Discs]]. The album featured remixes by Combichrist and Ego Likeness. A video for "Vena Cava" was released on 22 August 2007. The band toured Australia, the USA and Europe where they lived in Berlin to record their second studio album, \'\'[[Blood Death Ivory]]\'\'.

The band released their second studio album, \'\'Blood Death Ivory\'\' on 11 June 2008. The album was written and recorded between 2006 and 2008. Again, the band continued to tour the new material around Europe and the USA. They released their debut remix album \'\'[[Black Kingdom Red Kingdom]]\'\' on 15 May 2009. Around this time the band began to produce "Blipverts", short video blogs and tutorials on various topics, including the production of the band\'s third studio album.

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Angelspit band photo-july09.jpg|thumb|left|Promotional image for the launch of \'\'Hideous and Perfect\'\']] -->
The band released their third studio album, \'\'[[Hideous and Perfect]]\'\' on 9 September 2009. A video for "Fuck the Revolution" was released on 28 September 2009. They released their second remix album \'\'[[Larva Pupa Tank Coffin]]\'\' on 10 October 2010. \'\'Larva Pupa Tank Coffin\'\' includes 4 brand new Angelspit tracks and remixes by the band themselves as well as other artists. A video for the remix of "Sleep Now" was released on 2 October 2010. They released their third remix album, \'\'[[Carbon Beauty]]\'\' on 8 March 2011. This new remix album contains 3 new tracks as well as 10 remixes of tracks from the \'\'Hideous and Perfect\'\' album. A video for "Toxic Girl" was released on 13 April 2011, and a video for "Like It? Lick It!" was released on 27 July 2011.

On 15 April 2011, Angelspit announced the addition of three new members: guitarist Valerie Gentile (Black Tape for a Blue Girl, The Cr\xc3\xbcxshadows), drummer Chris Kling (Hanzel und Gretyl, Mortiis) and videojammer The Liar. The new line-up of Angelspit released their fourth studio album, \'\'Hello My Name Is\'\' on October 11, 2011. Matt James replaced Chris Kling in early 2012, and former Cr\xc3\xbcxshadows guitarist George Bikos filled in for Valerie Gentile on the band\'s 2012 tour. On 23 March 2014, Angelspit announced DestroyX was taking time off to focus on her other projects and would be re-joining Angelspit on future recordings.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Zoog|title=Destroy X is taking time off\xe2\x80\xa6|url=http://www.angelspit.net/destroy-x-is-taking-time-off/|publisher=Angelspit.net|accessdate=19 November 2014|date=23 March 2014}}</ref>

== Band members ==
* Zoog Von Rock (formerly Zoog) \xe2\x80\x93 [[Singing|vocals]], [[programming (music)|programming]] <small>(2004\xe2\x80\x93present)</small>
* George Bikos \xe2\x80\x93 [[guitar]]s <small>(2012\xe2\x80\x93present; session musician: 2008, 2009)</small>

 ****** Celldweller

b'{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name            = Celldweller
| image           = Klayton of Celldweller.jpg
| background      = non_vocal_instrumentalist
| origin          = [[New York City]], [[New York]], [[United States]]
| genre           = [[Electronic rock]], [[alternative metal]], [[industrial metal]], [[electronic music]]
| label           = Esion Media, Position Music, [[FiXT Music]]
| years_active    = 1999\xe2\x80\x93present
| website         = {{URL|celldweller.com}}
| associated_acts = [[Blue Stahli]], [[Circle of Dust]], [[Argyle Park]], [[Criss Angel]], [[Angeldust (Industrial band)|Angeldust]], [[Scandroid]]
| current_members = [[Klayton]]
}}

\'\'\'Celldweller\'\'\' is a [[Detroit, Michigan]]-based musical project created by multi-instrumentalist artist, producer, songwriter, performer, programmer, and remixer [[Klayton]]. Klayton creates a hybrid fusion of digital and organic elements: intricately designed soundscapes that take cues from electronic genres like [[drum and bass]], [[Electro (music)|electro]], and [[dubstep]], woven together with aggressive rock/metal and orchestral elements. Celldweller songs have been featured in many films, movie trailers, television shows and video games.{{Citation needed|date=April 2015}}

== Biography ==

===Precursors: Circle of Dust and Angeldust, 1997\xe2\x80\x931999===
The name Celldweller was derived from a nickname his mom gave him when he was a teenager, dubbed "Cellar Dweller", as he made all of his music in his parents cellar.<ref name="Origin of the name Celldweller">{{cite web|title=ask_celldweller Ep. 02: Thanks Mom|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aYqBUZG4rYQ|work=YouTube.com|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref> Klayton had gained a devoted cult following in the mid 90s because of his [[industrial metal]] band [[Circle of Dust]]. He also contributed to the supergroup [[Argyle Park]], using the pseudonyms Dred, Deathwish, and Celldweller. After the dissolution of Circle of Dust, Klayton concurrently released both a posthumous collection of reworked Circle of Dust leftovers titled \'\'[[Disengage (album)|Disengage]]\'\' and an album for a new project, [[Angeldust (industrial band)|Angeldust]], created in conjunction with illusionist [[Criss Angel]].<ref name="carpenoctem">{{cite web
  | url = http://www.celldwellertribe.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=8&Itemid=591
  | title = Klay Scott Interview with Carpe Noctem
  | publisher = Carpe Noctem magazine
  | year = 1997
  | accessdate = 2009-04-12
}}</ref> Both albums demonstrated Klayton\'s shift away from industrial metal and towards more electronic-modern industrial rock influences, incorporating richer electronic instrumentation and greater emphasis on melody. This change in style was a major step toward the sound that would come to define Celldweller\'s output. Klayton began creating songs for the Celldweller project in 1998/1999<ref name="deliriuminterview">{{cite web
  | url = http://www.celldwellertribe.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=885&Itemid=591
  | title = Klayton Interview with DELIRIUM
  | last = Diamantis-Fry
  | first = Sophie
  | year = 2003
  | accessdate = 2009-04-12
}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and released a limited edition EP of three early Celldweller demos and two solo trance tracks, which quickly sold out. Klayton and Criss Angel parted ways in 2000 after three albums\' worth of material had been completed, allowing Klayton to devote all of his time to Celldweller.<ref name="1340interview">{{cite web
  | url = http://www.celldwellertribe.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=382&Itemid=591
  | title = Klayton Interview with 1340 Mag
  | publisher = 1340 Mag
  | year = 2003
  | accessdate = 2009-04-12
}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>

===Eponymous debut period (1999\xe2\x80\x932004)===
[[File:Celldweller logo.jpg|thumb|right|Official Celldweller "cell-block" logo.]]

{{Main|Celldweller (album)|l1={{mp|Celldweller}}}}
Klayton worked in earnest with producer Grant Mohrman (formerly of [[Leaderdogs for the Blind]]) on the debut \'\'[[Celldweller (album)|Celldweller]]\'\' album, which was slated for release in February 2001. Unfortunately, various delays kept pushing the release date back.<ref name="Celldwellercurrentinfo29102002">{{cite web
  | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20021029181051/celldweller.com/currentinfo.html
  | url = http://www.celldweller.com
  | title = Celldweller current info 29 October 2002
  | archivedate = 29 October 2002
  | accessdate = 2009-04-12
}}</ref> During this time, Klayton kept fans up to date with numerous Celldweller Logs through his website and via email and, in 2001, released raw files of the song "Symbiont" to give fans and fellow musicians a chance to remix Celldweller\'s music.<ref name="Celldwellercurrentinfo01062000">{{cite web
  | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20001209081800/celldweller.com/currentinfo.html
  | url = http://www.celldweller.com
  | title = Celldweller current info 1 June 2000
  | archivedate = 1 June 2000
  | accessdate = 2009-04-12
}}</ref> Eight remixes were chosen and uploaded to the original [[Mp3.com]], most of them making it to the top of the Electronic and the Electro-Industrial charts. All the exposure led to over 500,000 song plays on Mp3.com.{{citation needed|date=April 2009}} The "Symbiont" remixes became a digital EP six years later.

The self-titled debut album saw release in early 2003 and debuted at No.&nbsp;17 on [[Billboard charts|Billboard\'s]] Internet Sales Chart.<ref>[{{BillboardURLbyName|artist=celldweller|chart=Internet Albums}} Celldweller ranking at Billboard]</ref> \'\'Celldweller\'\' included a guest appearance by [[Taproot (band)|Taproot]] drummer Jarrod Montague. In 2004, the album took home seven awards at the [[Just Plain Folks Music Organization|Just Plain Folks Music Awards]], winning Album of the Year, Producer of the Year, Industrial Album of the Year, Metal Song of the Year ("One Good Reason") and Best Industrial Rock Song ("Switchback"), and also took runner-up in Best Industrial Song with "Stay with Me (Unlikely)" and Best Rock Song with "I Believe You".<ref name="justplainfolks" /> Later, the songs "Birthright" and "Switchback" were included in the list of Hard and Extreme Mode songs respectively for the popular iPhone OS game \'\'[[Tap Tap Revenge]]\'\'.

In 2004, Klayton put together a double disc release called \'\'[[The Beta Cessions]]\'\'. The first disc contained a re-recording of the last Circle of Dust song, "Goodbye", alternate mixes of "Switchback", the Klayton tracks from the initial Celldweller EP, and demo versions of debut \'\'Celldweller\'\' songs. The second disc contained the full debut album in instrumental form, with a few of the instrumentals being slightly edited.<ref name="1340interview">{{cite web
  | url = http://www.celldwellertribe.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=881&Itemid=707
  | title = Beta Cessions Review
  | publisher = ReGen
  | last = Yucel
  | first = Ilker
  | year = 2006
  | accessdate = 2009-04-12
}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Klayton stated that he plans to release Beta Cessions to coincide with each of his major albums to collect outtakes, demos, and other rarities.<ref name="06102005blog">{{cite web
  | url = http://www.celldwellertribe.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=429&Itemid=579
  | title = Klayton Was Here... (artist\'s blog) 06-10-2005
  | date = 6 October 2005
  | accessdate = 2009-04-12
}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>

In the years following the release of the first Celldweller album, various remix EPs were released, culminating in the conception of the Take It & Break It Celldweller Remix Competition in 2006.<ref name="keyboardmag">{{cite web
  | url = http://www.celldwellertribe.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=921&Itemid=697
  | title = Celldweller To Launch Groundbreaking Remix Contest
  | date = September 2006
  | accessdate = 2009-04-11
}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Expanded off the fan remix concept that Klayton first toyed with in 2001 with the Symbiont remixes, the Take It & Break It competition saw the creation of its own website on which unlimited numbers of fans could register, download and remix the individual recording files of various Celldweller songs, and then submit their remixes. Three rounds of the competition were completed, with compilations of Celldweller remixes being released at the end of each round. In 2008, the Celldweller Remix Competition evolved into the FiXT Remix Competition where fans, remixers, and musicians have the opportunity to remix songs of not only Celldweller but other FiXT Music artists as well.{{citation needed|date=April 2009}}

In December 2008, Klayton released \'\'[[Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 1|Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 01]]\'\', a collection consisting primarily of short, instrumental score-based compositions. He selected and reworked demos from his extensive archives that he felt would suit for film, TV and video game licensing.<ref name="04122008blog">{{cite web
  | url = http://www.myspace.com/celldweller/blog/430459609
  | title = Klayton Was Here...(artist\'s blog) 5-10-08
  | date = 5 September 2008
  | accessdate = 2009-04-12
}}</ref> Additionally, some songs were from the (then work in progress) second main Celldweller album sessions.<ref name="fearnetinterview" /><ref>Celldweller - The Best It\'s Gonna Get Beta Cessions Commentary (Wish Upon a Blackstar Chapter 02 Deluxe Edition)</ref>  Celldweller\'s management has sought to have these songs placed in media, like those on the debut album, and several have already been heard on film and television and in video games.<ref name="fearnetinterview" />

===\'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\' period (2004\xe2\x80\x932012)===
[[File:Klaytonin2005.jpg|thumb|left|Klayton in 2005]]

{{Main|Wish Upon a Blackstar}}
Writing and recording for the second Celldweller album has been underway since 2004.<ref name="Eon Beta Cessions commentary">{{Cite web |author=celldweller |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jnOEyuLkXos |title=Eon Beta Cessions commentary |publisher=youtube.com |date= 2009-12-08 |accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref><ref name="Beta Cessions (Demos Vol. 01) ">{{Cite web |author=celldweller |url=http://www.fixtstore.com/product/62596/Celldweller---Beta-Cessions-%28Demos-Vol.-01%29-%28MP3-Album%29 |title=Beta Cessions (Demos Vol. 01) |publisher=FiXT Music |date=2011-12-23 |accessdate=2012-01-14}}</ref> Originally slated to come out in the summer of 2006, the album has been delayed numerous times. In March 2009, Klayton announced that the title of the album is \'\'[[Wish Upon a Blackstar]]\'\'. Of 50 songs, he has narrowed it down to the 10 that will comprise the album. In a blog post on his website, he elaborated on wanting to release the album in \'Chapters\' with each Chapter consisting of 2 songs.

In April 2009, Klayton revealed the tracks \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\' would contain,<ref name="4-20-09klog">{{cite web |url=http://www.celldweller.com/2009/04/does-this-smell-like-chloroform-04-20.html |title=Does This Smell Like Chloroform? (04-20-09) |publisher=Celdweller.com |first=Klayton |last=Scott |date=20 April 2009 |accessdate=2009-04-20}}{{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and has also stated that many of the leftovers will be on the second volume of The Beta Cessions.<ref name="fearnetinterview">{{cite web |url=http://www.fearnet.com/news/b13999_FEARnet_Meets_Cinema_s_Secret_Weapon___CELLDWELLER.html |title=Klayton interview with FEARnet |publisher=FEARnet |first=Gregory S. |last=Burkart |date=10 December 2008 |accessdate=2009-04-11}}</ref>

During the recording of \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\', Klayton also began work on his follow-up to \'\'Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 01\'\'. \'\'[[Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 2|Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 02]]\'\' will be released in the same manner as \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\': as handfuls of tracks are completed, Chapters of the full album will be released digitally until the full collection is complete and the album is released on physical media. Chapter 01 of \'\'SVH Vol. 02\'\' featured four songs, including a 20 minute ambient piece (a first for Celldweller). Additionally, a Limited Edition CD of Chapter 01 was released on 7 December 2010 that contained a bonus short ambient track, "Distants".

In addition to working on \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\' and \'\'SVH Vol. 02\'\', Celldweller kept busy on other fronts. He produced the remainder of the debut [[Blue Stahli]] album, appeared on the soundtrack of the [[Xbox 360]]/[[PlayStation 3]] game \'\'[[Dead Rising 2]]\'\' with a new original song, "[[Kill the Sound]]", as well as a selection of previously released Celldweller songs,<ref name="deadrising2announce">{{cite web |url=http://fixtstore.com/news/?p=1921 |title=Dead Rising 2: The Music Behind the Game (Celldweller) |publisher=FiXT News |date=28 September 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref> and also remixed songs for [[BT (musician)|BT]]<ref name="BTremix">{{cite web |url=http://www.celldweller.com/site/?p=197 |title=Update from the studio |publisher=Celldweller |date=3 April 2009 |accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref> and [[Jes Brieden|JES]].

Klayton confirmed in April 2010 that, for the first time in five years, he would be taking Celldweller on the road. The live band would consist of Klayton and fellow FiXT recording artist [[Blue Stahli]].<ref name="WUABtour">{{cite web |url=http://www.celldweller.com/site/?p=304 |title=Updates (lots of \'em) |publisher=Celldweller |date=5 April 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref> The first leg of the tour, in the fall of 2010, included shows at Triton Fest in New York City, [[Dragoncon]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], and EBM Fest in Toronto. In November 2010, Klayton announced that he is planning to release studio recordings of the alternate live versions of Celldweller songs played on the tour. The first of these releases, \'\'[[Cellout EP 01]]\'\', is available as an iTunes exclusive, released on January 25, 2011.

On May 4, 2011, a 4-EP bundle was released via Groupees in a 72 hour only exclusive online sale with 20% of the benefits going to Red Cross for Tornado Relief. The EPs in the promotion were \'\'Cellout EP 01\'\', Chapter 01 of \'\'Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 02\'\', Chapter 03 of \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\' and the \'\'[[Unreleased EP]]\'\' which contained previously unreleased songs and remixes including a song titled "Senorita Bonita" from the Chapter 02 of \'\'SVH Vol. 02\'\' and a Beta Cessions demo, "Atmospheric Light".<ref name="72 Hour Promo Sale">{{cite web 
|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KPe5cKU7b5M 
|title=Atmospheric Light &#124 72 Hour Promo Sale
|publisher=Celldweller 
|date=3 May 2011 
|accessdate=2011-06-03}}</ref>

In May 2011, in a [[Ustream]] broadcast Klayton mentioned that he was planning to launch a Celldweller VIP Membership, which would give "access to unreleased demos, video, news, discounts & more". It was to be launched in "early/mid July", 2011.<ref name="Anyone still...">{{cite web |url=http://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10150273212681672 |title=Anyone still... &#124 Facebook |publisher=Facebook |date=10 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-06-11}}</ref>

On November 24, 2011, Klayton announced that he is planning to release \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\' on March 27, 2012.<ref name="Wish Upon a Blackstar - Letter From Klayton">{{Cite web |author=celldweller |url=http://mim.io/c208f1 |title=Wish Upon A Blackstar &#124 Letter From Klayton |publisher=mim.io |date= 2011-11-24 |accessdate= 2011-11-24}}</ref>

Chapter 02 of \'\'Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 02\'\' was released on February 14, 2012 and pre-orders of \'\'[[Live Upon a Blackstar]]\'\' began on the same day along with an announcement about the delay of \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\' to May 22, 2012.<ref name="Live Upon a Blackstar">{{Cite web |author=celldweller |url= http://www.fixtstore.com/product/63930/Celldweller---Live-Upon-A-Blackstar-%28MP3-Album%29 |title= Celldweller - Live Upon a Blackstar |publisher=FiXT Music |date= 2012-02-14 |accessdate= 2012-02-16}}</ref> On March 2, 2012, Klayton released a new SVH song, "Elara" as a single.<ref name="Surprise! "Elara"...">{{Cite web
  | url = http://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/373632739327262
  | title = Surprise! "Elara"...
  | publisher = Facebook
  | date = 2012-03-02
  | accessdate = 2012-03-03
}}</ref>

The MP3 Album version of \'\'Live Upon a Blackstar\'\' was released on March 26, 2012, one day early.<ref name="What\'s this?...">{{Cite web |author=celldweller |url=http://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/124430994348143 |title=What\'s this?... |publisher=Facebook |date=2012-03-27 |accessdate= 2012-03-27}}</ref> However, the \'\'Live Upon a Blackstar\'\' Blu-ray DVD was delayed to April 17, 2012 and was delayed again, to May 22, 2012.<ref name="Celldweller - Live Upon A Blackstar (DVD & Blu-Ray Combo)">{{Cite web
|author= FiXT Music
|url= http://www.fixtstore.com/product/63929/Celldweller---Live-Upon-A-Blackstar-%28DVD/Blu-Ray%29
|title= Celldweller - Live Upon A Blackstar (DVD & Blu-Ray Combo)
|publisher= FiXT Music
|date= 2012-04-07
|accessdate= 2012-04-17
}}</ref> The release date of \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\' was also moved. Currently, it is scheduled to be released on "a final release date in early June 2012."<ref name="What happened to...">{{Cite web
|author= celldweller
|url= http://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10150760128266672?comment_id=23320282
|title= What happened to...
|publisher=Facebook.com
|date= 2012-03-27
|accessdate= 2012-04-08
}}</ref> On April 18, 2012, the final release date of \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\' was announced. The album is set to be released on June 12, 2012.<ref name="Wish Upon A Blackstar Official Release Date + Free Download of Unshakeable">{{Cite web
|author= celldweller
|url= http://mim.io/3a3582
|title= "Wish Upon A Blackstar" Official Release Date + Free Download of "Unshakeable"
|publisher= mim.io
|date= 2012-04-18
|accessdate= 2012-04-18
}}</ref> On May 22, 2012, the \'\'Live Upon a Blackstar\'\' DVD/Blu-ray was delayed to June 12, 2012.<ref name="Celldweller - Live Upon A Blackstar (DVD & Blu-Ray Combo)" />

On June 12, 2012, \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\' was released alongside the \'\'Live Upon a Blackstar\'\' Blu-ray DVD.<ref name=""Wish Upon a Blackstar" is live worldwide today.">{{Cite web
  | url = https://twitter.com/celldweller/status/212525787155398656
  | title = "Wish Upon a Blackstar" is live worldwide today.
  | publisher = Twitter
  | date = 2012-06-12
  | accessdate = 2012-06-12
}}</ref><ref name="Celldweller - Live Upon A Blackstar (DVD & Blu-Ray Combo)" />

On July 13, 2012, Klayton released a new \'\'SVH Vol. 02\'\' song as a single and he also announced the release date of July 24, 2012 for the full \'\'Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 02\'\' album.<ref name="Celldweller - First Person Shooter (Single) (MP3 Album)">{{Cite web
  | url = http://www.fixtstore.com/product/80349/Celldweller---First-Person-Shooter-%28Single%29-%28MP3-Album%29
  | title = Celldweller - First Person Shooter (Single) (MP3 Album)
  | publisher = FiXT Music
  | date = 2012-07-13
  | accessdate = 2012-07-14
}}</ref><ref name="Soundtrack For The Voices In My Head Vol. 2">{{Cite web
  | url = http://www.fixtstore.com/product/81325/Celldweller---Soundtrack-For-The-Voices-In-My-Head-Vol.-2-%28MP3-Album%29
  | title = Soundtrack For The Voices In My Head Vol. 2
  | publisher = FiXT Music
  | date = 2012-07-24
  | accessdate = 2012-07-25
}}</ref> On July 16, 2012, a new vocal song titled "Tough Guy" was released for free download on Dubstep.net.<ref name="Tough Guy by Celldweller - Dubstep.NET Exclusive">{{Cite web
  | url = http://www.dubstep.net/track/tough-guy-by-celldweller-dubstep-net-exclusive
  | title = Tough Guy by Celldweller - Dubstep.NET Exclusive
  | publisher = Dubstep.net
  | date = 2012-07-16
  | accessdate = 2012-07-16
}}</ref> Klayton stated that this song is "towards the next Celldweller album".<ref name="There\'s a *pretty...">{{Cite web
  | url = http://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10151094426621672
  | title = There\'s a *pretty...
  | publisher = Facebook
  | date = 2012-07-14
  | accessdate = 2012-07-16
}}</ref>

On September 14, 2012, a new Klash-Up, "Miss Murder\'s Personal Jesus" was premiered [[Alternative Press]]\'s website. It contains elements of [[AFI (band)|AFI]]\'s "[[Miss Murder]]" and [[Depeche Mode]]\'s "[[Personal Jesus]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altpress.com/features/entry/song_premiere_celldweller_miss_murders_personal_jesus_afi_depeche_mode_klas |title=Song Premiere: Celldweller, "Miss Murder\xe2\x80\x99s Personal Jesus (AFI & Depeche Mode Klash-Up)" |publisher=Alternative Press |date=2012-09-14 |accessdate=2012-10-19}}</ref>
On October 19, 2012, another Klash-Up titled "Cry Little Sister Vs. Hello Zepp" was released on [[Bloody Disgusting]]\'s website. It contains elements of [[Gerard McMahon]]\'s "[[Cry Little Sister]]" and "[[Hello Zepp]]" from \'\'[[Saw (film series)|Saw]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3198783/premiere-stream-and-download-celldwellers-hello-little-sister-vs-hello-zepp-klash-up/ |title=[Premiere] Stream AND DOWNLOAD Celldweller\xe2\x80\x99s "Cry Little Sister Vs. Hello Zepp" Klash-Up |publisher=Bloody.Disgusting |date=2012-10-19 |accessdate=2012-10-19}}</ref>

On October 22, 2012, Klayton announced International Tour, including shows in Estonia, Latvia, Russia and Ukraine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SETSYslbSBw |title=Celldweller 2012 International Tour Announcement |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2012-10-22 |accessdate=2012-11-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celldweller.com/site/?page_id=435 |title=Celldweller Tour 2012 |publisher=celldweller.com |date=2012-10-26 |accessdate=2012-11-05}}</ref>

On October 26, 2012, Celldweller launched another Groupees campaign,<ref name="2012Groupees">{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/501083426582401 |title=2012 Groupees Campaign |publisher=Celldweller |date=26 October 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-19}}</ref> selling \'\'Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 1\'\' and \'\'Vol. 2\'\', \'\'Live Upon a Blackstar\'\', \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\', \'\'The Complete Cellout\'\' as well as offering the \'\'Live Upon a Blackstar\'\' DVD for digital download with a portion of all the sales were donated to the Children\'s Defense Fund. Through the campaign, donors unlocked a new 3-song \'\'Unreleased EP 2\'\' with demo songs that were intended for \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\'.<ref name="Unreleased2">{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/387266478014897 |title=Unreleased EP 2 |publisher=Celldweller |date=15 November 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-19}}</ref>

On December 11, 2012, the \'\'[[Space & Time (EP)|Space & Time EP]]\'\' was released containing remixes of various songs from \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\'.<ref name="SpacenTime">{{cite web |url=http://www.fixtstore.com/product/88996/Celldweller---Space-&-Time-%28Deluxe-Edition%29-%28MP3-Album%29 |title=Space & Time (Deluxe Edition) |publisher=FiXT Music |date=2012-11-19 |accessdate=2012-12-11}}</ref>

===\'\'Blackstar\'\' and \'\'End of an Empire\'\' (2013\xe2\x80\x93present)===
{{Main|Blackstar (novel)|l1={{mp|Blackstar}}|End of an Empire}}
On the February 11, 2013, which marked the 10th anniversary of the release of [[Celldweller (album)|his debut album]], Klayton announced that he was working on a re-issue of the debut album, along with a 2-CD Deluxe Edition due out in May. The finished version of the unreleased song, "Uncrowned", was also released with the re-issue. It was originally written for the debut album, but never made it on there.<ref name="Someone reminded me...">{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10151482995846672 |title=Someone reminded me...|publisher= Celldweller |date=2013-02-11 |accessdate=2013-06-16}}</ref> The re-issue also contains remastered versions of the tracks released during the Groupees promotions, alongside never heard before tracks.<ref name="Celldweller announces re-issue available">{{cite web|title=Celldweller announces re-issue available|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151623607631672&set=a.487925516671.294704.11000096671&type=1|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=2 April 2013}}</ref> On May 1, 2013, Klayton made and posted an announcement video on his social networking pages that the [[Celldweller (album)#10 Year Anniversary Edition|re-issue of his debut album]] was available for pre-order from the FiXT website. The re-issue was released on June 10, 2013, one day before the original release date.<ref name="We\'ve got a special">{{cite web|title=We\'ve got a special...|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151691651586672&l=b05ed5b929|publisher=Facebook|date=2013-06-10|accessdate=2013-06-10}}</ref>

On March 29, 2013, he released a previously unreleased song entitled "Younger", featuring [[Kenzie (songwriter)|Kenzie]], and is up for free download.<ref name="Younger released tomorrow">{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10151565721381672 |title= Celldweller to release \'Younger\'  |publisher= Celldweller |date=2013-03-28 |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref> The song was written approximately four years ago.<ref name="Younger, written 4 years ago">{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10151564436816672 |title= \'Younger\', written 4 years ago  |publisher= Celldweller |date=2013-03-26 |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref>

On June 25, 2013, \'\'The Complete Cellout Vol. 01 Instrumentals\'\' was released, containing instrumental versions of the songs from \'\'The Complete Cellout Vol. 01\'\'.<ref name="Cellout Instrumental">{{cite web|title=The Complete Cellout Vol. 01 Instrumentals|url=http://www.fixtstore.com/product/101859/Celldweller---The-Complete-Cellout-Vol.-01-Instrumentals-%28MP3-Album%29
 |publisher=FiXT Music |date=2013-06-25 |accessdate=2013-06-27}}</ref>

Klayton programmed four tracks on the [[I See Stars]] album \'\'[[New Demons (I See Stars album)|New Demons]]\'\',<ref name="Currently working on...">{{cite web|title=Currently working on...|url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10151684102076672
 |publisher=Facebook |date=2013-06-06 |accessdate=2013-06-06}}</ref> and composed music for the video game \'\'[[Dead Rising 3]]\'\'.<ref name="Dead Rising 3 Soundtrack">{{cite web|title=Dead Rising 3 has been announced...|url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10151691981931672?comment_id=29173458&offset=0&total_comments=2
 |publisher=Facebook |date=2013-06-10 |accessdate=2013-06-11}}</ref><ref name="Scoring a video game...">{{cite web|title=Scoring a video game...|url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10151169372061672
 |publisher=Facebook |date=2012-08-17 |accessdate=2013-06-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Many of you guys...|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151693997501672&set=a.487925516671.294704.11000096671&type=1|publisher=Facebook|date=2013-06-12|accessdate=2013-06-12}}</ref> Klayton also released two songs with [[James Dooley (composer)|James Dooley]], entitled "Black Sun" and "Rise from the Underworld". "Black Sun" appeared in the film \'\'[[I, Frankenstein]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Metalectro Special: Celldweller|url=http://www.metalectro-music.com/2013/10/07/metalectro-special-celldweller/|accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref>

Klayton announced in February that he will be publishing a new novel, titled \'\'[[Blackstar (novel)|Blackstar]]\'\', which is based on/inspired by his album \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\'. The novel is being written by five-time award-winning author [[Josh Viola]] (director of the "[[Unshakeable]]" music video) of \'\'[[The Bane of Yoto]]\'\' and renowned author [[Keith Ferrell]] of \'\'Bloodmoon: Birth of the Beast\'\'. The first act was released on December 3, 2013.<ref name="Celldweller Plans New Music, Book Series, And More">{{cite web |url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3220840/celldweller-plans-new-music-book-series-and-more/ |title= Celldweller Plans New Music, Book Series, And More  |publisher= Bloody-Disgusting |date=2013-02-27 |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref>

\'\'[[Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 03]]\'\' was also announced on his Facebook.<ref name="Some observant fans...">{{Cite web
  | url = https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151636725181672&set=a.487925516671.294704.11000096671&type=1
  | title = Some observant fans...
  | publisher = Facebook
  | date = 2013-05-09
  | accessdate = 2013-05-22
}}</ref> Chapter 01 of \'\'SVH Vol. 03\'\' was revealed by [[The Orchard (company)|The Orchard]]. It was released earlier exclusively on iTunes on July 2, 2013. On other online stores, including FiXT Store, it was released on July 16, 2013.<ref name="SVH 3 Ch1 early release">{{cite web|title=Are you ready for...|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151723235291672&l=429b449d21
 |publisher=Facebook |date=2013-06-26 |accessdate=2013-06-27}}</ref><ref name="The Orchard SVH3 leak">{{cite web|title=Soundtrack for the Voices in My Head Vol. 03, Chapter 01|url=http://www.theorchard.com/release/765573869842/Celldweller/Soundtrack%20for%20the%20Voices%20in%20My%20Head%20Vol.%2003%2C%20Chapter%2001
 |publisher=The Orchard |accessdate=2013-06-07}}</ref>

Klayton also announced a new project with music producer [[Varien]], called [[Scandroid]]. A website was created with a preview of a new song. The full song, "Salvation Code", was released on August 6, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Salvation Code|url=http://www.salvationcode.com/}}</ref>

On August 23, 2013, Celldweller posted an image of him and what he describes on the post as a set for a music video shoot. The song it is for is currently unknown,<ref>{{cite web|title=On set for a Celldweller Music Video shoot right now...|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151843381926672&set=a.487925516671.294704.11000096671&type=1|work=Facebook|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref>  but details about the video were posted a day later, with an image of a forest and with a quote \'\'"I am here shooting a Celldweller music video (feat @bluestahli.)"\'\' with [[Blue Stahli]] playing a guest role in the video,<ref>{{cite web|title=I am here shooting a Celldweller music video...|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151846408651672&set=a.487925516671.294704.11000096671&type=1|work=Facebook|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref> and in another post, that they are wearing space suits in the woods.<ref>{{cite web|title=In a space suit in the woods...|url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10151845990001672|work=Facebook|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref> In a post on the next day after that, he commented to say that he and Blue Stahli are celebrating the wrap of the music video, along with "#theluckyones", possibly meaning that the song will be "The Lucky One".<ref>{{cite web|title=Wrap of the music video...|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151848832051672&set=a.487925516671.294704.11000096671&type=1|work=Facebook|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref>

On November 22, 2013, Celldweller released \'\'Zombie Killer\'\', an EP consisting of the tracks he composed for the official soundtrack of \'\'[[Dead Rising 3]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Celldweller - Timeline Photos|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10152053410816672&set=a.487925516671.294704.11000096671&type=1|accessdate=November 23, 2013}}</ref>

On December 6, 2013, Celldweller released the official music video to "Unshakable" a week earlier to its initial release date due to fans making over 100 reviews on \'\'Blackstar\'\'\'s [[Ebook]] and [[Blackstar (novel)#Score|score]] on [[iTunes]] and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]].<ref name="Unshakable music video unlocked a week early">{{cite web|title=Unshakable music video unlocked a week early|url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10152085846751672|work=Facebook|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=6 December 2013|author=Josh|format=Facebook Post|date=6 December 2013|quote=There are over 100 reviews for the Blackstar eBook and original score on Amazon and iTunes...}}</ref><ref name=\'Music video to "Unshakable" is released\'>{{cite web|title=PREMIERE: CELLDWELLER\'S "UNSHAKEABLE" MUSIC VIDEO|url=http://www.djz.com/news/premiere-celldweller-s-unshakeable-music-video/|work=djz.com|publisher=DJZ|accessdate=6 December 2013|author=Rishabh Bhavnani|format=News post|date=6 December 2013|quote=...today we\'ve got the premier of the official music video...}}</ref> On January 5, 2014, he released a short song called "Snowcore" on his [[SoundCloud]] page.<ref>{{cite web|title=Snowcore (01-05-2014)|url=https://soundcloud.com/celldweller/snowcore-01-05-2014|accessdate=January 6, 2014}}</ref>

On February 2014, Celldweller announced the \'\'Sonix Producer Pack Vol. I\'\', which features sounds that Klayton created for music production. It was released to the public on February 11, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sonix Producer Pack (Instagram Teaser #1)|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HzACjRjf7lo|accessdate=February 4, 2013}}</ref>

The second act of \'\'Blackstar\'\', \'\'[[Blackstar (novel)#Act Two: Awakening|Blackstar Act Two: Awakening]]\'\', was released on June 3, 2014, along with its score.<ref>{{cite web|title=Blackstar Act Two: Awakening (Original Score)|url=http://www.fixtstore.com/product/108160/Celldweller---Blackstar-Act-Two:-Awakening-%28Original-Score%29-%28MP3-Album%29}}</ref>

On March 18, 2014, he announced another album coming some time in 2014.<ref>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S1BPtiKoehE</ref> He also stated that the next album will be released in a series of chapters, similar to his previous feature album \'\'Wish Upon a Blackstar\'\'.<ref name="ask_celldweller EP.06">{{cite web|title=ask_celldweller EP.06: Do I Stutter?|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O3ZVMDKxGaI&feature=youtu.be|work=[[YouTube]].com|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=9 April 2014}}</ref> On August 13, 2014, the new album title was announced and is \'\'[[End of an Empire]]\'\'. Its first chapter, \'\'Time\'\', was released on September 16, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=End Of An Empire Chapter 1: Time|url=http://www.fixtstore.com/product/109279/Celldweller---End-of-an-Empire-%28Chapter-01:-Time%29-%28MP3-Album%29}}</ref>

== YouTube career ==
{{Expand section|1=<nowiki />
* Add references
* Expand on YouTube career
* Expand into table
|date=July 2014}}
{{Infobox podcast
|italic title = no
|title        = Celldweller
|image        = 
|hosting      = Klayton
|language     = [[English language|English]]
|began        = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2006}}
|genre        = [[Documentary]] and [[vlogging]]
|url          = {{url|https://www.youtube.com/user/celldweller}}
}}
While he has owned a YouTube account since 2006, Klayton started up a [[YouTube]] career on 2014 when he started six shows on his [[YouTube]] channel in 2014:

* "Demo Vault" consists of demos that Klayton stored away, with the first release "Klay Out West" on February 28, 2014.<ref name="Demo Vault - Klay Out West">{{cite web|title=Demo Vault - Klay Out West (2005)|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HtSamDo-ImQ&feature=youtu.be|work=YouTube.com|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=4 March 2014}}</ref> On May 30, 2014, Klayton released the first in a series of compilations, \'\'[[Demo Vault Vol. 01]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Celldweller - Demo Vault Vol. 01|url=http://www.fixtstore.com/product/108439/celldweller---demo-vault-vol.-01-(mp3-album)}}</ref> \'\'Demo Vault Vol. 02\'\' was released on September 5.<ref>{{cite web|title=Celldweller - Demo Vault Vol. 02|url=http://www.fixtstore.com/product/109422/Celldweller---Demo-Vault-Vol.-02-MP3-Album}}</ref> On October 17, 2014, Klayton released the last episode of Demo Vault, stating that he didn\'t really run out of material but thinks the rest just isn\'t good enough to be published.<ref>{{cite web|title=Demo Vault - Wah Wah Wah|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=71Ou-pBsiuA}}</ref>
* "Ask Celldweller" has Klayton answering questions that his fans ask via comments and video responses. The show premieres episodes every 2nd and 4th Tuesday of the month.<ref name="First Ask Celldweller episode">{{cite web|title=ask_celldweller Ep. 01: Construction Zone|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sk-Qj0kuTfk&feature=youtu.be|work=YouTube.com|publisher=Celldweller|accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref>
* "Cellevision" involves Klayton contacting and meeting with other FiXT artists. The show premieres episodes every 1st and 3rd Thursday.
* "Celldweller Production" has Klayton showing off the gear he uses to make music. The show premieres episodes every other month.
* "Recording Cessions" has Klayton creating, recording and mastering music in his studio. The show premieres episodes every 4th Thursday.
* "Transmissions" (previously "Because I Can") has Klayton creating experimental tracks with his modular system, like "Snowcore", "A Storm on Saturn", "Metropolitan" and "The Halls of Valhalla", a compilation of these experiments, \'\'Transmissions: Vol. 01\'\', was released on December 23, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Celldweller - Transmissions: Vol. 01|url=http://www.fixtstore.com/product/109859/Celldweller---Transmissions:-Vol.-01-%28MP3-Album%29}}</ref>

==Awards==
The debut Celldweller album won seven awards in the 2004 [[Just Plain Folks Music Organization|Just Plain Folks Music Awards]]:<ref name="justplainfolks">{{cite web
  | url = http://www.jpfolks.com/MusicAwards/2004/FoundersAwards.htm
  | title = 2004 Just Plain Folks Music Awards
  | date = 7 November 2004
  | accessdate = 2009-04-10
}}</ref>

* Best [[Hard Rock]] song - "Fadeaway"
* Best [[Industrial music|Industrial]] Song - "[[Switchback (Celldweller song)|Switchback]]" (with "Stay with Me (Unlikely)" in second place)
* Best [[Heavy metal music|Metal]] song - "One Good Reason"
* 2nd place, Best [[Rock music|Rock]] Song - "I Believe You"
* Album of the Year - Celldweller
* Producer of the Year - [[Klayton]]
* Best Industrial album - Celldweller
* Best Male Vocalist - [[Klayton]] ([[2005 Radio-Active-Music Awards]])

==Live band==

=== Current members ===
*[[Klayton]] - [[vocals]], [[synthesizers]], [[guitar]], [[Bass guitar|bass]], [[percussion]], [[DJing]] <small>(1999\xe2\x80\x93present)</small>

=== Past live members ===
*[[Blue Stahli|Bret Autrey (Blue Stahli)]] - [[backing vocals]], [[synthesizers]], [[guitar]], [[Bass guitar|bass]], [[percussion]] <small>(2010\xe2\x80\x932013)</small>
*Dale Van Norman - electric guitar, keyboards, percussion, backing vocals <small>(2003\xe2\x80\x932005)</small>
*Kemikal - bass guitar, keyboards, percussion, backing vocals <small>(2003\xe2\x80\x932005)</small>
*Cais - acoustic and electronic drums, percussion <small>(2003\xe2\x80\x932005)</small>
*Kenny James - acoustic and electronic drums, percussion <small>(2003\xe2\x80\x932005)</small>
*Del Cheetah - guitar, keyboards, percussion <small>(2003\xe2\x80\x932005)</small>
*Chris Cross aka Tweety - guitar, keyboards, percussion <small>(2003\xe2\x80\x932005)</small>
