*[http://books.google.com/books?id=XBIEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA16&dq=%22Phi+in+the+Sky%22&hl=en&ei=FiDtTIb-DYOC8gasqble&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Phi%20in%20the%20Sky%22&f=false "Reconfigured Kidney Thieves Rebounding With Extasy EP, New Album," \'\'Billboard\'\', Dec. 15, 2001]
*[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=kidneythieves-p310237|pure_url=yes}} Kidneythieves at AllMusic]
*[http://www.myspace.com/kidneythieves Kidneythieves official Myspace profile]

[[Category:Musical groups reestablished in 2007]]
[[Category:American alternative rock groups]]
[[Category:Industrial rock musical groups]]
[[Category:American industrial metal musical groups]]
[[Category:American alternative metal musical groups]]
[[Category:American post-grunge musical groups]]
[[Category:American industrial music groups]]
[[Category:Musical groups established in 1998]]
[[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 2004]]
[[Category:Rock music duos]]'

 ****** KMFDM

b'{{distinguish|KFDM}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name                = KMFDM
| image               = Kmfdm live in 2011.jpg
| image_size          = 250
| caption             = KMFDM live in 2011
| background          = group_or_band
| origin              = [[Hamburg]], Germany
| genre               = [[Industrial rock]], [[industrial metal]], [[electro-industrial]]
| years_active        = 1984\xe2\x80\x931999, 2002\xe2\x80\x93present
| label               = Z, Skysaw, [[Wax Trax! Records|Wax Trax!]], [[Metropolis Records|Metropolis]], [[Sanctuary Records|Sanctuary]], KMFDM
| associated_acts     = [[MDFMK]], [[Excessive Force]], [[Pig (band)|Pig]], [[KGC (band)|KGC]], [[Slick Idiot]], The Spittin\' Cobras
| website             = {{url|www.kmfdm.net}}
| current_members     = [[Sascha Konietzko]]<br/>[[Lucia Cifarelli]]<br/>[[Jules Hodgson]]<br/>[[Andy Selway]]<br/>[[Steve White (guitarist)|Steve White]]
| past_members        = [[Mark Durante]]<br/>[[En Esch]]<br/>Rudolf Naomi<br/>[[William Rieflin|Bill Rieflin]]<br/>[[G\xc3\xbcnter Schulz]]<br/>[[Tim Skold]]<br/>[[Raymond Watts]]}}

\'\'\'KMFDM\'\'\' <!--PLEASE DO NOT CHANGE THIS TO KEIN MITLEID F\xc3\x9cR DIE MEHRHEIT; IT IS INTENDED TO BE GRAMMATICALLY INCORRECT--PLEASE DO NOT CHANGE THE TRANSLATION TO "no majority for the pity"; WE ARE USING THE OFFICIAL BAND TRANSLATION IN THE LEAD, AND EXPLAINING IT IN THE BODY-->(originally \'\'\'Kein Mehrheit F\xc3\xbcr Die Mitleid\'\'\', loosely translated as "no pity for the majority")<ref name="1997 History"/> is an [[industrial music|industrial]] band led by German [[multi-instrumentalist]] [[Sascha Konietzko]], who founded the group in 1984 as a performance art project. KMFDM has released nineteen studio albums and two dozen singles, with sales of more than two million records worldwide.

The band has undergone many line-up changes and featured dozens of guest musicians. Its earliest incarnation included German drummer [[En Esch]] and British vocalist [[Raymond Watts]], the latter of whom left and rejoined the group several times over its history. German guitarist [[G\xc3\xbcnter Schulz]] joined in 1990; both he and Esch continued with the band until KMFDM broke up in 1999. Konietzko resurrected KMFDM in 2002 (Esch and Schulz declined to rejoin), and by 2005 he had assembled a consistent line-up that included American singer [[Lucia Cifarelli]], British guitarists [[Jules Hodgson]] and [[Steve White (guitarist)|Steve White]], and British drummer [[Andy Selway]].

Critics consider KMFDM to be one of the first bands to bring industrial music to mainstream audiences, though Konietzko refers to the band\'s music as "The Ultra-Heavy Beat". The band incorporates [[heavy metal (music)|heavy metal]] guitar riffs, [[electronic music]], samples, and both male and female vocals in its music, which encompasses a variety of styles. KMFDM normally tours at least once after every major release, and band members are known for their accessibility to and interaction with fans, both online and at concerts. Members, singly or working with each other and others, have recorded under many other names, primarily Watts\' [[Pig (musical project)|Pig]] in 1988, Konietzko\'s [[Excessive Force]] in 1991, and Esch and Schulz\'s [[Slick Idiot]] in 2001.

==History==

===Origin (1984)===
[[File:KMFDM Castle Party 2009 07.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Sascha Konietzko]] performing in Bolk\xc3\xb3w, Poland in July 2009]]
<!--***PLEASE read ALL of this paragraph AND the talk page before changing to "Kein Mitleid F\xc3\xbcr Die Mehrheit"***-->
KMFDM is an [[initialism]] for the nonsensical and grammatically incorrect [[German (language)|German]] phrase \'\'Kein Mehrheit F\xc3\xbcr Die Mitleid\'\', which literally translates as "no majority for the pity", but is typically given the loose translation of "no pity for the majority".<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/><ref name=deseret-may-1995/><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/outcast-clique-proud-role-article-1.830051 | author=Kennedy, Helen | title=Outcast Clique Proud of Role | work=[[New York Daily News]] | publisher=[[Mortimer Zuckerman]] | date=April 21, 1999 | accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref><ref name=CMJ-604/> In the original phrase, the articles preceding the nouns \'\'Mehrheit\'\' and \'\'Mitleid\'\' are [[inflection|inflected]] for the wrong [[grammatical gender|gender]], as the proper [[declension]] would be \'\'Keine Mehrheit f\xc3\xbcr das Mitleid.\'\' Swapping the two nouns yields the grammatically correct \'\'Kein Mitleid F\xc3\xbcr Die Mehrheit\'\', which translates directly as "no pity for the majority". In a 2003 interview, Konietzko explained the origins of the phrase:

{{quote|text="On the morning of February 29th, 1984 I woke up and went down to breakfast at a hotel in Paris. We had a show that night opening for an exhibition for young European artists.&nbsp;... we needed a motto for the night so that we could make up some fliers and post them around. There was a German newspaper on the table and so I started cutting out words and threw them all into a cap. We picked a few of them out and it read "Kein Mehrheit Fur Die Mitleid<nowiki>["]</nowiki>. It\'s kinda improper German in regards to its translation but in the [[Dada|DA-DA]]-esque{{sic}} mindset of the early morning it made perfect sense. So when I was on my way back to Hamburg I\'d mentioned it to [[Raymond Watts|Raymond [Watts]]]. He liked it but he was having difficulty pronouncing it correctly. So finally he said, \'Why don\'t you just call it KMFDM?\' So that was it. We were KMFDM."<ref name=mk/>}}

KMFDM was officially founded in Paris, France, on February 29, 1984, as a [[performance art]] project between [[Sascha Konietzko]] and German painter and multimedia artist Udo Sturm at the opening of an exhibition of young European artists at the [[Grand Palais]].<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/> The first show consisted of Sturm playing an [[ARP 2600]] synthesizer, Konietzko playing vacuum cleaners and bass guitars with their amplifiers spread throughout the building,<ref name="WDYKD">{{cite AV media notes | title=What Do You Know, Deutschland? | titlelink=What Do You Know, Deutschland? | others=KMFDM | year=2006 | type=CD booklet | page=2 | publisher=[[Metropolis Records]] | id=MET439 | location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania}}</ref> and four Polish coal miners (whom Konietzko had met at a [[bordello]])<ref name="RS740"/> pounding on the foundations of the Grand Palais.<ref name="1997 History">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/history.html | title=KMFDM History| publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=April 25, 2010 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/19970408173452/http://www.kmfdm.net/history.html |archivedate = April 8, 1997}}</ref>

===Early years in Germany (1984\xe2\x80\x9389)===
[[File:En esch 5 23 2006 arb.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[En Esch]] performing with [[Slick Idiot]] in Washington D.C. in May 2006]]
Sturm left early on,<ref name=AllMusic-bio/> but Konietzko continued performing, at one point having twenty people in his troupe, which by then was engaged in antics such as [[fire eating]] and throwing entrails at audiences.<ref name="RS740"/> Konietzko then returned to [[Hamburg]], where he joined up with [[Peter Missing]] in his new band [[Missing Foundation]].<ref name=AllMusic-bio/> Drummer Nicklaus Schandelmaier,<ref name="Miami">{{cite news | url=http://www.miaminewtimes.com/1995-10-26/music/kmfdm-blows-your-top/ | author=Cardenas, Georgina | title=KMFDM Blows Your Top | work=[[Miami New Times]] | page=2 | publisher=Miami New Times, LLC | date=October 26, 1995 | accessdate=March 1, 2010}}</ref> who had recently moved to Hamburg from Frankfurt, also joined the group, and took the stage name [[En Esch]]. Although the group did some live performances,<ref name=AllMusic-bio>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/artist/missing-foundations-mn0000501531 | author=Huey, Steve | title=Missing Foundation Biography | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref> Konietzko and Esch dropped out of Missing Foundation before any recordings were made and went back to work as KMFDM,<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/> collaborating with Hamburg-based studio owner [[Raymond Watts]].<ref name="1997 History"/>

Cassette copies of the band\'s first album, \'\'[[Opium (KMFDM album)|Opium]]\'\', began circulating through the underground clubs and bars of Hamburg in 1984.<ref name="1997 History"/> KMFDM released its next album, \'\'[[What Do You Know, Deutschland?]]\'\', in December 1986.<ref name="1997 History"/> It was recorded from 1983 to 1986, with some of the songs recorded by Konietzko and Watts before Esch was a member of the band,<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/> and indeed, before the band officially existed. Skysaw Records gave the album a second UK release in 1987 and introduced the band to visual artist [[Aidan Hughes]], usually credited as \'\'Brute!\'\'. Hughes redesigned the album\'s cover,<ref name="1997 History"/> and went on to design almost every KMFDM album cover.<ref name="AllMusic Bio">{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/artist/kmfdm-mn0000359062 | title=KMFDM Biography | author=Prato, Greg | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref>

Watts left the group after working on just three songs on 1988\'s \'\'[[Don\'t Blow Your Top (album)|Don\'t Blow Your Top]]\'\'<ref name=AllMusic-dbyt>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/dont-blow-your-top-mw0000198442 | author=Hinds, Andy | title=Don\'t Blow Your Top Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref> to start his own project, [[Pig (musical project)|Pig]].<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.raymondwatts.com/interviews/convulsionmagazine.html | title=Raymond Watts Interview | work=Convulsion Magazine | publisher=AK Distribution | year=1992 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227133704/http://www.raymondwatts.com/interviews/convulsionmagazine.html | archivedate=February 27, 2012}}</ref>  After working the Hamburg underground music scene and releasing albums on European labels, the band began its long-standing relationship with [[Wax Trax! Records]] when \'\'Don\'t Blow Your Top\'\' was licensed to the label for US distribution.<ref name="1997 History"/> The album was produced by [[Adrian Sherwood]], and was described by [[AllMusic]] critic Dave Thompson as "[highlighting] the producer as much as the band".<ref name="IGC"/>

===Success in America (1990\xe2\x80\x9394)===
{{listen | pos=right | filename=More & Faster 243.ogg | title="More & Faster 243" | description=The chorus of "More & Faster 243" off \'\'UAIOE\'\', a song called KMFDM\'s "first classic" which "shows some early glimpses of the band\'s sense of humor".<ref name=uaioe/>}}
KMFDM recorded and released its fourth album, \'\'[[UAIOE]]\'\', in early 1989 for distribution in both the U.S. and Europe,<ref name="1997 History"/> arrived in America for the first time on December 16,<ref name="Chicken">{{cite web | url=http://www.tlchicken.com/article.php?ARTid=1640 | title=A Completely Different Chicken: KMFDM\'s Sascha K. | work=Tastes Like Chicken | publisher=Tastes Like Chicken, LLC | date=November 10, 2007 | accessdate=March 6, 2010}}</ref> and commenced touring the U.S. with [[Ministry (band)|Ministry]].<ref name=AllMusic-bio/> During KMFDM\'s first US tour, band members started using the phrase "Kill Motherfucking [[Depeche Mode]]" for the acronym to tease journalists who did not understand German.<ref name=hybrid/> The band signed directly to Wax Trax! to distribute its fifth album, \'\'[[Na\xc3\xafve (album)|Na\xc3\xafve]]\'\',<ref name="1997 History"/> which was recorded in Europe and featured the debut of guitarist [[G\xc3\xbcnter Schulz]], known at the time as Svetlana Ambrosius. A [[Na\xc3\xafve/The Days of Swine & Roses|remix of the album\'s title track]] was the group\'s first hit, reaching No.&nbsp;21 on [[Hot Dance Club Songs|\'\'Billboard\'\'{{\'}}s Dance/Club Play Songs Chart]] in March 1991.<ref name="KMFDM singles"/>

Konietzko moved to Chicago in 1991,<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/><ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.seattleweekly.com/1999-04-28/music/guns-n-records/ | title=Guns n Records | work=Seattle Weekly | author=McCarthy, Jackie | publisher=Seattle Weekly, LLC | date=April 4, 1999 | accessdate=February 2010}}</ref> and Esch followed a year later. KMFDM quickly became a part of the Chicago industrial music scene that included Ministry, [[Front 242]], [[My Life with the Thrill Kill Kult]], and [[Revolting Cocks]].<ref name="nash">{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/?id=mw4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA10&dq=jim+nash#v=onepage&q=jim%20nash&f=false | author=Rosenblum, Trudi Miller | title=Jim Nash Dies at 47; Founder of Wax Trax! | page=10 | publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc]] | date=October 21, 1995 | accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref> Konietzko later remarked, "We came from Germany and we all had to have day jobs and work our asses off to afford to be KMFDM and all of a sudden were in the states and were selling thousands of thousands of {{sic}} fucking records!"<ref name=hybrid/>

The band\'s next club hit was "[[Split (KMFDM song)|Split]]", which was released in June 1991 and reached No.&nbsp;46 on \'\'Billboard\'\'{{\'}}s Dance/Club Play Songs Chart in July.<ref name="KMFDM singles">{{cite web | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=kmfdm|chart=Dance/Club Play Songs}} | title=KMFDM Dance/Club Play Songs | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | accessdate=March 6, 2010}}</ref> During 1991, Konietzko collaborated with [[Buzz McCoy]] of My Life With the Thrill Kill Kult to record an album under the name [[Excessive Force]] entitled \'\'[[Conquer Your World]]\'\'.<ref name=AllMusic-x-force/> Konietzko and Esch then began work on their halves of the intended sixth album, \'\'Apart\'\', which was eventually released as two separate albums.<ref name="Money 2006">{{cite AV media notes | title=Money | titlelink=Money (album) | others=KMFDM | year=2006 | type=CD booklet | pages=2\xe2\x80\x933 | publisher=[[Metropolis Records]] | id=MET463 | location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania}}</ref> Esch\'s half became his solo album, \'\'[[Cheesy (album)|Cheesy]]\'\', while the official KMFDM album used Konietzko\'s material and was renamed \'\'[[Money (album)|Money]]\'\'.<ref name="Money 2006"/> This album spawned two more club hits in 1992: "[[Vogue (KMFDM song)|Vogue]]", which reached No.&nbsp;19 on the Billboard Dance/Club Play Songs Chart in April, and [[Money (KMFDM song)|the title track]], which reached No.&nbsp;36 on that same chart in July.<ref name="KMFDM singles"/>

After touring in 1992 with drummer [[Chris Vrenna]],<ref>{{cite journal | title=Band News | work=KMFDM/Excessive Force Newsletter | page=3 | issue=1 | year=1991 | publisher=KMFDM Inc.}}</ref> the then-core of KMFDM (Konietzko, Esch, Schulz, and second guitarist [[Mark Durante]]) returned to Chicago and found that Wax Trax! had filed [[Chapter 11]] bankruptcy to begin corporate reorganization in November 1992.<ref name="1997 History"/><ref name=morristrib>{{cite news | url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-03-11/entertainment/9403110039_1_bill-morrissey-post-smiths-british-pop-singer/ | title=The Morrissey The Merrier | author=Kot, Greg | date=March 11, 1994 | work=[[Chicago Tribune]] | page=2 | publisher=[[Tribune Company]] | accessdate=May 10, 2012}}</ref> The band went into the studio in 1993 as a group to record its seventh album, \'\'[[Angst (KMFDM album)|Angst]]\'\', which sold more than 100,000 copies over the next two years.<ref name="Miami"/> Esch said after the album\'s release, "I like this album way more. \'\'Money\'\' was done in a hurry, and I was doing a major [[Pigface]] tour, so I didn\'t have much influence on the album. I really like \'\'Angst\'\'. I\'m totally down with it. We\'ve tried to involve guitar players, we tried to be like a real band, especially in the creative kind of aspect."<ref name=magnet>{{cite journal | url=http://glennk.org/~c510292/kmfdm/magnet.interview.html | author=Sutton, Jeneveve | title=Laff Mich Glucklich Seim | work=[[Magnet (magazine)|Magnet]] | publisher=Magnet Magazine Inc. |date=January 1994 | accessdate=July 19, 2012}}</ref> After the release of \'\'Angst\'\', Wax Trax!/TVT Records launched a promotion in which fans were encouraged to devise as many alternate meanings for KMFDM as possible, with more than a thousand submissions resulting.<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/> The 1994 song "Light" contains a possible alternate meaning: \'\'keiner Macht f\xc3\xbcr Dich mehr\'\' ("no more power for you").<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/lyrics/light.htm | title=Light Lyrics | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=September 9, 2010}}</ref>

Konietzko released a second album under the Excessive Force moniker in 1993 entitled \'\'[[Gentle Death]]\'\'.<ref name=AllMusic-x-force/> KMFDM received its first exposure to the mainstream with its single "[[A Drug Against War]]". Despite the band\'s anti-[[MTV]] stance,<ref name=hybrid/> the video of "A Drug Against War" received airplay on MTV<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/> and was shown on the MTV cartoon \'\'[[Beavis and Butt-head]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tv.com/shows/beavis-and-butthead/mr-andersons-balls-58234/# | title=Mr. Anderson\'s Balls Episode | publisher=[[CBS]] | accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref> The track "[[Light (KMFDM song)|Light]]" reached No.&nbsp;31 on the Billboard Dance/Club Play Songs Chart in May 1994.<ref name="KMFDM singles"/>

The song "Liebeslied" from \'\'Na\xc3\xafve\'\' originally contained an unlicensed sample of "O Fortuna" from [[Carl Orff]]\'s \'\'[[Carmina Burana (Orff)|Carmina Burana]]\'\'.<ref name="2002 History">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/history.html | title=KMFDM History on December 10, 2002 from archive.org | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=February 1, 2011 | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20021210104941/http://www.kmfdm.net/history.html |archivedate = December 10, 2002}}</ref> Orff\'s publisher threatened the band with legal action,<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/?id=en6jizvGCTgC&pg=PA91&dq=kmfdm+orff#v=onepage&q=kmfdm%20orff&f=false | author=Eddy, Chuck | title=Essentials | work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] | page=91 | publisher=Spin Media LLC | date=April 2010 | accessdate=July 27, 2012}}</ref> and the album was withdrawn from production in 1993. A new version of the album, entitled \'\'Na\xc3\xafve/Hell to Go\'\', was released the following year.<ref name="1997 History"/> It contained new mixes of several songs, including a version of "Liebeslied" with the offending sample removed.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/na%C3%AFve-hell-to-go-mw0000623828 | author=Hinds, Andy | title=Na\xc3\xafve/Hell To Go Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref>

Wax Trax! was saved from bankruptcy by an infusion of funds from [[TVT Records]],<ref name="1997 History"/><ref name="AllMusic Bio"/> and in March 1994 announced plans to release the compilation set \'\'[[Black Box \xe2\x80\x93 Wax Trax! Records: The First 13 Years]]\'\',<ref name=morristrib/> which includes the KMFDM songs "[[Virus (KMFDM song)|Virus]]" and "[[Godlike (song)|Godlike]]",<ref>{{cite web | url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r209175|pure_url=yes}} | title=Black Box: WaxTrax! Records \xe2\x80\x93 The First 13 Years | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=May 10, 2012}}</ref> two songs which Thompson called "defining".<ref name="IGC"/>

===Peak popularity (1994\xe2\x80\x9399)===
[[File:Chris and Ogre.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Chris Connelly (musician)|Chris Connelly]] (right) and [[Nivek Ogre]] in 1991. Both contributed guest vocals for KMFDM in the 1990s.]]
The mid-to-late 1990s were KMFDM\'s most successful years in terms of album sales and mainstream awareness. Konietzko moved to Seattle in 1994, while Esch moved to New Orleans.<ref name="2002 History"/> Watts rejoined the band to work on its eighth album, \'\'[[Nihil]]\'\', which peaked at No.&nbsp;16 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Heatseekers chart<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/nihil-mw0000175076/awards | title=Nihil: Charts and Awards | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 19, 2012}}</ref> and sold over 120,000 copies.<ref name="RS740">{{cite journal | url=http://www.waste.org/~alone/kmfdm/rsinterview.html | title=KMFDM make industrial music the old-fashioned way. They trash their hardware. | author=Wiederhorn, Jon | work=[[Rolling Stone]] | issue=740 | page=24 | publisher=Jann S. Wenner | date=August 8, 1996 | accessdate=March 22, 2010}}</ref> It marked the first contributions by drummer [[Bill Rieflin]], who worked with the band on its next five albums. \'\'Nihil\'\' featured KMFDM\'s most widely known song, "[[Juke Joint Jezebel]]", versions of which appeared on both the \'\'[[Bad Boys (soundtrack)|Bad Boys]]\'\' and \'\'[[Mortal Kombat (soundtrack)|Mortal Kombat]]\'\' soundtracks, the latter of which peaked at No.&nbsp;10 on the Billboard 200<ref>{{cite web | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=soundtrack|chart=all}} | title=Mortal Kombat Soundtrack | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | accessdate=March 2, 2010}}</ref> and sold over 1.8 million copies.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.raymondwatts.com/interviews/unhip.html | title=Raymond Watts Interview | work=Unhip | publisher=Unhip | year=1999 | issue=1 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227133711/http://www.raymondwatts.com/interviews/unhip.html | archivedate=February 27, 2012}}</ref>

Commenting on the rotating cast of musicians shortly after \'\'Nihil\'\'\'s release, Konietzko said, "It\'s as if En and I are the suns and the other musicians at the time come and revolve around us."<ref name=deseret-may-1995>{{cite news | url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/419161/NO-POLITICAL-RAGE-JUST-LIFE-NORMAL-STUFF-FOR-KMFDM.html | author=Iwasaki, Scott | title=No Political Rage, Just \'Life, Normal Stuff\' for KMFDM | work=[[Deseret News]] | page=1 | publisher=Jim M. Wall | date=May 5, 1995 | accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref> Regarding the duo\'s dynamic, Konietzko said, "En Esch and myself have always been the cornerstone of KMFDM\'s existence. And we are diametrically opposed as writers. The angsty stuff generally comes from him. The poppy, hard stuff comes from me."<ref name=daily-press/> Esch commented in 1994, "Sascha and myself are different, of course. But that\'s why we can still make things happen. Our best and worst qualities are contrary. To put it simply, he\'s more organized and stable, I\'m more complicated and abstract."<ref name=magnet/>
{{listen
| filename=Juke Joint Jezebel chorus.ogg
| title="Juke Joint Jezebel"
| description=The "snarling guitars <nowiki>[</nowiki>wrapped<nowiki>]</nowiki> in spiky synth barbed wire"<ref name=keyboard>{{cite journal | title=[[Keyboard (magazine)|Keyboard]] | page=120 | volume=21 | year=1995 | publisher=GPI Publications}}</ref> and "swooping, gospelish chorus"<ref name=tribune>{{cite news | url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-05-26/entertainment/9505260020_1_kmfdm-sascha-konietzko-en-esch | title=Industrial Arts | author=Kot, Greg | date=May 26, 1995 | work=[[Chicago Tribune]] | publisher=[[Tribune Company]] | accessdate=August 4, 2012}}</ref> from "Juke Joint Jezebel", KMFDM\'s biggest "hit"<ref name=AllMusic-nihil/>
| filename2=KMFDM Power.ogg
| title2="Power"
| description2=Konietzko wrote the "dumb and catchy"<ref name="Aquarian"/> song to satisfy the label\'s demand for a song for radio play, but hired [[Cheryl Wilson]] to lend "soul-mama vamping"<ref name="billboard-may 96">{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pw0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA84&dq#v=onepage&q=&f=false | title=Reviews and Previews: Singles | author=Flick, Larry | volume=108 | issue=21 | page=84 | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc]] | date=May 25, 1996 | accessdate=March 10, 2010}}</ref> to the chorus because he had heard "radio didn\'t like big female choruses".<ref name="Aquarian"/>}}
In late 1995, close friend and president of Chicago\'s Wax Trax! Jim Nash died of an illness complicated by AIDS,<ref name="nash"/> and Seattle became the official headquarters of KMFDM.<ref name="1997 History"/><ref name="AllMusic Bio"/> Watts toured with KMFDM throughout 1995 in support of \'\'Nihil\'\', but then left the group to return to recording under the Pig moniker. Esch also separated from the group, and \'\'[[Xtort]]\'\' was created in 1996 almost entirely without his input.<ref name=MacDonald-96/> Konietzko instead brought in a number of other industrial artists such as [[Chris Connelly (musician)|Chris Connelly]] to assist with the album.<ref name=MacDonald-96/> \'\'Xtort\'\' was the first KMFDM album to chart on the \'\'Billboard\'\' 200 and the highest-charting and best-selling album in the band\'s history, reaching No.&nbsp;92<ref name="Billboard">{{cite web | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=kmfdm|chart=all}} | title=KMFDM Billboard 200 | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref> and selling more than 200,000 copies.<ref name="Blog Critics">{{cite web | url=http://blogcritics.org/music/article/kmfdm/ | title=KMFDM Profile | work=[[Blogcritics]] | author=Olsen, Eric | authorlink=Eric Olsen (writer) | page=3 | publisher=Eric Olsen | date=October 5, 2003 | accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref> "Power", the album\'s first single, was the most heavily promoted song in the band\'s history, with almost 100,000 copies included in a free Wax Trax! sampler album in mid-1996.<ref name=borzillo/> Konietzko later said \'\'Xtort\'\' was his favorite album of the 1990s.<ref name="Xtort 2007">{{cite AV media notes | title=Xtort | others=KMFDM | year=2007 | type=CD booklet | publisher=[[Metropolis Records]] | location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania}}</ref>

Esch returned for the \'\'[[Symbols (album)|Symbols]]\'\' album, which was released in 1997 and featured [[Abby Travis]] and [[Skinny Puppy]]\'s [[Nivek Ogre]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/discography/albums/symbols.htm|title=Symbols Credits | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref> \'\'Symbols\'\' reached No.&nbsp;137 on the Billboard 200.<ref name="Billboard"/> Its first track, "Megalomaniac", was featured in the film \'\'[[Mortal Kombat: Annihilation]]\'\', and was the first song from its soundtrack to receive radio airplay.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/mortal-kombat-getting-ready-to-annihilate-america-19971015 | author=Bendersky, Ari | title=Mortal Kombat Getting Ready To Annihilate America | work=[[Rolling Stone]] | publisher=Jann S. Wenner | date=October 15, 1997 | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref>  [[Tim Skold]], formerly of the band [[Shotgun Messiah]], made his first appearance as a band member, writing lyrics and performing vocals on "Anarchy".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metropolis-records.com/artist/skold | title=Artists: Skold | publisher=[[Metropolis Records]] | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref><ref name="allbiz"/> Looking back on \'\'Symbols\'\' in 2002, Konietzko said, "I listened to the \'\'Symbols\'\' album and heard exactly why KMFDM broke up in the first place. It told me the story of what went wrong. There were maybe two (good) songs on that album and the others were just a bunch of compromising tug-of-wars. That was something I was not going to do again."<ref name=deseret-2002>{{cite news | url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/922248/KMFDM-back-together-after-strife.html | last=Iwasaki|first=Scott | title=KMFDM back together after strife | work=[[Deseret News]] | page=1 | publisher=Jim M. Wall | date=June 28, 2002 | accessdate=July 19, 2012}}</ref>

The band released a pair of [[compilation albums]] in 1998. The first, \'\'[[Retro (KMFDM album)|Retro]]\'\', was a greatest hits compilation which included most of the singles released up until \'\'Xtort\'\'.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/retro-mw0000601614 | author=Boldman, Gina | title=Retro Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 23, 2012}}</ref> The second, \'\'[[Agogo (album)|Agogo]]\'\', was a collection of rarities and previously unreleased tracks, including a cover of [[U2]]\'s "[[Mysterious Ways (song)|Mysterious Ways]]".

===\'\'Adios\'\' (1999)===
The album \'\'[[Adios (KMFDM album)|Adios]]\'\' was written and performed almost exclusively by Konietzko and Skold.<ref name="cmj july 1999"/> Ogre again provided vocals, as did German musician [[Nina Hagen]].<ref name="cmj july 1999">{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/?id=sikEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA51&dq=kmfdm+adios#v=onepage&q=kmfdm%20adios&f=false | title=Reviews: KMFDM-Adios | work=[[CMJ New Music Monthly]] | author=Jarman, David | publisher=CMJ Network, Inc | date=July 1999 | issue=71 | page=51 | accessdate=March 29, 2011}}</ref> Originally the fulfillment of the band\'s ten record contract with Wax Trax!/TVT,<ref name="cmj april 1999">{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/?id=H8S0WdfdaJQC&pg=PA14&lpg=PA14&dq=kmfdm+adios+-wikipedia+-mp3+-lyrics+contract#v=onepage&q=kmfdm%20adios%20-wikipedia%20-mp3%20-lyrics%20contract&f=false | title=Wax Trax!-TXT Offers KMFDM\'s Final Statement With \'Adios\' | work=[[CMJ New Music Report]] | author=Sciaretto, Amy | publisher=CMJ Network, Inc | issue=612 | page=14 | date=April 5, 1999 | accessdate=March 29, 2011}}</ref> \'\'Adios\'\' later signaled the breakup of the band itself,<ref name="cmj july 1999"/> which Esch\'s and Schulz\'s limited participation foreshadowed.<ref name="cmj july 1999"/>

KMFDM disbanded, albeit temporarily, on January 22, 1999, with only Konietzko and Skold remaining together.<ref name="allbiz"/> Konietzko said the split was due to "lots of stress and pressure, as well as differences in vision and drive".<ref name="allbiz">{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=oRAEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA13&lpg=PA13&dq=%22Kmfdm+Is+Back+With+\'Attak\'+On+Metropolis%22&source=bl&ots=F1H9ghYq1e&sig=qwETVwOVdyZwKWsDCJkA7KOoX_s&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Mp58T4mVOIXMgQfY4I3sCw&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Kmfdm%20Is%20Back%20With%20\'attak\'%20On%20Metropolis%22&f=false | title=Kmfdm Is Back With \'attak\' On Metropolis | author=McCormick, Moira | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc]] | volume=114 | number=14 | page=14 | date=April 6, 2002 | accessdate=April 4, 2012}}</ref> Esch said "There was a lot of negative energy between Sascha and G\xc3\xbcnter Schulz and myself and we all decided on the phone to call the band quits."<ref name="DML">{{cite web | url=http://deutschmusikland.com/RN/monamur_eneschinterview.php | title=Mona Mur & En Esch Interview | publisher=Deutschmusikland.com. Radio Nietzsche | date=March 2009 | accessdate=April 29, 2010}}</ref> \'\'Adios\'\' was released three months later, and reached No.&nbsp;189 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' 200.<ref name="Billboard"/> Its title track was called "a bitter goodbye".<ref name=AllMusic-adios>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/adios-mw0000034498 | author=Boldman, Gina | title=Adios Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref>

In the wake of the [[Columbine High School massacre]], it was revealed that lyrics to KMFDM songs ("Son of a Gun", "Stray Bullet", "Waste") were posted on the website of shooter [[Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold|Eric Harris]],<ref>{{cite book | url=http://books.google.com/?id=nF8YAQAAIAAJ&dq=KMFDM+songs | author=Wilson, Scott | title=Great Satan\'s Rage | chapter=Columbine | pages=138\xe2\x80\x93139 | publisher=[[Manchester University Press]] | year=2008 | accessdate=January 31, 2011 | isbn=978-0-7190-7463-9}}</ref> and that the date of the massacre, April 20, coincided with both the release date of the album \'\'Adios\'\'<ref name="MTV-speakout">{{cite web | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1427256/kmfdm-rammstein-speak-out-about-columbine.jhtml | title=KMFDM And Rammstein Speak Out About Columbine | publisher=[[MTV Networks]] | date=April 23, 1999 | accessdate=January 31, 2011}}</ref> and the birthday of [[Adolf Hitler]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DN&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI%7CDN&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB5CE474D7991CD&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | title=Music Linked To Killings? | work=[[Philadelphia Daily News]] | publisher=Knight Ridder | date=April 22, 1999 | accessdate=January 31, 2011}}</ref> Some journalists were quick to jump on the apparent connection of the massacre to violent entertainment and [[Nazism]],<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/daily/april99/suspects042299.htm | author=Duggan, Paul; Shear, Michael D.; Fisher, Marc | title=Shooter Pair Mixed Fantasy, Reality | work=[[Washington Post]] | page=A1 | publisher=[[Katharine Weymouth]] | date=April 22, 1999 | accessdate=January 31, 2011}}</ref> though one wrote, "Lyrically, the band has written some songs that could easily be misconstrued by anyone lacking an ear for irony and looking for an excuse to commit violence."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-54473896.html | author=Finn, Timothy | title=Record Industry Lets the Beat Go on Because Sex, Angst and Violence Sell | publisher=[[Knight Ridder/Tribune News Service]] | date=April 26, 1999 | accessdate=August 30, 2013}}{{subscription|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}</ref> In response, Konietzko issued a statement:

:"First and foremost, KMFDM would like to express their deep and heartfelt sympathy for the parents, families and friends of the murdered and injured children in Littleton. We are sick and appalled, as is the rest of the nation, by what took place in Colorado yesterday.\'\'<ref name="MTV-speakout"/><ref name="KMFDM1999">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/ | title=KMFDM.net on April 27, 1999 from archive.org | publisher=KMFDM Inc | date=April 27, 1999 | accessdate=April 21, 2010 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/19990427193333/http://www.kmfdm.net/ | archivedate = April 27, 1999}}</ref>

:"KMFDM are an art form\xe2\x80\x94not a political party. From the beginning, our music has been a statement against war, oppression, fascism and violence against others. While some of the former band members are German as reported in the media, none of us condone any Nazi beliefs whatsoever."<ref name="KMFDM1999"/><ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/an-old-debate-emerges-in-wake-of-shooting-19990422 | author=Boehlert, Eric | title=An Old Debate Emerges in Wake of School Shooting | work=[[Rolling Stone]] | publisher=Jann S. Wenner | date=April 23, 1999 | accessdate=March 31, 2010}}</ref>

===MDFMK, Slick Idiot, and reformation (2000\xe2\x80\x9302)===
[[File:KMFDM Castle Party 2009 02.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Lucia Cifarelli]] performing in Bolk\xc3\xb3w, Poland in July 2009]]
After the group disbanded, Schulz and Esch formed the band [[Slick Idiot]],<ref name="regenSI">{{cite web | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100111133749/http://www.regenmag.com/Reviews-1972-Slick-Idiot-Sucksess.html | url=http://www.regenmag.com/Reviews-1972-Slick-Idiot-Sucksess.html | title=Reviews: Slick Idiot \xe2\x80\x93 Sucksess | author=Y\xc3\xbccel, Ilker | work=ReGen Magazine | publisher=ReGen Media | date=October 22, 2009 | archivedate=January 11, 2010 | accessdate=March 7, 2012}}</ref> while Konietzko and Skold regrouped as [[MDFMK]], adding singer [[Lucia Cifarelli]] to form a trio.<ref name="MDFMK">{{cite web | url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p419913|pure_url=yes}} | title=MDFMK Overview | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref> MDFMK released one [[MDFMK (album)|self-titled album]] with [[Republic Records|Republic/Universal Records]], and toured North America.<ref name=mdfmk-mtv>{{cite web | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/871608/mdfmk-rock-us.jhtml | author=Moss, Corey | title=MDFMK Prepare For Sonic Assault Of U.S. | publisher=[[MTV Networks]] | date=May 4, 2000 | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref> After being released from his contract with Universal due to a disagreement over who would produce the next album, Konietzko said he called [[Metropolis Records]] and asked if they\'d be interested in signing KMFDM. The label agreed, although at the time only Konietzko himself was certain to participate.<ref name=mk/>

KMFDM reformed in 2002 with Konietzko, Skold, Cifarelli, and former collaborators Watts and Rieflin, due to "public demand" according to Konietzko,<ref name="allbiz"/> who said at the time, "I talked with the usual KMFDM suspects to see if they were interested, and what we came up with was something better than what we had before."<ref name=deseret-2002/> Recalled Esch in 2009, "I was happy about my new creative freedom at that time and so I refused the concept of a fast reunion of the original KMFDM."<ref name="DML"/> Konietzko said of the reformed band, "Not only is it fun again, but it\'s devoid of all the personal confrontations due to egos and fractions that were once a part of the band,"<ref name=deseret-2002/> but said, "I really miss En Esch," in 2003.<ref name=mk>{{cite web | url=http://www.mk-magazine.com/interviews/archives/000123.php | author=Curry, Chris | title=MK Magazine Interviews: KMFDM | work=MK Magazine | publisher=MK Magazine | date=November 1, 2003 | accessdate=July 12, 2012}}</ref> KMFDM released its first album in three years, \'\'[[Attak]]\'\', in March 2002. The album was on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Independent Albums Chart for four weeks, peaking at No.&nbsp;11.<ref name=kmfdm-ind>{{cite web | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=kmfdm|chart=Independent Albums}} | title= KMFDM Independent Albums Chart | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref>

===New line-up (2003\xe2\x80\x9307)===
Skold left after \'\'Attak\'\' to join [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]].<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/75601/twiggy-ramirez-exits-marilyn-manson | title=Twiggy Ramirez Exits Marilyn Manson | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc]] | year=2002 | accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref> Over the next few years, Watts\' bandmates from Pig joined KMFDM one by one. [[Jules Hodgson]] had already done guitar work for 2002\'s \'\'Attak\'\'.<ref name=jules>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/bio/jules_pr.htm | title=Jules Hodgson Profile | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref> [[Andy Selway]] first played drums for KMFDM on \'\'[[WWIII (album)|WWIII]]\'\' in 2003,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/bio/andy_pr.htm | title=Andy Selway Profile | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref> and [[Steve White (guitarist)|Steve White]] contributed to 2005\'s \'\'[[Hau Ruck]]\'\' after touring with the band.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/bio/steve_pr.htm | title=Steve White Profile | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref> All three, along with Watts and Cifarelli, were mentioned as band members on "Intro", the final track on \'\'WWIII\'\',<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/lyrics/intro.htm | title=Intro Lyrics | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=July 19, 2012}}</ref> although that was to be the last album on which Watts performed. \'\'WWIII\'\' was on \'\'Billboard\'\'{{\'}}s Dance/Electronic Albums Chart for seven weeks, and peaked at No.&nbsp;3.<ref name=nu-kmfdm-chart>{{cite web | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=kmfdm|chart=Dance/Electronic Albums C}} | title= KMFDM Dance/Electronic Albums Chart | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | accessdate=March 6, 2010}}</ref>

\'\'Opium\'\' was re-released in 2002 as KMFDM001 on the band\'s new label, KMFDM Records,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/discography/albums/opium.htm | title=Discography: Opium | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=May 24, 2012}}</ref> and [[84\xe2\x80\x9386|a collection of songs recorded between 1984\xe2\x80\x9386]] was released in 2004.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.future-retro.com/kmfdmspotlight.html | title=Artist Spotlight: KMFDM | work=[[Future Retro]] | publisher=Jered Flickinger | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311184059/http://www.future-retro.com/kmfdmspotlight.html | archivedate=March 11, 2012}}</ref> Shortly after the release of \'\'WWIII\'\', Konietzko began work on the soundtrack for 2004\'s [[Spider-Man 2 (video game)|\'\'Spider-Man 2\'\' video game]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/discography/webmp3.htm | title=Discohraphy: Web/MP3s | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref> \'\'Hau Ruck\'\' performed about as well \'\'WWIII\'\', appearing on \'\'Billboard\'\'{{\'}}s Dance/Electronic Albums Chart for eight weeks but only hitting No.&nbsp;5.<ref name=nu-kmfdm-chart/> Unlike \'\'WWIII\'\', \'\'Hau Ruck\'\' showed up on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Independent Albums chart for a single week at No.&nbsp;48.<ref name=kmfdm-ind/> A companion EP, \'\'[[Ruck Zuck (EP)|Ruck Zuck]]\'\', was released in 2006.

Konietzko took a new approach for \'\'[[Tohuvabohu]]\'\', released in 2007. "Principally in the past, there used to be 2 people that would start songs: me and Jules. On this record I said to the other 2 guys, Andy (Selway) and Steve (White), \'Why don\'t you guys come up with something?\'"<ref name=ult-guitar/> \'\'Tohuvabohu\'\' was on \'\'Billboard\'\'{{\'}}s Dance/Electronic Albums Chart for just three weeks and peaked at No.&nbsp;4.<ref name=nu-kmfdm-chart/> It appeared on the Independent Albums Chart for one week at No.&nbsp;29.<ref name=kmfdm-ind/>  \'\'Tohuvabohu\'\' also had a companion, \'\'[[Brimborium]]\'\', a full length remix album released in 2008 that barely made it onto \'\'Billboard\'\'{{\'}}s Dance/Electronic Albums Chart, hitting No.&nbsp;20 for a single week.<ref name=nu-kmfdm-chart/>

Metropolis Records announced in mid-2006 it would reissue KMFDM\'s entire Wax Trax!-era studio album back catalog, which had been out of print since the early 2000s. The albums were released in chronological order in groups of two or three from September 2006 to May 2007.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdmrecords.com/news/ | title=News | publisher=KMFDM Records. KMFDM Inc | accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref> Konietzko said the remastering was done over concerns about losing the rights to the back catalog after TVT defaulted on a loan, explaining, "The original agreement was that the catalog would have reverted back to me in 2008, anyway, but TVT and Rykodisc were thinking of just making a KMFDM compilation, which would have eliminated my catalog, and I didn\'t want that."<ref name=deseret-2006>{{cite news | url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/650192580/KMFDM-playing-until-fun-stops.html | author=Iwasaki, Scott | title=KMFDM playing until fun stops | work=[[Deseret News]] | publisher=Jim M. Wall | date=September 22, 2006 | accessdate=August 12, 2012}}</ref> Konietzko commented in 2006 that the current line-up was the best he had worked with,<ref name=deseret-2006/> and said in a separate interview that his former bandmates were "looking at me for handouts".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/entertainment/2003325086_kmfdm27.html | author=Scanlon, Tom | title=Seattle\'s KMFDM is a clown-free zone | work=[[Seattle Times]] | publisher=[[The Seattle Times Company]] | date=October 27, 2006 | accessdate=July 19, 2012}}</ref> Konietzko announced in October 2007 that he was packing up and moving back to Germany in the next three months.<ref name=hybrid/>

===Back in Germany (2007\xe2\x80\x93present)===
[[File:Tim Skold of Marilyn Manson, live in Florence 29052007 1.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Tim Skold]] performing with [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]] in 2007]]
Following the Finnish [[school shooting]]s of [[Jokela school shooting|2007]] and [[Kauhajoki school shooting|2008]], media reports again attempted to draw a connection between the shooters and the band, and noted that both listed KMFDM among their favorite bands.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/europe/11/08/school.shooting/index.html | accessdate=October 13, 2008 | first=Phil | last=Black | date=November 8, 2007 | title=Finland in mourning after fatal school shooting | work=[[CNN]] | publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080219170829/http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/europe/11/08/school.shooting/index.html |archivedate = February 19, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://tvnz.co.nz/world-news/gunman-kills-10-in-finnish-school-2100588 | title=Gunman kills 10 in Finnish school | date=September 24, 2008 | work=TVNZ | publisher=Reuters}}</ref> In an interview with Norwegian broadcaster [[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation|NRK]] shortly after the 2008 incident, Konietzko responded to these claims by saying the recent shootings were a by-product of the [[copycat crimes|copycat]] mentality and the Finnish shooters\' desire to emulate the lifestyles and actions of the Columbine shooters. "One of my biggest concerns immediately following this incident [the Columbine shooting] was that there would be copycats repeating such things in the future, as there often are when people commit heinous crimes and acts of violence. I was, unfortunately, right."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nrk.no/kultur-og-underholdning/1.6241067 | author=Fredriksen, Alexander & Moen, Siri Narverud | title=Don\'t Shoot Up the School | publisher=NRK \xe2\x80\x93 Norsk Rikskringkasting | date=September 30, 2008 | accessdate=April 7, 2010}}</ref>

KMFDM re-released all of its old singles and hard-to-find tracks from before the 1999 breakup in a series of three double albums called \'\'Extra\'\'\xe2\x80\x94\'\'[[Extra, Vol. 1|Vol. 1]]\'\', \'\'[[Extra, Vol. 2|Vol. 2]]\'\', and \'\'[[Extra, Vol. 3|Vol. 3]]\'\'\xe2\x80\x94in mid-2008. KMFDM Records released \'\'[[Skold vs. KMFDM]]\'\' in early 2009, which was a collaboration that Skold and Konietzko conducted over the Internet while on separate continents from June to October 2008.<ref name=anti-svk>{{cite web | url=http://www.antimusic.com/news/09/feb/10Skold_vs._KMFDM.shtml | title=Skold vs. KMFDM | work=Antimusic | publisher=Iconoclast Entertainment Group | date=February 10, 2009 | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref> A follow-up is planned, but is not a high priority.<ref name=terror-2010>{{cite journal | title=[[Terrorizer (magazine)|Terrorizer]]: Dominion | issue=5 | page=11 | publisher=Dark Arts Ltd | date=August 2010}}</ref>

KMFDM\'s sixteenth studio album, \'\'[[Blitz (album)|Blitz]]\'\', released in March 2009, showcased further collaboration with Skold, but less input from the band members not living in Germany. It reached No.&nbsp;4 on \'\'Billboard\'\'{{\'}}s Dance/Electronic Albums Chart, and was on the chart for four weeks.<ref name=nu-kmfdm-chart/> Its companion remix album, \'\'[[Krieg_(album)|Krieg]]\'\', was released in early 2010.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.fearnet.com/news/review/kmfdm-krieg-cd-review | author=Burkart, Gregory | title=KMFDM: \'KRIEG\' - CD Review | work=FearNet | date=March 31, 2010 | accessdate=June 22, 2012}}</ref> Two compilation albums, \'\'[[W\xc3\xbcrst]]\'\' and \'\'[[Greatest Shit]]\'\', were released in September that same year.<ref name=metrokmfdm>{{cite web | url=http://www.metropolis-records.com/artist/kmfdm | title=Artists: KMFDM | publisher=[[Metropolis Records]] | accessdate=May 7, 2012}}</ref>

On December 14, 2010, the official KMFDM website was changed to include a single image with the text "All Systems Have Been Ripped. The Internet Has Been Shut Down." A new song titled "Rebels in Control" became available for listening and download on the site, posted in support of [[Julian Assange]] with regards to the controversy over [[WikiLeaks]].<ref name="SideLine">{{cite web | url=http://www.side-line.com/news_comments.php?id=45590_0_2_0_C | title=KMFDM Wikileaks tribute song gets over 75.000 streams in 48 hours | work=SideLine News | publisher=SideLine | date=December 23, 2010 | accessdate=January 18, 2011}}</ref><ref name="KMFDM news">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/news/news.htm | title=KMFDM News | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=January 17, 2011}}</ref>

Former band members Durante, Esch, Schulz, and Watts appeared with [[Mona Mur]] at the April 2011 Wax Trax! Retrospectacle in Chicago,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://regenmag.com/interviews/done-with-the-past/ | author=Ilker, Y\xc3\xbccel | title=Done with the Past | work=ReGen Magazine | publisher=ReGen Media | date=December 11, 2011 | accessdate=July 19, 2012}}</ref> a charity event celebrating the industrial music label.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.slicingupeyeballs.com/2011/02/16/wax-trax-records-retrospectacle-anniversary-concert-chicago/ | author= | title=Wax Trax! \'Retrospectacle\': Front 242, Thrill Kill Kult, members of KMFDM, RevCo | work=Slicing Up Eyeballs | publisher=in this world, among all others | date=February 16, 2011 | accessdate=July 23, 2012}}</ref> The group performed KMFDM songs from the Wax Trax! era, including "Juke Joint Jezebel", "Godlike, "[[Brute (song)|Brute]]", and "[[Don\'t Blow Your Top (song)|Don\'t Blow Your Top]]".<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/westcoastsound/2011/04/wax_trax_retrospectacle_annive.php | author=Bodine-Fischer, Diamond | title=Wax Trax! Retrospectacle: 33 1/3 Anniversary with Front 242, Thrill Kill Kult, members of KMFDM, Revolting Cocks and more | work=[[LA Weekly]] | page=2 | publisher=LA Weekly, LP | date=April 18, 2011 | accessdate=July 23, 2012}}</ref> Konietzko expressed a desire to perform with the current band line-up, but was turned down by event organizers.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/weekend/4817008-421/story.html | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5xyI9IWl7 | author=Conner, Thomas | title=Where\'s Al Jourgensen? | work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] | publisher=Sun-Times Media, LLC | date=April 14, 2011 | archivedate = April 15, 2011 | accessdate=April 21, 2011}}</ref>
{{listen | filename=Krank sample.ogg | title="Krank" | description=Part of the chorus from "Krank", which critics called "adrenalin-pumping"<ref name=terror-2011>{{cite journal | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/press/print/dominion-2011.jpg | journal=[[Terrorizer (magazine)|Terrorizer]]: Dominion | author=Hoon, Ross | title=Digital Evolution | issue=9 | page=7 | publisher=Dark Arts Ltd | date=March 2011 | accessdate=March 12, 2011}}</ref> and "an aggressive stomper in the best KMFDM tradition".<ref name="reflect">{{cite web | url=http://www.reflectionsofdarkness.com/artists-k-o-cdreviews-133/9221-cd-review-kmfdm-krank.html | title=CD Review: KMFDM \xe2\x80\x93 Krank | author=Uhlenbruch, J. | publisher=Reflections of Darkness | date=March 21, 2011 | accessdate=March 26, 2011}}</ref>}}
KMFDM released \'\'[[WTF?!]]\'\' in April 2011, featuring what Konietzko called "a slew of guest musicians"<ref name="noise">{{cite news | url=http://www.noisecreep.com/2010/03/19/kmfdm-are-neck-deep-in-new-material-will-feature-guest-musici/ | title=KMFDM are Neck Deep in New Material | author=Sciarretto, Amy | work=Noise Creep | publisher=AOL Inc. | date=March 19, 2010 | accessdate=May 8, 2010}}</ref> including Rieflin, [[Koichi Fukuda]], [[Free Dominguez]], and [[William Wilson (vocalist)|William Wilson]].<ref name=terror-2010/><ref name=wtf>{{cite AV media notes | title=WTF?! | others=KMFDM | year=2011 | type=CD booklet | pages=5, 11 | publisher=[[Metropolis Records]] | id=MET708 | location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania}}</ref> The album\'s first single, "Krank", charted in both Germany and the United States.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.side-line.com/reviews_comments.php?id=46416_0_17_0_C+KMFDM | title=KMFDM \xe2\x80\x93 WTF?! (CD \xe2\x80\x93 Dependent/KMFDM Records) | work=SideLine News | publisher=SideLine | date=June 20, 2011 | accessdate=November 16, 2011}}</ref> \'\'WTF?!\'\' was on \'\'Billboard\'\'{{\'}}s Dance/Electronic Albums Chart for one week at No.&nbsp;8.<ref name=nu-kmfdm-chart/>

Work on KMFDM\'s eighteenth album began in February 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/blogs/kaptain.htm | title=K\xc3\xa4pt\'n\'s Korner | author=Konietzko, Sascha | authorlink=Sascha Konietzko | publisher=KMFDM Inc | date=January 31, 2012 |accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref> Titled \'\'[[Kunst (album)|Kunst]]\'\', it was released on February 26, 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3201992/kmfdm-announces-new-album-release-date-and-reveal-nsfw-album-cover/ | title = KMFDM Announces New Album, Release Date, AND Reveal NSFW Album Cover | author=Barkan, Jonathan | publisher=Bloody Disgusting | date=November 5, 2012 | accessdate = November 5, 2012}}</ref> The band toured the United States in March and Europe in April 2013.<ref name=2013-tour>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/tour/tour.htm | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6FLYFhT25 | title=KMFDM Tour Dates | publisher=KMFDM Inc | archivedate=March 23, 2013}}</ref> KMFDM reissued \'\'Opium\'\' and \'\'WWIII\'\' in October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://exclaim.ca/News/kmfdm_reissue_opium_wwiii_announce_north_american_tour|title=KMFDM Reissue \'Opium\' and \'WWIII,\' Announce North American Tour|date=August 19, 2013|accessdate=November 9, 2013|publisher=[[Exclaim!]]}}</ref>

On May 24, 2014, Konietzko announced on the band\'s [[Facebook]] page that a new album, entitled \'\'Our Time Will Come\'\', would be released on October 14, 2014. A new live album entitled \'\'We Are KMFDM\'\' and a single called "Genau (The German in You)" were also announced.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.facebook.com/officialkmfdm/posts/10152469403757658 | first=Sascha | last=Konietzko | authorlink=Sascha Konietzko | title=KMFDM Facebook Post May 24, 2014 beginning "K\xc3\xa4pt\'n here...." | publisher=[[Facebook]] | date=May 24, 2014 | accessdate=May 24, 2014}}</ref>

{{clear}}

==Musical style==
[[File:Kmfdm jules starlite.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Jules Hodgson]] performing in Edmonton, Canada in October 2004]]
KMFDM\'s earliest output was [[performance art]],<ref name="KMFDM news"/> as Konietzko incorporated not only visuals such as burning beds and exploding televisions,<ref name="Miami"/> but also non-musical devices used as instruments, e.g. vacuum cleaners.<ref name="Miami"/><ref name="dunedin"/> The 1980s albums featured heavy use of [[sample (music)|sampling]] and studio manipulations, and the primary instruments used were [[synthesizer]]s and [[drum machines]]. Konietzko has cited [[T.Rex (band)|T.Rex]], [[David Bowie]], and [[Frank Zappa]] as inspiration in the early stages of KMFDM.<ref name="Chicken"/><ref name="Blog Critics"/> Before forming the band, he listened to [[punk music]] and "true industrial" bands such as [[Throbbing Gristle]].<ref name=daily-press>{{cite news | url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1995-10-20/features/9510200261_1_kmfdm-sascha-konietzko-en-esch | author=McDonald, Sam | title=Moral Minority: German-born Industrial Rock Group Kmfdm Has \'No Pity For The Majority\' | work=[[Daily Press (Virginia)|Daily Press]] | publisher=Digby Solomon | date=October 20, 1995 | accessdate=July 14, 2012}}</ref>

The band\'s music has been described as [[industrial music|industrial]],<ref name=amg-guide>{{cite book | title=All Music Guide to Rock: The Definitive Guide to Rock, Pop, and Soul | first=Stephen Thomas | last=Erlewine | page=627 | year=2002 | publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] | url=http://books.google.com/?id=1-pH4i3jXvAC&pg=PA627&dq=kmfdm+industrial#v=onepage&q=kmfdm%20industrial&f=false | isbn=978-0-87930-653-3| accessdate=July 27, 2012}}</ref> [[industrial rock]],<ref name=CMJ-604>{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/?id=9uYwm-dwInwC&pg=PA4&dq=kmfdm+industrial#v=onepage&q=kmfdm%20industrial&f=false | journal=[[CMJ New Music Report]] | title=Top Stories: KMFDM Calls It Quits | editor=Mitchel, Wendy | volume=57 | issue=604 | page=4 | publisher=CMJ Network, Inc | date=February 8, 1999 | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref> [[industrial metal]],<ref name=DiPerna>{{cite journal |author=Di Perna, Alan | title=Jackhammer of the Gods | work=[[Guitar World]] | volume=15 | issue=6 | page=69 | year=1995 | publisher=[[Hal Leonard Corporation]]}}</ref> and [[techno]]-industrial.<ref>{{cite journal | journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | title=CMT Spots a \'Turn On\'; KMFDM Cries Censorship | last=Atwood | first=Brett | url=http://books.google.com/?id=mw4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA93&dq=kmfdm+industrial#v=onepage&q=kmfdm%20industrial&f=false | volume=107 | issue=42 | page=93 | publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc]] | date=October 21, 1995 | accessdate=July 27, 2012}}</ref>
While recognized along with Ministry, [[Nine Inch Nails]], and Skinny Puppy as pioneers in introducing industrial music to mainstream audiences,<ref name="IGC">{{cite book | url=http://books.google.com/?id=ZHP-r9-eqdAC&pg=PA70&dq=sascha+konietzko#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Alternative Rock | chapter=The Industrial Gothic Complex | pages=70\xe2\x80\x9371 | author=Thompson, Dave | publisher=[[Hal Leonard Corporation]] | year=2000 | accessdate=September 9, 2010 | isbn=978-0-87930-607-6}}</ref> KMFDM describes its sound as "The Ultra-Heavy Beat".<ref name="dunedin">{{cite web | url=http://dunedinfreepress.com/kmfdm2.htm | author=Brennan, Frances | title=KMFDM | work=The Dunedin Free Press | publisher= Dunedin Free Press/Brennan Ink | year=2009 | accessdate=December 29, 2009}}</ref> Konietzko once stated, "If I was to give myself a label it would be industrial-alternative-electronic-crossover-rock and danceabilly."<ref name="IGC"/>

The band has made heavy use of guitars since its inception,<ref name="IGC"/> and pioneered their use during the band\'s early days in Germany.<ref name=daily-press/> Although not a metal fan, Konietzko said his "infatuation with ripping off metal [[Lick (music)|licks]]" stemmed from his experiments with [[E-MU Systems|E-mu]]\'s [[E-mu Emax|Emax]] [[Sampler (musical instrument)|sampler]] in late 1986, adding, "What I always hated most about heavy metal was that the best riffs came only once and were never repeated. So the fascination, actually, was to sample a great riff, [[Music loop|loop]] it, and play it over and over again."<ref name=DiPerna/> While the album \'\'Don\'t Blow Your Top\'\' was more sparse in content, due to the influence of producer Sherwood,<ref name="IGC"/><ref name="robbins 369">{{cite book | author=Robbins, Ira A. | title=The Trouser Press record guide | page=369 | year=1991 | isbn=978-0-02-036361-3 | publisher=[[Collier Books]]}}</ref> it was the exception rather than the rule. Ministry founder and frontman [[Al Jourgensen]], on tour with the band in 1989, described KMFDM as "a battalion of guitars marching through Europe."<ref name="IGC"/>
{{listen | filename=What Do You Know sample.ogg |title="What Do You Know?" | description=This song, from the band\'s second album, features "scathing political commentary&nbsp;... that helped define the group\'s subversive identity",<ref name=AllMusic-wdykd/> sampling a speech by former U.S. president [[John F. Kennedy]].}}
KMFDM\'s music has since been a fusion of [[electronic music|electronic]] and [[heavy metal (music)|heavy metal]],<ref name="IGC"/><ref name="robbins 369"/> with occasional elements of [[dub music|dub]],<ref name="robbins 369"/><ref>{{cite journal | title=KMFDM: Money | work=Option magazine issues 42\xe2\x80\x9347 | page=111 | publisher=Sonic Options Network | year=1992}}</ref> as well as orchestral samples<ref>{{cite book | url=http://books.google.com/?id=nH9oejneZtQC&q=%22Beastie+Boys+with+grand+orchestral%22&dq=%22Beastie+Boys+with+grand+orchestral%22 | author=Robbins, Ira A. | title=The Trouser Press guide to \'90s rock | page=398 | year=1997 | publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]] | accessdate=April 4, 2011 | isbn=978-0-684-81437-7}}</ref> and live horns.<ref name="Aquarian">{{cite news | url=http://www.beermelodies.com/interviews/kmfdm-ready-to-%E2%80%98xtort%E2%80%99-2/ | title=KMFDM Ready to \'Xtort\' | author=Fortunato, John | work=[[The Aquarian Weekly]] | publisher=Arts Weekly, Inc. | year=1996 | accessdate=April 23, 2010}}</ref> Many songs feature prominent backing vocals by female singers<ref name=AllMusic-nihil>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/nihil-mw0000175076 | author=Hinds, Andy | title=Nihil Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 15, 2012}}</ref> such as [[Dorona Alberti]],<ref name="Hinds Angst">{{cite web | url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r203823|pure_url=yes}} | title=Angst Review | author=Hinds, Andy | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=April 4, 2011}}</ref> Travis, and Cifarelli. Many of the musicians who have played in the band are [[multi-instrumentalist]]s, so there is a degree of versatility and freedom in the music.<ref name=hybrid/>

Many albums feature one or more songs in which the band lampoons itself, notably in the lyrics to "Sucks"<ref name="Hinds Angst"/> and "Inane".<ref name=MacDonald-96>{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9CwEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT39&dq#v=onepage&q=&f=false | title= Reviews | author=MacDonald, Heidi | page=40 | work=[[CMJ New Music Monthly]] | publisher=CMJ Network, Inc | date=September 1996 | accessdate=April 4, 2011}}</ref> The band\'s "cynical detachment" has been compared to [[Steely Dan]].<ref name=MacDonald-95/> The band\'s lyrics often express political concerns<ref name=AllMusic-nihil/><ref name="Hinds Angst"/> and call for the rejection of and resistance to terrorism, violence, oppression, censorship, and war.<ref name=terror-lyrics>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/lyrics/terror.htm | title=Lyrics: Terror | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/lyrics/glory.htm | title=Lyrics: Glory | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref> In the 1995 song "Terror", Konietzko specifically warns, "[[Fundamentalist]] forces are undermining the integrity of [[liberalism|liberal]] and democratic political structures".<ref name=terror-lyrics/> Samples of news broadcasts and speeches by political leaders are sometimes featured in songs.<ref name="robbins 369"/> Konietzko has said that while the 2003 album \'\'WWIII\'\' is critical of then-president [[George W. Bush]], who was sampled extensively for the album,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.splendidezine.com/review.html?reviewid=106497585768161 | title=Reviews KMFDM: WWIII | author=Zahora, George | work=Splendid Magazine | publisher=Splendid WebMedia | date=October 15, 2003 | accessdate=June 8, 2012}}</ref> "It\'s not an anti-Bush record per se, it\'s an anti-stupidity record", and, "If we had a message, it would be: Think for Yourself and Don\'t Believe the Bullshit."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=100&story_id=895 | title=KMFDM bring sound of \'WWIII\' | author=Chernov, Sergey |work=[[St. Petersburg Times]] | issue=928 | volume=50 | publisher=The St. Petersburg Times | date=July 2, 2004 | accessdate=June 8, 2012}}</ref>

==Reception==
As of July 2007, KMFDM had sold approximately two million records worldwide.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.revolvermag.com/news/kmfdm-return-with-new-album.html | title=KMFDM Return with New Album | work=[[Revolver (magazine)|Revolver]] | publisher=Future US Inc | date=July 12, 2007 | accessdate=July 24, 2012}}</ref> Critics have been widely positive of KMFDM, though less enthusiastic about the band\'s earliest work. \'\'What Do You Know, Deutschland?\'\' was called "less energetic" and \'\'Don\'t Blow Your Top\'\' was called "a little flimsy" in comparison to later albums by AllMusic critics Andy Hinds and Vincent Jeffries, respectively.<ref name=AllMusic-dbyt/><ref name=AllMusic-wdykd/> \'\'UAIOE\'\', when the band\'s sound began to develop, was called "more assured" by Hinds and "more representative of KMFDM\'s true motives" by Thompson, who added that KMFDM\'s guitar-heavy sound inspired Ministry\'s own embrace of the instrument after the bands toured together in 1990.<ref name="IGC"/><ref name=uaioe>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/uaioe-mw0000206538 | author=Hinds, Andy | title=UAIOE Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 19, 2012}}</ref>
[[File:KMFDM Castle Party 2009 13.jpg|thumb|left|[[Steve White (guitarist)|Steve White]] performing in Bolk\xc3\xb3w, Poland in July 2009]]
The first major breakthrough in the band\'s critical reception was 1990\'s \'\'Na\xc3\xafve\'\', called "one of their strongest releases" by [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of AllMusic,<ref>{{cite book | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Bgn9SGmA4dkC&pg=PA627#v=onepage&q=&f=false | title=All Music Guide to Rock: The Definitive Guide to Rock, Pop, and Soul 3rd Edition | last=Erlewine | page=627 | publisher=Backbeat Books | first=Stephen Thomas | isbn=978-0-87930-653-3 | year=2002 | accessdate=July 27, 2012}}</ref> "brilliant" by fellow AllMusic critic Ned Raggett,<ref name=am-naive>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/na%C3%AFve-mw0000262101 | title=KMFDM Na\xc3\xafve Review | author=Raggett, Ned | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=March 12, 2010}}</ref> "superb" by Hinds,<ref name=am-angst>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/angst-mw0000114024 | title=Angst Review | author=Hinds, Andy | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref> and "the most fun \'industrial dance\' album ever" by \'\'Spin\'\' critic Chuck Eddy.<ref name="spin">{{cite news | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_hQxGHrtDC0C&pg=PT74#v=onepage&q=&f=false | title=KMFDM Money Review | author=Eddy, Chuck | work=Spin Magazine | page=71 | publisher=Bob Guccioni Jr. | date=July 1992 | accessdate=March 12, 2010}}</ref> The subsequent albums released in the 1990s were described as some of the band\'s strongest by AllMusic critic Greg Prato,<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/> with their metal guitars, industrial beats, and dance floor sensibilities praised by Ira Robbins and \'\'[[CMJ New Music Monthly]]\'\' critic Heidi MacDonald.<ref name="robbins 369"/><ref name=MacDonald-95>{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=LC0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q=&f=false | title = Best New Music: KMFDM Nihil | author=MacDonald, Heidi | work=[[CMJ New Music Monthly]] | page=15 | publisher=CMJ Network, Inc | date=May 1995 | accessdate=March 10, 2010}}</ref> Michael Saunders of the \'\'[[Boston Globe]]\'\' said of the band: "It\'s a small field, but KMFDM is tops in it: makers of dense, danceable, post-industrial torrents of noise. The German band specializes in fabricating aural assaults that can be intimidating to the uninitiated."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8329021.html | author=Saunders, Michael | title=KMFDM turns up the noise | work=[[Boston Globe]] | publisher=Christopher M. Mayer | date=May 23, 1995}}</ref> MacDonald said in 1996, "With Ministry gone grindcore, Skinny Puppy just gone, and Nine Inch Nails a brand name, KMFDM is now the standard bearer of industrial",<ref name=MacDonald-96/> though Erlewine and Hinds felt the band was losing some steam towards the end of the decade.<ref name=AllMusic-xtort>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/xtort-mw0000648344 | author=Erlewine, Stephen Thomas | title=Xtort Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref><ref name=AllMusic-symbols>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/symbols-mw0000028951 | author=Hinds, Andy | title=Symbols Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref>

Greg Rule declared in 1999, after its temporary disbandment, that KMFDM had "produced nine high-impact records that have earned them a large, loyal fanbase strewn across the planet."<ref>{{cite book | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=n8jXbBgHKNsC&pg=PT220&dq=kmfdm&hl=en&sa=X&ei=NBapT82NF4XAtwf976CXDw&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=kmfdm&f=false | title=Electro Shock!: Groundbreakers of Synth Music | author=Rule, Greg | chapter=4: KMFDM | page=211 | year=1999 | publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation | isbn=0-87930-582-7 | accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref> Erlewine called the band "one of Wax Trax\'s first industrial superstars", "an underground sensation", and "one of the major industrial bands of the \'90s."<ref name=amg-guide/> Most of the band\'s albums released in the 21st century have been well-received, although Prato and \'\'ReGen Magazine\'\'{{\'}}s Ilker Y\xc3\xbccel have commented on the sameness from one album to the next.<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/hau-ruck-mw0000396597 | author=Prato, Greg | title=Hau Ruck Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.regenmag.com/Reviews-1068-KMFDM-Tohuvabohu.html | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071022074539/http://www.regenmag.com/Reviews-1068-KMFDM-Tohuvabohu.html | author=Y\xc3\xbccel, Ilker | title=Reviews: KMFDM Tohuvabohu | work=ReGen Magazine | publisher=ReGen Media | date=August 24, 2007 | archivedate=October 22, 2007 | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref> The most recent albums, \'\'Blitz\'\' and \'\'WTF?!\'\', have been described as moving back in an electronic, less guitar-focused direction by Trey Spencer of \'\'Sputnikmusic\'\' and AllMusic\'s David Jeffries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sputnikmusic.com/album.php?reviewid=29996 | author=Spencer, Trey | title=KMFDM \xe2\x80\x93 Blitz (staff review) | work=Sputnukmusic | publisher=Sputnikmusic.com | date=March 25, 2009 | accessdate=August 4, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/wtf!-mw0002112356 | author=Jeffries, David | title=WTF?! Review | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 21, 2012}}</ref>

==Touring and fanbase==
[[File:Andy Selway.jpg|thumb|right|[[Andy Selway]] performing live with KMFDM]]
KMFDM has released on average an album every year and a half, and usually tours at least once in support of each album. At most concert venues, KMFDM mingles with the fans before and after the show to sign autographs, pose for photos, and answer questions.<ref name=hybrid>{{cite web | url=http://www.hybridmagazine.com/music/0702/kmfdm.shtml | title=KMFDM Reloads with: Attak | author1=Freedland, Israel | author2=Schneider, Justin | work=Hybrid Magazine | publisher= [noun] digital media | accessdate=May 9, 2012}}</ref> Konietzko, who keeps in contact with fans via e-mail and the band\'s website,<ref name=borzillo>{{cite journal | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qQkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA9&#v=onepage&q=&f=false | title=Wax Trax!/TVT\'s KMFDM Rides Industrial Revolution with 8th Set | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | author=Borzillo, Carrie | publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc]] | volume=108 | number=25 | pages=9, 97 | date=June 22, 1996 | accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref> and band representatives have experimented with ways for fans to interact more directly. KMFDM launched "Horde" in 2002, an exclusive fan club which gave members the opportunity to attend a private meet-and-greet with the band before every show, and allowed access to members-only music and footage online. A featurette on the Horde fan club appears on the \'\'[[WWIII Live 2003]]\'\' DVD.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.side-line.com/news_comments.php?id=1929_0_2_0_C | author=Van Isacker, Bernard | title=World Tour 2003 KMFDM sees DVD/CD release in June and July | work=SideLine News | publisher=SideLine | date=June 10, 2004 | accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref>

In the 2004 \'\'Fankam\'\' project, an audience member was selected at each concert to record that night\'s show, as well as some back-stage antics, with a hand-held digital video camera. The resulting footage was incorporated into the following year\'s \'\'20th Anniversary World Tour\'\' DVD, which included fan photos submitted to the KMFDM official website. KMFDM encouraged fans to call a special "FanPhone" and leave a voice message in March 2007.<ref name=ult-guitar>{{cite web | url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/interviews/interviews/sascha_konietzko_of_kmfdm_i_actually_am_not_a_musician.html | title=Sascha Konietzko of KMFDM: \'I Actually Am Not A Musician\' | date=November 10, 2007 | publisher=Ultimate Guitar | accessdate=March 3, 2010}}</ref> The song "Superpower" from 2007\'s \'\'Tohuvabohu\'\' includes sound-clips from these messages.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.revenantmedia.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1193&Itemid=37 | title=KMFDM\'s Sascha Konietzko Part 1 | author=Cooper, Christina | work=Revenant Media | publisher=Revenant Media | date=August 28, 2007 | accessdate=March 2, 2010 }}</ref> The band used the Fankam project again for its 2011 "Kein Mitleid" tour in the United States.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/fankam/ | title=Fankam | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref>

==Album artwork==
[[File:Kmfdmmoney.jpg|thumb|left|[[Aidan Hughes|Brute!]]\'s album cover for \'\'[[Money (album)|Money]]\'\'. The man on the left is a self-portrait.<ref name=best-art/> Hughes\' artwork has become closely associated with the band\'s image.<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/>]]

KMFDM has a long-standing relationship with commercial artist [[Aidan Hughes|Aidan "Brute!" Hughes]], who creates the artwork adorning almost all of the band\'s albums and singles,<ref name="AllMusic Bio"/> which has been called "one of rock music\'s most memorable cover art collections".<ref name=AllMusic-wdykd>{{cite web | url=http://www.AllMusic.com/album/what-do-you-know-deutschland-mw0000204960 | author=Jeffries, Vincent | title=KMFDM: What Do You Know Deutschland? | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> Hughes\' artwork is featured in KMFDM\'s music videos for "A Drug Against War" and "Son of a Gun", and on the band\'s promotional t-shirts.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bruteprop.co.uk | title=Brute! Propaganda | author=Hughes, Aiden | publisher=Aiden Hughes | accessdate=March 8, 2011}}</ref> Art critic [[Brian Sherwin]] said Hughes is probably best known for the collection of KMFDM artwork he has created.<ref name=sherwin>{{cite web | url=http://myartspace-blog.blogspot.com/2008/12/art-space-talk-aidan-hughes.html | author=Sherwin, Brian | authorlink=Brian Sherwin | title=Art Space Talk: Aidan Hughes | date=December 31, 2008 | accessdate=August 4, 2012}}</ref>

All of his work, which has been called "striking",<ref>{{cite book | author=Larkin, Colin | title=The Virgin Encyclopedia of Nineties Music | page=219 |date=May 2000 | publisher=Virgin Paperbacks | isbn=978-0-7535-0427-7}}</ref> shares a distinct visual style inspired by [[Golden Age of comic books|Golden Age comic]] artists, [[Constructivism (art)|Russian Constructivists]], Italian [[Futurism|Futurists]], and [[woodcut]] artists.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://blog.bruteprop.co.uk/?page_id=2 | title=About the Man | author=Hughes, Aiden | publisher=Aiden Hughes | accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref> In an interview with Sherwin, Hughes stated, "KMFDM have cornered the market in industrial post-modern angst and so my work reflects that."<ref name=sherwin/> Hughes said that initially he based his work on the music, which caused "artistic block".<ref name=best-art>{{cite book | author=Drozdowski, Ted | title=The Best Music Cd Art + Design | page=130 |date=September 1997 | publisher=Rockport Pub | isbn=978-1-56496-367-3}}</ref> Konietzko gave him more freedom to use whatever themes he wished, resulting in the cover to \'\'Money\'\', which Hughes said "was based upon my disillusionment with the street lifestyle I was experiencing at the time, and the art carries with it the implication that no matter what temptation lies in your path, you still gotta pay!"<ref name=best-art/>

The only studio album covers not designed by Hughes are \'\'Opium\'\', which consists of a black and white photo, and \'\'Nihil\'\', which was designed by [[Francesca Sundsten]], wife of drummer Rieflin.<ref name=bruin>{{cite news | url=http://www.dailybruin.com/index.php/article/1995/05/kmfdm-delves-deeper-into-metal | author=Gopalan, Nisha | title=KMFDM delves deeper into metal-industrial | work=[[Daily Bruin]] | publisher=The Daily Bruin | date=May 3, 1995 | accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref>
{{clear}}

==Members==

===Official line-up===
The official line-up<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/bio/profiles.htm | title=KMFDM Member Bios | publisher=KMFDM Inc | accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref> of KMFDM consists of:
*[[Sascha Konietzko]] \xe2\x80\x93 vocals, guitar, bass, programming, keyboards, synthesizer, percussion
*[[Lucia Cifarelli]] \xe2\x80\x93 vocals, keyboards
*[[Jules Hodgson]] \xe2\x80\x93 guitar, bass, keyboards
*[[Andy Selway]] \xe2\x80\x93 drums
*[[Steve White (guitarist)|Steve White]] \xe2\x80\x93 guitar

===Key former members===
*[[En Esch]] \xe2\x80\x93 vocals, drums, guitar, programming
*[[Raymond Watts]] \xe2\x80\x93 vocals, programming
*[[G\xc3\xbcnter Schulz]] \xe2\x80\x93 guitar, programming
*[[Mark Durante]] \xe2\x80\x93 guitar, steel guitar
*[[Tim Skold]] \xe2\x80\x93 vocals, guitar, bass, drums, programming

==Associated acts==
Members of KMFDM have either founded, fronted, or supported a score of other bands throughout the band\'s history, before, during, or after working in KMFDM.

*[[Shotgun Messiah]] \xe2\x80\x93 Tim Sk\xc3\xb6ld (1985\xe2\x80\x9393)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/shotgun-messiah-mn0000752660 | title=Shotgun Messiah Overview | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=March 30, 2013}}</ref>
*[[Pig (musical project)|Pig]] \xe2\x80\x93 Raymond Watts (1988\xe2\x80\x93present)<ref>{{cite web | url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p13949|pure_url=yes}} | title=Pig Overview | publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=April 7, 2010}}</ref> (Pig members Jules Hodgson, Andy Selway, and Steve White joined KMFDM in 2002 and 2003), G\xc3\xbcnter Schulz (touring guitarist 2006\xe2\x80\x93present)
*[[Pigface]] \xe2\x80\x93 Bill Rieflin (1990\xe2\x80\x9393), En Esch (1990\xe2\x80\x9393, 1999\xe2\x80\x932005), Schulz (1999\xe2\x80\x932005)<ref>{{cite web | url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p13950|pure_url=yes}} | title=Pigface Overview | publisher=[[AllMusic]].
