 ****** Whitehouse (band)

b'{{Refimprove|date=October 2010}}
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name                = Whitehouse
| image                 = Whitehouse live 2006.jpg <!-- Put only the image name (e.g. Example.png) without the Image: prefix. -->
| caption            = Whitehouse (William Bennett & Philip Best) live at Consumer Electronics Festival, 2006
| image_size            = <!-- Only for images narrower than 220 pixels. Set the value as a number without "px". -->
| background          = group_or_band
| alias               = 
| origin              = [[United Kingdom]]
| genre               = [[Power electronics (music)|Power electronics]], [[Experimental music|experimental]], [[noise]], [[avant-garde]], [[dark ambient]]
| years_active        = 1980&ndash;1985, 1990&ndash;2008
| label               = [[Come Organisation]], Susan Lawly, [[Ramleh (band)|Ramleh]]
| associated_acts     = 
| website             = 
| current_members     = William Bennett
| past_members        = [[Philip Best]]<br/>[[Peter Sotos]]<br/>[[Kevin Tomkins]]<br/>[[Glenn Michael Wallis]]<br/>[[Peter McKay (musician)|Peter McKay]]<br/>[[Paul Reuter (musician)|Paul Reuter]]<br/>[[John Murphy (musician)|John Murphy]]
}}

\'\'\'Whitehouse\'\'\' were a pioneering [[England|English]] [[Power electronics (music)|power electronics]] band formed in 1980, largely credited for the founding of the power electronics subgenre of [[industrial music]].

==History and personnel==
The name Whitehouse was chosen both in mock tribute to the British morality campaigner [[Mary Whitehouse]], and in reference to a [[Whitehouse (magazine)|British pornographic magazine of the same name]].

The group\'s founding member and sole constant was William Bennett.  He began as a guitarist for [[Essential Logic]]. He wrote of those early years, "I often fantasised about creating a sound that could bludgeon an audience into submission."<ref>[http://www.susanlawly.freeuk.com/faq/faq.html Susanlawly.freeuk.com]</ref> Bennett later recorded as [[Come (UK band)|Come]] (featuring contributions from the likes of [[Daniel Miller (music producer)|Daniel Miller]] and [[J. G. Thirlwell]]) before forming Whitehouse in 1980. The group began performing live in 1982. In 2009, Bennett claimed that his pre-eminent inspiration was [[Yoko Ono]]: "Yoko\'s amazing music was by far the biggest influence on me, and Whitehouse, in the formative years (despite what some would have you believe)."<ref>William Bennett, "The Inner Sleeve", \'\'The Wire\'\' 309, November 2009, p. 71.</ref>

[[Philip Best]] joined the group in 1982 at the age of 14, after running away from home. He was a member on and off ever since.

The group was inactive for the second half of the 1980s. A "special biographical note" on the Susan Lawly website states, "All members of Whitehouse went to live outside London for varying reasons and pursued separate lives. There was a feeling in the group that all that could be achieved had been realised."<ref>[http://www.susanlawly.freeuk.com/textfiles/ladossier4.html Susanlawly.freeuk.com]</ref>

Eventually, Whitehouse re-emerged with a series of [[album]]s, produced by the [[United States|American]] [[record producer]], [[Steve Albini]], beginning with 1990s \'\'[[Thank Your Lucky Stars (album)|Thank Your Lucky Stars]]\'\'. Albini worked with the band until 1998, when Bennett took over all production duties.

Through the 1990s the most stable line-up was Bennett, Best, and the writer [[Peter Sotos]], who was convicted of possession of child pornography. Sotos left in 2002, leaving the band as a two-piece.

The band had numerous other members in the 1980s including [[Kevin Tomkins]], [[Steven Stapleton]], Glenn Michael Wallis, [[John Murphy (musician)|John Murphy]], Stefan Jaworzyn, Jim Goodall, and [[Hafler Trio|Andrew McKenzie]], though many of these participated only at live performances, not on recordings.

Bennett terminated Whitehouse in 2008 to concentrate on his [[Cut Hands]] project.<ref>"[http://www.decibelmagazine.com/featured/william-bennett-cut-hands-interviewed Interview with William Bennett]". \'\'Decibel\'\', 8 July 2014.</ref>

==Music==
Whitehouse specialised in what they call "extreme electronic music". They were known for their controversial lyrics and imagery, which portrayed sadistic sex, rape, misogyny, serial murder, eating disorders, child abuse, neo-nazi fetishism and other forms of violence and abjection.

Whitehouse emerged as earlier [[industrial music|industrial]] acts such as [[Throbbing Gristle]] and [[SPK (band)|SPK]] were pulling back from noise and extreme sounds and embracing relatively more conventional musical genres. In opposition to this trend, Whitehouse wanted to take these earlier groups\' sounds and fascination with extreme subject matter even further; as referenced on the sleeve of their first LP, the group wished to "cut pure human states" and produce "the most extreme music ever recorded". In doing so, they drew inspiration from some earlier experimental musicians and artists such as [[Alvin Lucier]], [[Robert Ashley]], and [[Yoko Ono]] as well as writers such as [[Marquis de Sade]].

The signature sonic elements on their early recordings were simple, pulverizing electronic bass tones twinned with needling high frequencies, sometimes combined with ferocious washes of white noise, with or without vocals (usually barked orders, sinister whispers, and high-pitched screams).

In the early 1990s the band phased out the analog equipment responsible for this sound, instead relying more heavily on computers. Since 2000 they began incorporating percussive rhythms, sometimes from African instruments such as the [[djembe]], both sampled and performed in-studio.

==Reception and influence==
Whitehouse were a key influence in the development of [[noise music]] as a musical genre in [[Europe]], [[Japan]], the [[United States|US]], and elsewhere. The early music of Whitehouse is often credited with pioneering the [[power electronics (music)|power electronics]] (a term Bennett himself coined on the blurb to the \'\'[[Psychopathia Sexualis (album)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]\'\' album) and noise genres.

The band\'s 2003 album [[Bird Seed (Whitehouse album)|\'\'Bird Seed\'\']] was given an \'honourable mention\' in the digital musics category of Austria\'s annual [[Prix Ars Electronica]] awards.<ref>[http://www.aec.at/en/archives/prix_archive/prix_year_cat.asp?iProjectID=9581&iCategoryID=9555 ARS Electronica<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

As Nick Cain of \'\'[[The Wire (magazine)|The Wire]]\'\' put it, {{cquote|By the end of the 1990s, power electronics was in a deep freeze. Fast forward a decade, and ... Whitehouse ... were enjoying an unlikely vogue, universally hailed by Noise makers from [[Peter Rehberg]] to [[Wolf Eyes]] ... and their work officially inducted into the avant garde canon through a collaboration with the German New Music ensemble [[Zeitkratzer]].<ref>Nick Cain, "Noise", \'\'The Wire Primers: A Guide to Modern Music\'\', Rob Young, ed., London: Verso, 2009, p. 31.</ref>}}

 ****** White Zombie (band)

b'{{For|the American horror film|White Zombie (film)}}
{{Refimprove|date=November 2008}}
{{Infobox musical artist
|name            = White Zombie
|image           = White_zombie.JPG
|landscape       = Yes
|background      = group_or_band
|years_active    = 1985\xe2\x80\x931998
|origin          = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York]], [[United States]]
|genre           = [[Heavy metal music|Heavy metal]], [[industrial metal]], {{nowrap|[[groove metal]]}}, [[alternative metal]], <br>[[noise rock]] (early)
|label           = [[Silent Explosion]], [[Caroline Records|Caroline]], [[Geffen Records|Geffen]]
|past_members    = <!--DO NOT CHANGE! Members are listed in order required under Wikipedia Infobox Guidelines.-->[[Rob Zombie]]<br>[[Sean Yseult]]<br>[[Paul Kostabi|Ena Kostabi]]<br>Peter Landau<br>[[Ivan de Prume]]<br>[[Tim Jeffs]]<br>[[Tom Guay]]<br>John Ricci<br>[[Jay Noel Yuenger]]<br>Phil Buerstatte<br>[[John Tempesta]]
}}

\'\'\'White Zombie\'\'\' was an American [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band that formed in 1985. Based in [[New York City]], White Zombie was originally a [[noise rock]] band. White Zombie is better-known for its later heavy metal-oriented sound. The group officially disbanded in 1998. In 2000, White Zombie was included on VH1\'s 100 Greatest Artists of Hard Rock, ranking at No. 56.<ref>[http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/2000/vh1hardrock.htm VH1: 100 Greatest Hard Rock Artists page] [[VH1]], cited January 18, 2010</ref>

==History==

===Early years===
White Zombie was co-founded by writer, vocalist and graphic artist [[Rob Zombie]], after coming up with the band idea in 1985 while attending [[Parsons School of Design]] in his junior year. Zombie\'s girlfriend at the time, [[Sean Yseult]], was the other co-founder. She had been playing the [[Farfisa]] keyboard in the band LIFE with [[Ivan de Prume]], but the band soon broke up. [[Paul Kostabi|Ena Kostabi]] owned a [[recording studio]], which he would rent out to different bands. When he met Yseult, she asked if he could teach her to play bass. They then recruited Peter Landau to play drums and began to write and record songs. White Zombie\'s first release, \'\'[[Gods on Voodoo Moon]]\'\', was an [[Extended play|EP]] and was recorded on October 18, 1985. It was released under the band\'s own label [[Silent Explosion]], under which they would release most of their early work. Only 300 copies were pressed, of which only 100 were sold; the band members still retain possession of the remaining 200.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}}

In 1986, Zombie hired [[Tim Jeffs]], his Parsons School of Design roommate, to play guitar to replace Ena Kostabi, and Yseult brought in De Prume from their days in the band LIFE as the replacement for Landau. It was at this time the band started touring, making their live performance debut at [[CBGB]] on April 28, 1986.<ref>Tim Jeffs\' Early White Zombie Biography. cited July 6, 2009.</ref><ref>Yseult, Sean. "CBGB\'s". \'\'I\'m in the Band\'\'. 2010. pg. 8, cited January 9, 2011</ref> White Zombie released their second EP, \'\'[[Pig Heaven]]\'\', that year. The release contained two songs, "Pig Heaven" and "Slaughter the Grey". The EP was recorded at 6/8 Studios on Houston St and Bleecker St in NoHo in New York City. Other songs that were recorded during the session but never released were titled "Follow Wild", "Rain Insane", "Paradise Fireball" and "Red River Flow". After touring for a year in the band, Tim Jeffs left and was replaced by [[Tom Guay]], often known as Tom Five. The band released a second pressing of \'\'Pig Heaven\'\' with different cover art, but retained the same recording with Jeffs on guitar. Only 500 copies of each pressing were released on vinyl.

In 1987, the band released their third EP, \'\'[[Psycho-Head Blowout]]\'\'. Later that year, the band released their first full-length album, \'\'[[Soul-Crusher]]\'\', which was their first release to feature sound clips from movies in the songs, a trademark that would continue for the remainder of the band\'s lifespan. John Ricci replaced Tom Guay shortly after the release of \'\'Soul-Crusher\'\'.<ref name="The Great Rock Discography"/>

In 1988, the band signed to [[Caroline Records]], permanently discontinuing their old indie label. Their second album, \'\'[[Make Them Die Slowly (album)|Make Them Die Slowly]]\'\', was released in February 1989.<ref name="The Great Rock Discography"/> The album was a musical shift for White Zombie. While their previous releases had been strictly punk-influenced noise rock, \'\'Make Them Die Slowly\'\' had more of a [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] sound.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} This is also the first album crediting "Rob Zombie" instead of his previous [[stage name]], "Rob \'Dirt\' Straker".

Ricci\'s [[carpal tunnel syndrome]] severely affected his ability to play guitar, forcing him to leave the band when \'\'Make Them Die Slowly\'\' was finished. [[Jay Noel Yuenger|Jay Yuenger]], or "J", replaced him before the album\'s release, affecting their future sound.<ref>{{Wayback |date=20030820103658 |url=http://www.inyoureye.com/secure/whitezom/white_1.cfm |title="J. from White Zombie Speaks!"}}, cited June 12, 2010</ref> One of the most obvious examples of this direction is the difference between the songs "Disaster Blaster" on \'\'Make Them Die Slowly\'\' and the re-worked version, "Disaster Blaster II", on the \'\'[[God of Thunder (album)|God of Thunder]]\'\' EP.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}}

===Major label years===
After searching for a record label and being turned down multiple times, the band turned towards [[RCA Records]]. However, Zombie opted for a [[recording contract]] with [[Geffen Records]]. Michael Alago, a representative of Geffen, became interested after hearing \'\'God of Thunder\'\' and watched one of their shows at Pyramid Club and liked them, mostly for their song "Soul-Crusher". The band produced a [[demo (music)|demo]] with the help of [[J. G. Thirlwell]] of [[Foetus]] and were signed to Geffen.<ref>[http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/interviews/interviews/rob_zombie_i_find_it_distracting_to_hear_my_own_music.html "Rob Zombie: I Find It Distracting To Hear My Own Music"] ultimate-guitar.com interview. cited December 2008.</ref>

On March 17, 1992, White Zombie released \'\'[[La Sexorcisto: Devil Music, Vol. 1|La Sexorcisto: Devil Music Volume One]]\'\', the album which launched them into mainstream recognition. White Zombie began a two-and-a-half-year-long tour for the album soon after its release, during which the band gained a large [[cult following]]. During the tour, [[Ivan de Prume]] left the band to pursue a successful career as a producer/engineer as well as drummer/percussionist and opened his own studio, Burningsound. He was replaced by Phil Buerstatte. The [[music video]] for the song "[[Thunder Kiss \'65]]" went into heavy rotation on [[MTV]] in 1993. The popular TV show \'\'[[Beavis and Butt-head]]\'\' began featuring their music videos, boosting the band\'s popularity.<ref name="The Great Rock Discography"/> By the end of 1993, the album had been certified [[RIAA certification|gold]] by the [[RIAA]]. By the time the tour ended in December 1994, Zombie and Yseult had broken up, and \'\'La Sexorcisto\'\' had gone [[RIAA certification|platinum]]. Due to artistic differences, Buerstatte was let go, and [[John Tempesta]], who had previously worked with [[Exodus (band)|Exodus]] and [[Testament (band)|Testament]], was hired to record White Zombie\'s second major label album.<ref name="The Great Rock Discography"/> In 1995, \'\'[[Astro Creep: 2000]]\'\' was released, featuring the hit single "[[More Human than Human]]". In 1996, an album of remixes was released under the title \'\'[[Supersexy Swingin\' Sounds]]\'\'. After making one last song for the 1996 film \'\'[[Beavis and Butt-head Do America]]\'\', titled "Ratfinks, Suicide Tanks and Cannibal Girls", White Zombie broke up in 1998.<ref name="The Great Rock Discography"/>

==After disbanding==
After the breakup of White Zombie, Sean Yseult joined the [[surf rock]] band [[The Famous Monsters]], and started playing bass for horror-themed [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]]-based band, [[Rock City Morgue]]. She also briefly played bass for [[The Cramps]].

Tempesta continued his musical relationship with Zombie, drumming for him on his first two solo albums, \'\'[[Hellbilly Deluxe]]\'\' and \'\'[[The Sinister Urge (album)|The Sinister Urge]]\'\'. He is no longer with Zombie, and has gone on to play for [[Scum of the Earth (band)|Scum of the Earth]] with his brother, [[Powerman 5000]] guitarist Mike Tempesta, and ex-Zombie guitarist [[Mike Riggs]]. Tempesta has toured with Testament (as shown on Testament\'s DVD, \'\'Live In London\'\'). On February 14, 2006, he was hired as the new drummer for [[The Cult]], before which, he played with [[Helmet (band)|Helmet]].

[[Jay Noel Yuenger|J.]] produced records for [[Fu Manchu (band)|Fu Manchu]] and [[New York City|New York]]-based Puny Human.

In July 2006, original members Tom Five and de Prume reunited to perform with de Prume\'s band, Healer, a middle eastern infused metal band, for several concerts in Southern California for The Vans [[Warped Tour]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=54694|title=Original WHITE ZOMBIE Members Team Up For VANS WARPED TOUR Appearance|publisher=[[Roadrunner Records]]|date=July 6, 2006 |archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20100603025147/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=54694|archivedate=October 26, 2006}}</ref> De Prume continues to write and record music with Healer, as well as recording, producing and engineering for special projects in his studio, Burningsound. His drums and percussion work can also be heard on Sony\'s "Ghost Rider" score. In 2009, de Prume began hosting the weekly radio show, "Metalopolis". His studio guests have included [[Rob Halford]], [[Dave Mustaine]], [[Max Cavalera]], [[Vinnie Paul]] and [[Tom Araya]]. De Prume is also a member of the band KREEP, and has completed a West Coast tour in spring 2010, and is planning an East Coast tour in fall 2010.

In November 2008, Geffen/UME released \'\'[[Let Sleeping Corpses Lie]]\'\', a [[boxed set]] which includes sixty four tracks featuring every White Zombie album and EP (except the remix albums), all remastered. The package also contained nine music videos (including their breakthrough Grammy-nominated hit "Thunder Kiss \'65"), and ten live performances. In an interview<ref>{{cite web|title=Rob Zombie: All Boxed Up|url=http://suicidegirls.com/interviews/Rob+Zombie%3A+All+Boxed+Up/|publisher=[[SuicideGirls]]|author=Carrie Borzillo-Vrenna|date=December 3, 2008|accessdate= December 3, 2008|archiveurl=
//web.archive.org/web/20100603025147/http://suicidegirls.com/interviews/Rob+Zombie%3A+All+Boxed+Up/|archivedate=December 5, 2008}}</ref> to promote the release of \'\'Let Sleeping Corpses Lie\'\', Zombie made it clear that a reunion with his White Zombie band mates was unlikely, saying, "I don\'t want fans to think it\'s the beginning of anything."

In December 2010 Yseult released "I\'m in the Band", a book containing tour diaries and photos as well as detailing her eleven years spent as a member of White Zombie.<ref>[http://seanyseult.com/the-book/ The Book], September 9, 2010.</ref><ref>[http://www.amazon.com/dp/1593762992 I\'m In the Band Amazon page], September 9, 2010.</ref>

In June 2011, in an interview with \'\'[[Metal Hammer]]\'\' magazine, Rob Zombie was asked why White Zombie split up, in which he replied: "It had run its course. Success is a big thing that you can never plan for, because it affects everybody differently. I don\'t want to blame myself or anyone else in the band \xe2\x80\x94 it\'s just that the band didn\'t work anymore. Rather than continuing on and making shitty records and having it all fall apart, I thought: \'Let\'s just end it on a high point\'".

In May 2013, former drummer Phil Buerstatte died.<ref>{{cite web|author=Marc Hogan |url=http://www.spin.com/articles/phil-buerstatte-white-zombie-drummer-has-died/ |title=Phil Buerstatte, Former White Zombie Drummer, Dead at 44|publisher=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|date=May 21, 2013|accessdate=May 22, 2013|archiveurl=
//web.archive.org/web/20100603025147/http://www.spin.com/articles/phil-buerstatte-white-zombie-drummer-has-died/|archivedate=June 9, 2013}}</ref>

 ****** The Young Gods

b':\'\'For the [[Marvel Comics]] group, see [[Young Gods (comics)]]. Young Gods is also the name of an album by the rock band [[Little Angels]]. For the movie from [[Finland]] see [[Young Gods (film)]]\'\'

{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name                = The Young Gods
| image               = The Young Gods 2.jpg
| background          = group_or_band
| alias               = TYG
| origin              = [[Fribourg]], [[Switzerland]]
| caption             = The Young Gods in 2007 
| genre               = [[Post-industrial music|Post-industrial]], [[industrial rock]], [[dark ambient]]
| occupation          = 
| years_active        = 1985\xe2\x80\x93present<ref name="Bio">{{cite web|last=The Young Gods|title=Everybody Knows (Biography)|url=http://www.younggods.com/cms/front_content.php?idcat=26|publisher=The Young Gods (Official Site)|accessdate=5 August 2011}}</ref>
| label               = [[Wax Trax! Records|Wax Trax!]],<ref name="WaxTrax">{{cite web|last=[[Discogs]]|title=The Young Gods (self-titled album)|url=http://www.discogs.com/Young-Gods-The-Young-Gods/release/1522550|publisher=[[Discogs]]|accessdate=6 August 2011|format=[[Wax Trax! Records]] [[Wax Trax! Records discography|#WAX7135 - LP, Album, CD]]|year=1987}}</ref> [[PIAS Recordings|Play It Again Sam]], [[Interscope Records|Interscope]], [[Ipecac Recordings|Ipecac]], Intoxygene, [[RecRec Music|Make Up]], [[Two Gentlemen]]

\'\'\'The Young Gods\'\'\' (TYG) are a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Post-industrial music|post-industrial]] band from [[Fribourg]]. The band\'s lineup consisted of a trio composed by a vocalist, a keyboardist / sampler operator and a drummer. In 2007, a fourth member joined the band. Their instrumentation often includes sampled electric guitars, drums, keyboards, and other samples.<ref name="Bio"/> The lyrics are written in English, French and German.

==Biography==
Their name is taken from an early [[Young God (EP)|EP]] by the [[no wave]]/[[noise rock]] band [[Swans (band)|Swans]]. Artists influenced by The Young Gods include [[Pitchshifter]], [[Mike Patton]], [[Sepultura]], [[The Edge]] (as stated in [[U2 by U2]]), [[Devin Townsend]], [[Ithak]], [[Econoline Crush]] and [[David Bowie]]; asked in 1995 if his album \'\'[[Outside (David Bowie album)|Outside]]\'\' was influenced by [[Nine Inch Nails]], Bowie answered: "The band that I was actually quite taken with was three guys from Switzerland called The Young Gods... I\xe2\x80\x99d been aware of them previous to knowing about Nine Inch Nails."

[[Roli Mosimann]] of Swans has worked with the group as a producer. In 2007 they did a [[Take-Away Show]] acoustic video session. Notable hits are: "[[Did You Miss Me?]]", "[[Envoy\xc3\xa9!]]", "[[Longue Route]]", "[[Skinflowers]]", and "[[Kissing the Sun]]".

In December 2012, The Young Gods give a small series of concerts to celebrate the 25th anniversary of their first album (1987). The group will play songs from their first two albums ("The Young Gods" and "L\'eau rouge"). The line-up will be Franz Treichler (vocals), Bernard Trontin (drums) and Cesare Pizzi (samplers).

The group supplied original music for the 2012 animated short film, \'\'[[Kali the Little Vampire]]\'\', which went on to win over 20 international awards.<ref name=publico>{{cite web |url= http://www.publico.pt/culturaipsilon/noticia/unesco-da-estatuto-de-patrimonio-cultural-internacional-a-kali-o-pequeno-vampiro-de-regina-pessoa-1621729|title= Kali, o Pequeno Vampiro exibido enquanto "patrim\xc3\xb3nio cultural internacional" em festival da UNESCO|author= Lusa and P\xc3\x9aBLICO|date= January 30, 2014|accessdate= October 6, 2014|work= [[publico.pt]]|language= Portuguese}}</ref>

==Members==
Previous and current members are: 
* Vocals: \'\'\'Franz Treichler\'\'\' (aka Franz Muse, the only constant member)<ref name="Bio"/>
* Keyboard: \'\'\'Cesare Pizzi\'\'\' (aka Ludan Dross, current member and co-founder), Alain Monod (aka Al Comet, former member)
* Drums: Patrice Bagnoud (aka Frank Bagnoud,<ref>Patrice Bagnoud, alias Frank Bagnoud, died after a long illness in June 2005 http://www.younggods.com/cms/front_content.php?client=1&lang=1&idcat=88&idart=138</ref> former member), Urs "\xc3\x9cse" Hiestand (former member), \'\'\'Bernard Trontin\'\'\' (current member)
* Guitar, bass guitar, electronics: Vincent H\xc3\xa4nni (former member)

 ****** Z\'ev

b''

 ****** Rob Zombie

b'{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2012}}
{{Infobox musical artist
|name = Rob Zombie
|image = Rob_Zombie_-_Orange_Stage_-_Roskilde_Festival_2014.jpg
|caption = Rob Zombie performing at [[Roskilde Festival]] on the 4th of July 2014.
|image_size =
|background = solo_singer
|alias = Mr. Zombie, Rob Straker, Rob Zodiac
|birth_name = Robert Bartleh Cummings
|birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|1|12}}
|birth_place = [[Haverhill, Massachusetts]], United States
|instrument = Vocals
|genre = [[Heavy Metal music|Heavy metal]], [[groove metal]], [[alternative metal]], [[industrial metal]], [[shock rock]], [[noise rock]] (early)
|occupation = Musician, singer-songwriter, screenwriter, film director, film producer, programmer, music producer
|years_active = 1985 - present
|label = [[Roadrunner Records|Roadrunner]], Loud & Proud, [[Geffen Records|Geffen]], Zodiac Swan Records
|associated_acts = [[White Zombie (band)|White Zombie]], [[Alice Cooper]], [[Powerman 5000]], [[Ozzy Osbourne]], [[Black Label Society]], [[Marilyn Manson]], [[Slipknot (band)|Slipknot]], [[Iggy Pop]], [[Skrillex]], [[Howard Stern]], [[Drowning Pool]]
|website = {{URL|http://www.robzombie.com/}}
}}

\'\'\'Rob Zombie\'\'\'<ref name=WeeklyWire99>{{cite news | url= http://weeklywire.com/ww/03-01-99/tw_mus.html | title= Goremeister: Rob Zombie has paid his dues. Now it\'s showtime. | first= Ron |last= Bally | date= March 1, 1999 | work= Weekly Wire | publisher= Tucson Weekly | quote= he legally changed his name in 1996 | accessdate= November 9, 2012}}</ref> (born \'\'\'Robert Bartleh Cummings\'\'\';<ref>{{Cite journal |last= |first= |title=Rocker Zombie does horror in Halloween |url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=326074 |publisher=\'\'MSN\'\' |date=2007-11-18 |accessdate=2007-12-14 |postscript= <!--None-->}}{{dead link|date=November 2012}}</ref> January 12, 1965) is an American musician, film director, screenwriter and film producer. He rose to prominence as a founding member of the band [[White Zombie (band)|White Zombie]] which formed in the mid-1980s and rose to fame in the early 1990s. As a solo artist, he has released five [[studio albums]], three [[compilation album]]s, two [[remix album]]s, a [[live album]], a [[video album]], and 15 [[Single (music)|single]]s. In 2003 he expanded his career and became a film director, and has directed a total of six films, the majority of which he also wrote or co-wrote. He has also released numerous brands of comic books, and appeared as an actor on numerous occasions.

White Zombie\'s debut album, \'\'[[Soul-Crusher]]\'\', was released in 1987 and was followed by their second album \'\'[[Make Them Die Slowly (album)|Make Them Die Slowly]]\'\' in 1989. They rose to prominence after the success of their third album, \'\'[[La Sexorcisto: Devil Music, Vol. 1]]\'\', and its lead single "[[Thunder Kiss \'65]]" in 1993. The album went on to be certified multi-platinum by the [[RIAA]], for sales exceeding two million copies in the US. Their fourth and final studio album, \'\'[[Astro-Creep: 2000 \xe2\x80\x93 Songs of Love, Destruction and Other Synthetic Delusions of the Electric Head|Astro-Creep: 2000]]\'\', became their first top-10 entry on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]], and their second album to reach multi-platinum status.

Zombie began his solo career with the release of his 1998 debut album \'\'[[Hellbilly Deluxe]]\'\'. The album was both a critical and commercial success, spawning three hit singles, reaching the Top 5 of the Billboard 200, and selling over three million copies worldwide. \'\'Hellbilly\'\' is Zombie\'s highest selling album to date. He followed the success of the album with \'\'[[The Sinister Urge (album)|The Sinister Urge]]\'\' in 2001, which had similar success to that of its predecessor. Zombie\'s first [[greatest hits]] album, \'\'[[Past, Present & Future (Rob Zombie album)|Past, Present & Future]]\'\', was released in 2003, and reached [[Platinum certification|Platinum]] status by the RIAA. His third studio album, \'\'[[Educated Horses]]\'\', was released in 2006, and was his third Top 10 entry on the Billboard 200. In 2010, he released his fourth studio album \'\'[[Hellbilly Deluxe 2]]\'\', which is a sequel to \'\'Hellbilly Deluxe\'\'. His fifth album, \'\'[[Venomous Rat Regeneration Vendor]]\'\', was released on April 23, 2013.

Following his success as a musician, Zombie began directing, writing and producing films. His first film, \'\'[[House of 1000 Corpses]]\'\', was completed in 2000, but numerous struggles with the distributor led to the film\'s release being delayed until 2003. Its sequel, \'\'[[The Devil\'s Rejects]]\'\' was released in 2005. In 2007, he released his third film, a remake of the 1978 classic film \'\'[[Halloween (2007 film)|Halloween]]\'\'. The film went on to gross over $80 million, the highest-grossing film in the [[Halloween (franchise)|\'\'Halloween\'\' franchise]]. In 2009, Zombie released a sequel for the film, titled \'\'[[Halloween II (2009 film)|Halloween II]]\'\'. In 2009, Zombie released his first animated film, \'\'[[The Haunted World of El Superbeasto]]\'\', based on his comic book series of the same name. His film \'\'[[The Lords of Salem (film)|The Lords of Salem]]\'\' was released in 2013. Zombie bought the rights to a film about the [[Philadelphia Flyers]], titled \'\'The Broad Street Bullies\'\', though no release date for the film has been announced yet.

Zombie directed the majority of White Zombie\'s music videos, as well as numerous videos for his solo work. Zombie\'s lyrics are noted for their horror and sci-fi themes, and his live shows for their elaborate [[shock rock]] theatricality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://film.list.co.uk/article/32670-shock-rocker-and-horror-film-director-rob-zombie-full-interview-transcript/|title=Shock Rocker and Horror Film Director Rob Zombie Full Interview| publisher= Film.list.co.uk| accessdate= 2012-04-30}}</ref> He has sold over 15 million albums worldwide, and had six Top 20 hits on the \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' [[Hot Mainstream Rock Tracks]] chart in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|author=Zombie Live |url=http://www.amazon.com/Zombie-Live-Rob/dp/B000SUKPTS |title=Zombie Live: Music |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref>

==Early life==
[[File:Haverhill, MA.jpg|thumb|[[Haverhill, Massachusetts]], where Zombie grew up.]]
Robert Bartleh Cummings was born in [[Haverhill, Massachusetts]] on January 12, 1965.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zombiefaq.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=93&Itemid=54 |title=Rob Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Biography |publisher=ZombieFAQ.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> He is the oldest son of Robert and Louise Cummings.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.reillycapps.com/articles/rob-zombies-old-haunts.html |title=Rob Zombie\'s Old Haunts |publisher=Reillycapps.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> Rob\'s younger brother, Michael David Cummings, was born in 1968<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0957772/bio Biography page] at the [[Internet Movie Database]]</ref> and is better known by his stage name [[Spider One]]. His brother is the lead singer of the band [[Powerman 5000]].<ref>[http://celebritywonder.ugo.com/html/robzombie.html Rob Zombie] at Celebrity Wonder</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.amazon.com/Tonight-Stars-Revolt-Powerman-5000/dp/B00000JMXV |title=Tonight Stars Revolt, Powerman 5000 |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-25}}</ref>

Growing up, Rob had a fascination with [[horror film]]s, and has stated that he always "wanted to be [[Alice Cooper]], [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Bela Lugosi]], and [[Stan Lee]].<ref>"[http://www.enotes.com/zombie-rob-reference/zombie-rob Rob Zombie] at enotes.com</ref><ref>[http://www.menshealth.com/best-life/success-stories-rob-zombie Success Stories: Rob Zombie] at Men\'s Health</ref> While raising their sons, Rob\'s parents worked in a carnival,<ref>[http://www.dailykos.com/story/2008/11/13/660456/-Rob-Zombie-An-Unorthodox-Champion-of-American-Values Rob Zombie, An Unorthodox Champion of American Values] at \'\'[[Daily Kos]]\'\'</ref> but they chose to leave after a riot broke out and tents were set on fire.<ref>[http://movies.yahoo.com/person/rob-zombie/biography.html Rob Zombie Biography] at Yahoo Movies</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nshoremag.com/zombieland/ |title=Northshore &#124; Northshore Magazine |publisher=Nshoremag.com |date=2010-09-17 |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> Zombie recalled the experience in an interview, stating, "Everybody\'s pulling out guns, and you could hear guns going off. I remember this one guy we knew, he was telling us where to go, and some guy just ran up to him and hit him in the face with a hammer \xe2\x80\x93 just busted his face wide open. My parents packed up real quick, and we took off."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news-article/zombies-carnival-past_31_03_2006 |title=Rob Zombie &#124; Zombie\'s Carnival Past |publisher=Contactmusic.com |date=2006-03-31 |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref>

Cummings graduated from [[Haverhill High School]] in 1983.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/haverhill/x603537790/Haverhills-welcome-sign-and-new-book-honor-macabre-master-Rob-Zombie |title=Haverhill\'s welcome sign and new book honor macabre master Rob Zombie \xc2\xbb Haverhill \xc2\xbb EagleTribune.com, North Andover, MA |publisher=Eagletribune.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> He moved to New York City, and he began attending [[Parsons School of Design]] where he met eventual girlfriend [[Sean Yseult]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.superiorpics.com/rob_zombie/ |title=The Rob Zombie Picture Pages |publisher=Superiorpics.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref><ref>[http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/rob-zombie/bio/184861 Rob Zombie biography] at \'\'TV Guide.com\'\'</ref>

Presently, Rob Zombie lives in [[Woodbury, Connecticut]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/rob-zombie-complains-about-noise-from-skate-park-20130807 |title=Rob Zombie Complains About Noise from Skate Park &#124; Music News |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=2013-08-07 |accessdate=2014-07-25}}</ref>

==Career==

===1980s and 1990s: White Zombie===
Rob and Sean served as co-founders for a band that would become known as [[White Zombie (band)|White Zombie]]. Yseult and Zombie would break up after seven years of dating, though they continued to work in the band together.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lecaro |first=Lina |url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/westcoastsound/2010/11/shes_in_the_band-_white_zombie.php |title=Interview: White Zombie\'s Sean Yseult Awakens Sleeping Corpses With New Book \xe2\x80\x93 Los Angeles \xe2\x80\x93 Music \xe2\x80\x93 West Coast Sound |publisher=Blogs.laweekly.com |date=2010-11-16 |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> Between the years of 1985 to 1987, the band released three [[extended play]]s, none of which had commercial success. Their debut studio album \'\'[[Soul-Crusher]]\'\' was released in November 1987<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/White-Zombie-Soul-Crusher/release/932802 |title=White Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Soul-Crusher (Vinyl, Album, LP) |work=Discogs |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> through the band\'s own record label, Silent Explosion.<ref>{{cite web|author=Soul Crusher |url=http://www.amazon.com/Soul-Crusher-White-Zombie/dp/B00000EDLZ/ref=sr_1_1?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1345324849&sr=1-1&keywords=WHITE+ZOMBIE+Soul+Crusher |title=Soul Crusher: Music |publisher=Amazon.com |date=1990-10-17 |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Torreano |first=Bradley |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/soul-crusher-mw0000262655 |title=Soul Crusher \xe2\x80\x93 White Zombie : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> A second studio album, \'\'[[Make Them Die Slowly (album)|Make Them Die Slowly]]\'\', was released in 1989 and failed to have commercial success.<ref>{{cite web|author=Make Them Die Slowly |url=http://www.amazon.com/Make-Them-Slowly-White-Zombie/dp/B000008M91 |title=Make Them Die Slowly: White Zombie: Music |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Rivadavia |first=Eduardo |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/make-them-die-slowly-mw0000200296 |title=Make Them Die Slowly \xe2\x80\x93 White Zombie : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/White-Zombie-Make-Them-Die-Slowly/release/932818 |title=White Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Make Them Die Slowly (Vinyl, LP, Album) |work=Discogs |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref>

The group released their fourth extended play, \'\'[[God of Thunder (album)|God of Thunder]]\'\', later that year. Michael Alago, a representative for [[Geffen Records]], heard the EP and showed interest in the band. The band produced a demo with the help of [[J. G. Thirlwell]] and were signed to Geffen.<ref>{{cite web|author=comments policy &nbsp;54&nbsp;&nbsp;comments posted |url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/interviews/interviews/rob_zombie_i_find_it_distracting_to_hear_my_own_music.html?no_takeover |title=Rob Zombie: \'I Find It Distracting To Hear My Own Music\' &#124; Interviews @ |publisher=Ultimate-guitar.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> In 1993, the group released their first single, "[[Thunder Kiss \'65]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/White-Zombie-Thunder-Kiss-65/release/378472 |title=White Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Thunder Kiss \'65 (CD) |work=Discogs |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/Thunder-Kiss-65/dp/B001L8JFXS |title=Thunder Kiss \'65: White Zombie: Official Music |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> The song gained attention after it was featured on popular MTV series \'\'[[Beavis and Butt-head]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thegauntlet.com/interviews/2307/White-Zombie.html |title=White Zombie html |publisher=The Gauntlet |date=2008-11-20 |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> This helped the song to have commercial success, leading to its peak at number 26 on the \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' [[Hot Mainstream Rock Tracks]].<ref>{{cite web|author=White Zombie |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/white-zombie-mn0000820115/awards |title=White Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> Cummings had used the stage name Rob Straker during early years of White Zombie. However he was much more prominent with the Rob Zombie moniker. (Accordingly, by 1996, Cummings "legally changed his name to Rob Zombie".<ref name=WeeklyWire99/>)

Their third studio album, \'\'[[La Sexorcisto: Devil Music, Vol. 1]]\'\', went on to peak at number 26 on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]] and sell over two million copies in the United States alone, earning it multi-platinum status from the [[RIAA]].<ref name="riaa.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=White%20Zombie&go=Search&perPage=50 |title=Gold & Platinum Searchable Database \xe2\x80\x93 November 22, 2012 |publisher=RIAA |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> The album was also successful in Canada, where it earned a [[Gold certification]].<ref>[http://www.musiccanada.com/GPSearchResult.aspx?st=&ica=False&sa=white%20zombie&sl=&smt=0&sat=-1&ssb=Cert.%20Date Gold and Platinum Search<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Rob later began dating [[Sheri Moon Zombie|Sheri Moon]] after he and Sean ended their romantic relationship. Moon subsequently appeared in the video for "[[Feed the Gods]]", released in 1994.<ref name="girlsandcorpses.com">{{cite web | title= Sheri Not So Scary : An interview with Sheri Moon Zombie | first= Staci Layne | last= Wilson | work=Girls and Corpses Magazine | url= http://www.girlsandcorpses.com/issue10_sherimoon.html | issue=10 | accessdate= November 9, 2012}}</ref>

The band\'s fourth, and ultimately final, studio album \'\'[[Astro-Creep: 2000 \xe2\x80\x93 Songs of Love, Destruction and Other Synthetic Delusions of the Electric Head]]\'\' was released in 1995, and reached number 6 on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]]. The album went on to receive a multi-platinum certification from the [[RIAA]], much like their previous album.<ref name="riaa.com"/> It spawned the successful single "[[More Human Than Human]]", which peaked at number 7 on the \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' [[Alternative Songs]] chart in the United States.<ref>{{citation | url= {{BillboardURLbyName|artist=white zombie|chart=Alternative Songs}} | title= White Zombie Album & Song Chart History | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | accessdate= November 9, 2012}}</ref> Rob directed the video for "Human" and would go on to direct all of the band\'s subsequent videos.<ref>{{cite web|last=Leseman |first=Linda |url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/westcoastsound/2012/08/why_rob_zombie_is_sexy.php |title=Rob Zombie Is Quite Hot \xe2\x80\x93 Los Angeles \xe2\x80\x93 Music \xe2\x80\x93 West Coast Sound |publisher=Blogs.laweekly.com |date=2012-08-07 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Manf |first=Johnny |url=http://www.moviewiseguys.com/2010/11/from-the-vault-rob-zombies-music-videos.html |title=From The Vault: Rob Zombie\'s Music Videos |publisher=MovieWiseguys.com |date=2010-11-10 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>

In 1996, the band released their first [[remix album]] \'\'[[Supersexy Swingin\' Sounds]]\'\', featuring remixes of their previous releases.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.amazon.com/Supersexy-Swingin-Sounds-White-Zombie/dp/B000000OVC |title=Supersexy Swingin Sounds: Music |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cduniverse.com/search/xx/music/pid/1026808/a/Supersexy+Swingin%27+Sounds.htm |title=White Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Supersexy Swingin\' Sounds CD Album |publisher=Cduniverse.com |date=1996-08-13 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/white-zombie/albums/supersexy-swingin-sounds--99383 |title=Supersexy Swingin\' Sounds &#124; White Zombie Album &#124; Yahoo! Music |publisher=Music.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> The compilation album would ultimately be their last to enter the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]], and the last album formed during their formation. The band eventually broke up in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.411mania.com/music/news/92858 |title=Music \xe2\x80\x93 Rob Zombie Talks About The White Zombie Breakup |publisher=411mania.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> On the breakup, Rob stated "Sometimes a band just breaks up because the band has run its course and the best days are behind them. White Zombie went through a lot together and did tons of great stuff, but it was time to stop. The good times were over and we were all moving in different directions."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://robzombie.com/2012/02/qotw-white-zombie-by-something_weird/ |title=\xc2\xbb QOTW: White Zombie by Something_WEiRd Rob Zombie &#124; Official Website |publisher=Robzombie.com |date=2012-02-14 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>

===1998\xe2\x80\x932001: Solo career, \'\'Hellbilly Deluxe\'\', and \'\'The Sinister Urge\'\'===
Work on Zombie\'s debut solo album first began in 1997, before the band had officially broken up. For the album, Rob worked with numerous artists, including [[Charlie Clouser]] of [[Nine Inch Nails]] fame and former [[White Zombie (band)|White Zombie]] bandmate [[John Tempesta]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://robzombie.com/2012/07/artwork-for-rob-zombies-mondo-sex-head-revealed/comment-page-1/ |title=\xc2\xbb Artwork for Rob Zombie\xe2\x80\x99s Mondo Sex Head revealed Rob Zombie &#124; Official Website |publisher=Robzombie.com |date=2012-07-02 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Phares |first=Heather |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/american-made-music-to-strip-by-mw0000671137 |title=American Made Music to Strip By \xe2\x80\x93 Rob Zombie : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1999-10-26 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Records |first=Roadrunner |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/news/poll-who-s-your-favorite-rob-zombie-drummer |title=Poll: Who\'s Your Favorite Rob Zombie Drummer? |publisher=Roadrunner Records |date=2012-02-08 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1428856/rob-zombie-sets-date-solo-album.jhtml |title=Rob Zombie Sets Date For Solo Album \xe2\x80\x93 Music, Celebrity, Artist News |publisher=\'\'MTV\'\' |date=1998-07-09 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westnet.com/consumable/1998/09.02/revzombi.html |title=REVIEW |publisher=Westnet.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Zombie\'s solo debut album, \'\'[[Hellbilly Deluxe|Hellbilly Deluxe: 13 Tales of Cadaverous Cavorting Inside the Spookshow International]]\'\', was released on August 25, 1998.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hellbilly Deluxe |url=http://www.amazon.com/Hellbilly-Deluxe-Rob-Zombie/dp/B00000AEFF/ref=sr_1_1?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1345169566&sr=1-1&keywords=Hellbilly+Deluxe |title=Hellbilly Deluxe: Rob Zombie: Music |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Rob-Zombie-Hellbilly-Deluxe/release/1146059 |title=Rob Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Hellbilly Deluxe (CD, Album) |work=Discogs |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> The album was a commercial success, debuting at number 5 on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]] with first week sales of 121,000.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/77645/garths-scarecrow-shoots-straight-to-no-1 |title=Garth\'s \'Scarecrow\' Shoots Straight To No. 1 |work=Billboard |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> The first week sales of the album were higher than any previous White Zombie record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.last.fm/music/Rob+Zombie |title=Rob Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Discover music, videos, concerts, stats, & pictures at |publisher=Last.fm |date=2012-07-04 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>[http://hhnaddict.com/rob-zombie/]{{dead link|date=December 2012}}</ref> \'\'Hellbilly\'\' would go on to become Zombie\'s highest selling album to date, selling more than three million copies worldwide. It received triple-platinum status from the [[RIAA]], for sales exceeding three million copies in the United States. \'\'Hellbilly Deluxe\'\' was heavily influenced by [[classic horror|classic horror films]],<ref name="avclub.com">{{cite web|last=Tobias |first=Scott |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/rob-zombie,13946/ |title=Rob Zombie &#124; Film &#124; Interview |publisher=The A.V. Club |date=2005-08-02 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> with numerous songs on the album containing samples and quotes from some of Zombie\'s favorite [[horror film]]s.<ref name="reocities.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.reocities.com/tyrannorabbit/horrormetalz.html |title=Tyrannorabbit\'s Horrormetal-land |publisher=Reocities.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref name="rateyourmusic.com">[http://rateyourmusic.com/list/Mindcrimewithin/film_samples_in__metal__songs/]{{dead link|date=December 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.songfacts.com/search.php?q=Dragula Songfacts \xe2\x80\x93 Search results for : Dragula<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Three singles were released in total from the album: "[[Dragula (song)|Dragula]]", "[[Living Dead Girl (song)|Living Dead Girl]]", and "[[Superbeast]]". All three songs had critical and commercial success, with all three peaking inside the Top 40 of the \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' [[Hot Mainstream Rock Tracks]] chart in the US.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.100xr.com/artists/R/Rob_Zombie.htm |title=Rob Zombie Biography, Music News, Discography @ 100 XR \xe2\x80\x93 The Net\'s No. 1 Rock Station!!! |publisher=100xr.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> "Dragula" also had success in the United Kingdom, where it peaked at number 44.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zobbel.de/cluk/CLUK_Z.HTM |title=Chart Log UK: Z2 \xe2\x80\x93 ZZ Top |publisher=Zobbel.de |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Following the success of the album, Zombie released a remix album, \'\'[[American Made Music to Strip By]]\'\', in 1999.

Zombie was set to make his directorial debut with the film "The Crow: 2037", and even wrote the film\'s script.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1428859/zombie-will-write-direct-next-crow-flick.jhtml |title=Zombie Will Write/Direct Next "Crow" Flick \xe2\x80\x93 Music, Celebrity, Artist News |publisher=\'\'MTV\'\' |date=1997-02-11 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> The film was set to take place in the future, though it was never released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.experts123.com/q/what-happened-to-the-rob-zombie-script-for-crow-2037.html |title=What happened to the Rob Zombie script for Crow: 2037? |publisher=Experts123.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roteirodecinema.com.br/scripts/files/crow_2037_a_new_world_of_gods_and_monster.htm |title=Scripts on the Net \xe2\x80\x93 The Crow: 2037 A New World of Gods and Monster, by Rob Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Read The Screenplay |publisher=Roteirodecinema.com.br |date=2008-09-22 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://io9.com/5932803/100-wonderful-and-terrible-movies-that-never-existed |title=100 Wonderful and Terrible Movies That Never Existed |publisher=Io9.com |date=2012-08-10 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Following the failure of his first film attempt, Zombie began working on a new film, tentatively titled \'\'House of 1000 Corpses\'\'. [[Universal Pictures]] was set to distribute the film, which began filming in May 2000.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gill |first=John |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1428824/rob-zombie-direct-corpses-film.jhtml |title=Rob Zombie To Direct "Corpses" Film \xe2\x80\x93 Music, Celebrity, Artist News |publisher=\'\'MTV\'\' |date=2000-04-24 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> While filming the movie, however, Zombie encountered numerous problems with Universal, who feared the film would receive an [[NC-17]] rating. As a result, Zombie had to re-shoot numerous scenes to appease the company.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0251736/trivia House of 1000 Corpses (2003) \xe2\x80\x93 Trivia \xe2\x80\x93 IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Ultimately, [[Universal Pictures]] chose to shelve the film in late 2000, and the intended 2001 release was cancelled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/Devils-Rejects-Corpses-Two-Pack-Blu-ray/dp/B004AC6PQW |title=The Devil\'s Rejects / House of 1000 Corpses (Horror Two-Pack) [Blu-ray&#93;: Sid Haig, Sheri Moon Zombie, Bill Moseley, Karen Black, William Forsythe, Ken Foree, Matthew McGrory, Leslie Easterbrook, Geoffrey Lewis, Priscilla Barnes, Dave Sheridan, Kate Norby, Rob Zombie, Ali Forman, Andy Given, Andy Gould, Brent Morris, Danielle Shilling Lovett, Guy Oseary: Movies & TV |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://anythinghorror.com/2011/04/30/texas-frightmare-weekend-2011-day-2-press-conference-with-sid-haig/ |title=Texas Frightmare Weekend 2011: Day 2 \xe2\x80\x93 Press Conference with Sid Haig \xc2\xab AnythingHorror Central |publisher=Anythinghorror.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wn.com/original_universal_house_of_1000_corpses_trailer_rare |title=Original Universal House of 1000 Corpses Trailer Rare |publisher=Wn.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> The film would later serve as inspiration for the song of the same title on Zombie\'s \'\'[[The Sinister Urge (album)|The Sinister Urge]]\'\' album, with audio clips from the film being featured in the song.

Despite the failure of his directing career at that point, Zombie was still at work on his music career. His second studio album, \'\'[[The Sinister Urge (album)|The Sinister Urge]]\'\', was released on November 13, 2001. The album saw Zombie working with music legends such as [[Ozzy Osbourne]] and [[Kerry King]].<ref name="allmusic.com">{{cite web|last=Torreano |first=Bradley |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-sinister-urge-mw0000214563 |title=The Sinister Urge \xe2\x80\x93 Rob Zombie : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2001-11-13 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Despite debuting three spots lower than \'\'Hellbilly Deluxe\'\' on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/garth-brooks/10058 |title=\'Scarecrow\' Scares Off Britney &#124; News |work=NME |date=2001-11-22 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> it sold nearly 30,000 more copies in its first week, with first week sales of almost 150,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|author=Andrew Dansby |url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/garth-retires-the-competition-20011121 |title=Garth Retires the Competition &#124; Music News |work=Rolling Stone |date=2001-11-21 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Martens |first=Todd |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2003/10/01/outkast_leads_nine_new_top_20_chart_entries/ |title=/ A&E / Music / OutKast Leads Nine New Top-20 Chart Entries |work=Boston Globe |date= January 10, 2003|accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> \'\'The Sinister Urge\'\' went on to receive a Platinum certification from the [[RIAA]], his second solo album to do so.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://survivingthegoldenage.com/rob-zombie-mondo-sex-head/ |title=Record Review: Rob Zombie: Mondo Sex Head |publisher=Survivingthegoldenage.com |date=2012-08-13 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rzr.online.fr/docs/zombie/sinister_urge.htm |title=ROB ZOMBIE : THE SINISTER URGE : Zombie 2d solo album @ Zombieland 2 |publisher=Rzr.online.fr |date=2001-11-13 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Three singles were released from the album, "[[Never Gonna Stop (The Red Red Kroovy)]]", "[[Dead Girl Superstar]]", and "[[Demon Speeding]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://robzombie.com/music/the-sinister-urge/# |title=\xc2\xbb The Sinister Urge Rob Zombie &#124; Official Website |publisher=Robzombie.com |date=2012-07-17 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Lead single "Never Gonna Stop" became Zombie\'s third song to chart on the [[Alternative Songs]] chart in the US, as well as his Top 20 hit on the \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' [[Hot Mainstream Rock Tracks]] chart. "Demon Speeding" also had success on the latter chart, peaking only two positions lower than the aforementioned single. The album and subsequent singles received positive critical reviews,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,253069,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20090421134426/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,253069,00.html |archivedate=2009-04-21 |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2009-04-21 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/robzombie/albums/album/271092/review/6210001/the_sinister_urge |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071001212200/http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/robzombie/albums/album/271092/review/6210001/the_sinister_urge |archivedate=2007-10-01 |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2007-10-01 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> with [[Allmusic]] writing "It is the slow burn of [the album\'s] last track that shows the most promise; after years of making good heavy metal, he finally expands the boundaries of his own sound. Few metal musicians kept their sound fresh for as long as Zombie, and this album is no exception.<ref name="allmusic.com"/>

===2002\xe2\x80\x9305: Marriage, directorial debut, and soundtracks===
[[File:Rob Zombie (2005).jpg|thumb|right|Rob Zombie at Ozzfest, 2005.]]
Following the success of his second studio album, Zombie announced his engagement to longtime girlfriend [[Sheri Moon Zombie|Sheri Moon]], who had appeared in numerous music videos for both Rob and [[White Zombie (band)|White Zombie]]. Ten days before the couple\'s set wedding date, however, they decided to elope on [[Halloween]] of 2002.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0600667/bio#trivia Sheri Moon Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Biography<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://watchingrobertpickton88015.yuku.com/topic/1979/FICTIONAL-MONSTERS-KILLERS-ETC?page=1#.UDAibaNpf6M |title=FICTIONAL MONSTERS/KILLERS/ETC in "Watching/reading fictionalized crime stories." Forum |publisher=Watchingrobertpickton88015.yuku.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> On the decision, Sheri stated: "We were actually taking a walk in our neighborhood the day before. The wedding date was to be November 9th. We\'re like, \'Oh, God, we\'ve been together for nine years. We should just say our vows privately\'. It was just like a spur-of-the-moment decision. It just happens that the next day was Halloween. We didn\'t do it for any spooky reasons or anything".<ref name="girlsandcorpses.com"/> Zombie\'s first [[greatest hits]] album, titled \'\'[[Past, Present & Future (Rob Zombie album)|Past, Present & Future]]\'\', was released on September 23, 2003.<ref>{{cite web|last=Loftus |first=Johnny |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/past-present-future-mw0000324367 |title=Past, Present & Future \xe2\x80\x93 Rob Zombie : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2003-09-23 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> It reached number 11 on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]], and became Zombie\'s last album to receive a [[Platinum certification]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Rob%20Zombie&go=Search&perPage=50 |title=Gold & Platinum Searchable Database \xe2\x80\x93 November 24, 2012 |publisher=RIAA |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Rob Zombie |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/rob-zombie-mn0000235169/awards |title=Rob Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Awards|publisher=AllMusic|date=|accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>

Following his marriage, Zombie announced he had bought the rights to the previously shelved film \'\'[[House of 1000 Corpses]]\'\'.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0251736/news House of 1000 Corpses (2003) \xe2\x80\x93 News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.unratedmagazine.com/Document.cfm?Page=Articles/index.cfm&Article_ID=80 |title=House of 1000 Corpses by UnRated Magazine |publisher=Unratedmagazine.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://itunes.apple.com/us/artist/rob-zombie/id110374 |title=iTunes \xe2\x80\x93 Music \xe2\x80\x93 Rob Zombie |publisher=Itunes.apple.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Scenes for the movie were re-shot, and Zombie even filmed some scenes in the basement of his home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/rob-zombie-20717093 |title=Rob Zombie Biography \xe2\x80\x93 Facts, Birthday, Life Story |publisher=Biography.com |date=|accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Zombie later managed a deal with [[Lions Gate Entertainment]] to release the film, which was released theatrically on April 11, 2003.<ref>{{cite web|author=House of 1000 Corpses [2003] |url=http://robzombie.com/movies/house-of-1000-corpses/comment-page-1/ |title=\xc2\xbb House of 1000 Corpses [2003&#93; Rob Zombie &#124; Official Website |publisher=Robzombie.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Eric D. Snider |url=http://www.film.com/?p=129042 |title=Re-Views: House of 1000 Corpses (2003) \xe2\x80\x93 |publisher=Film.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Though negatively received by critics, the film was somewhat financially successful, grossing a total of $16,829,545 and earning back its $7,000,000 budget.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/series/HouseOf1000Corpses.php |title=House of 1,000 Corpses \xe2\x80\x93 Box Office History |publisher=The-numbers.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> The film was criticized for being too "grotesque" and "violent", but has since garnered a [[cult following]].<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.ps3trophies.org/forum/movies/105683-cult-classic-devils-rejects-house-1000-corpse.html |title=Cult classic, Devils rejects and house of 1000 corpse |publisher=PS3Trophies.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/cult-classic-rob-zombie-horror-movies-house-1000-7069.html?cat=9 |title=Cult Classic Rob Zombie Horror Movies: House of 1000 Corpses & The Devils Rejects \xe2\x80\x93 Yahoo! Voices |publisher=voices.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=9445 |title=Empire\'s House Of 1000 Corpses Movie Review |work=Empire |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phase9.tv/moviereviews/houseof1000corpses.shtml |title=House of a 1000 Corpses \xe2\x80\x93 movie review |publisher=Phase9.tv |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Despite numerous negative reviews,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.angelfire.com/film/teenreview/houseof1000corpses.html |title=Review: House of 1000 Corpses |publisher=Angelfire.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> the film is frequently listed as one of the "best horror films ever made".<ref>{{cite web|author=House of 1000 Corpses |url=http://www.amazon.com/House-1000-Corpses-Sid-Haig/dp/B00009MGEM |title=House of 1000 Corpses: Sid Haig, Karen Black, Bill Moseley, Sheri Moon Zombie, Chad Bannon, William Bassett, Erin Daniels, Joe Dobbs III, Judith Drake, Dennis Fimple, Gregg Gibbs, Walton Goggins, Rob Zombie, Andy Given, Andy Gould, Danielle Shilling Lovett, Guy Oseary, Joel Hatch, Robert K. Lambert: Movies & TV |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.wagerweb.com/entertainment/top-25-scariest-scary-movies-ever-made-16918.html |title=\xc2\xbb Top 25 Scariest Scary Movies Ever Made |publisher=Entertainment.wagerweb.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Zombie created the majority of the film\'s [[House of 1000 Corpses (soundtrack)|soundtrack]], which features music from artists such as [[The Ramones]], [[Helen Kane]], and Zombie himself. The film\'s [[House of 1000 Corpses (song)|eponymous song]], which was first featured on Zombie\'s \'\'[[The Sinister Urge (album)|The Sinister Urge]]\'\' album, is featured on the soundtrack. Original songs from Zombie, such as "Pussy Liquor" and "Little Piggy", are also featured, as is Zombie\'s cover version of the 1977 hit "[[Brick House (song)|Brick House]]", re-titled to "Brick House 2003".<ref>{{cite web|last=Kergan |first=Wade |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/house-of-1000-corpses-mw0000021706 |title=House of 1000 Corpses \xe2\x80\x93 Original Soundtrack : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2003-03-25 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Zombie\'s version of the song was used in a portion of the film. The soundtrack peaked at number 53 on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]], and number 4 on the [[Top Soundtracks]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=soundtrack|chart=all}} |title=House of 1000 Corpses \xe2\x80\x93 Original Soundtrack |work=Billboard |date=2003-04-19 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>

Following the success of \'\'[[House of 1000 Corpses]]\'\', it was announced work on a sequel for the film had begun. In an interview, Zombie stated that he already had an idea for a sequel while working on the first film, in which the brother of a cop murdered in the first film would return for revenge.<ref name="avclub.com"/> He later stated he wanted to make the characters less cartoonish than in the previous film, and would feature more of a "violent [[Western film]]" theme.<ref>{{cite web|author=JoBlo |url=http://www.joblo.com/movie-news/set-visit-interview-with-devils-rejects-director-rob-zombie |title=Set Visit: Interview with Devil\'s Rejects director Rob Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Movie News |publisher=JoBlo.com |date=2004-07-15 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> The film featured all of the [[List of Rob Zombie characters|Firefly family]] returning to the film,<ref>{{IMDb title|0395584}}</ref> and are forced to take refuge after their house is raided by the police and numerous family members are murdered.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0395584/trivia The Devil\'s Rejects (2005) \xe2\x80\x93 Trivia \xe2\x80\x93 IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eatmybrains.com/showfeature.php?id=25 |title=Interview with The Devil\'s Rejects\' Rob Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Feature Article |publisher=Eat My Brains! |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moviesonline.ca/movienews_6283.html |title=Exclusive Interview with Rob Zombie - MoviesOnline |publisher=Moviesonline.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-12-12}}</ref> The film, titled \'\'[[The Devil\'s Rejects]]\'\', was a commercial success, and received a more positive reception when compared to \'\'House of 1000 Corpses\'\'. \'\'The Devil\'s Rejects\'\' was released on July 22, 2005 in 1,757 theaters and grossed $7.1 million on its opening weekend, recouping its roughly $7 million budget. It grossed $17 million in North America and $2.3 million internationally, bringing the film\'s total gross to over $19.4 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=devilsrejects.htm |title=The Devil\'s Rejects (2005) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date=2005-08-25 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Much like its predecessor, \'\'The Devil\'s Rejects\'\' garnered a [[cult following]]. The film had mixed critical reviews, earning a 53% rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], with the consensus "Zombie has improved as a filmmaker since \'House of 1000 Corpses\' and will please fans of the genre, but beware \xe2\x80\x93 the horror is nasty, relentless, and sadistic."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/devils_rejects/ |title=The Devil\'s Rejects |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> The film has a 53 out of 100 rating on [[Metacritic]], meaning mixed to positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-devils-rejects |title=The Devil\'s Rejects Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More |publisher=Metacritic |date=2005-07-22 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>

===2006\xe2\x80\x9309: \'\'Educated Horses\'\' and the \'\'Halloween\'\' franchise===
[[File:Rob Zombie Comiccon.JPG|left|thumb|Rob Zombie attending the 2007 [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic Con]] to promote \'\'[[Halloween (2007 film)|Halloween]]]]
Work on Zombie\'s third studio album began in 2005, whilst Zombie was finishing \'\'[[The Devil\'s Rejects]]\'\'. Zombie was quoted as saying that the album had influences from [[glam rock]] artists like [[Slade]], [[T. Rex (band)|T. Rex]], and [[Gary Glitter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1classic.com/view/playlist/1544469/116562/Hangin_With_Rob_Zombie/Hangin_With_Rob_Zombie/index.jhtml |title=70\'s, 80\'s & 90\'s Classic Rock, Soul & Pop Music Videos &#124; VH1 |publisher=VH1 Classic |date= |accessdate=2012-02-14}}</ref> The album has been described as an "experiment" by Zombie, and features numerous acoustic led songs. The finished product, \'\'[[Educated Horses]]\'\', was released on March 28, 2006<ref>{{cite web|last=Christopher |first=James |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/educated-horses-mw0000350871 |title=Educated Horses \xe2\x80\x93 Rob Zombie : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2006-03-28 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> and sold 107,000 copies in its first week of release, debuting at number 5 on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' 200]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blistering.com/fastpage/fpengine.php/link/1/templateid/11674/tempidx/1/menuid/1 |title=Blistering Metal News: Rob Zombie\'s Educated Horses Debuts At Number 5 On Billboard Top 200 |publisher=Blistering.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/58852/ti-rules-as-king-of-album-chart |title=T.I. Rules As \'King\' Of Album Chart |work=Billboard |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> In its second week it dropped to number fourteen, selling a further 46,720 copies.<ref>Soundscan, [http://prince.org/msg/7/185183 "Soundscan / Billboard Top 200 Albums 04.12.06"], Prince.org, 
14, 2006.</ref> The song "[[The Lords of Salem (song)|The Lords of Salem]]" was nominated for the Grammy for Best Hard Rock Performance of 2008.<ref>[http://www.grammy.com/grammy_awards/51st_show/list.aspx#04 ]{{dead link|date=November 2012}}</ref> The album received mixed critical reviews, with [[Rolling Stone]] writing "A handful of cuts are too long on sludgy instrumental grooves, but whether Zombie is out-Trent Reznoring [[Trent Reznor]] on the [[sitar]]-laden grindfest "17 Year Locust" or spitting fire amid the apocalyptic blues riffs of "The Devil\'s Rejects," he sounds like a gifted schlockmeister that [[The Strokes|Strokes]] fans can enjoy. Or at least tolerate."<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/robzombie/albums/album/9491563/review/9597771/educated_horses | title = Educated Horses review | publisher = Wenner Media | author = [[Rolling Stone]] | date = 2006-04-05 | accessdate = 2006-04-05 }}{{dead link|date=November 2012}}</ref>

In 2006, it was announced that Zombie had signed on to write and direct a remake of the 1978 [[horror film]] classic \'\'[[Halloween (1978 film)|Halloween]]\'\'. After the announcement, Zombie posted on his official MySpace page, stating "...what I am doing is starting totally from scratch. This is the new HALLOWEEN. Call it a remake, an update, a reimaging or whatever, but one thing that for sure is this is a whole new start... a new beginning with no connection to the other series. That is exactly why the project appeals to me. I can take it and run with it."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fearsocial.com/2012/06/rob-zombie-strikes-deal-to-direct-produce-and-write-halloween-remake/ |title=Account Suspended |publisher=Fearsocial.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}{{dead link|date=November 2012}}</ref> Zombie later referred to the film as a "re-imagining" of the original [[John Carpenter]] film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.robzombiemovies.com/halloween/ |title=Halloween Remake \xe2\x80\x93 Halloween from Rob Zombie \xe2\x80\x93 Halloween 9 |publisher=Robzombiemovies.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Zombie\'s remake of \'\'[[Halloween (2007 film)|Halloween]]\'\' was officially released on August 31, 2007 to 3,472 theaters in North America,<ref name="mainpage">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=halloween07.htm|title=Main Page Summary|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate= 2008-08-17}}</ref> giving it the widest release of any of the previous \'\'Halloween films\'\'.<ref name="compare">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/franchises/chart/?id=halloween.htm|title=\'\'Halloween\'\' film series comparison chart|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2009-03-03}}</ref> On its opening day, \'\'Halloween\'\' grossed $10,896,610,<ref name="DBO">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=daily&id=halloween07.htm| title= Daily Box Office Totals|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2009-03-03}}</ref> and immediately surpassed the opening weekend grosses for several of the original series\'s films.<ref name="compare"/> From September 1\xe2\x80\x932, \'\'Halloween\'\' earned $8,554,661 and $6,911,096, respectively, for a 3-day opening weekend total of $26,362,367. The film would earn an additional $4,229,392 on Labor Day for a 4-day holiday weekend gross of $30,591,759.<ref name="DBO"/> Thanks to its opening weekend of $30.5 million, the film broke the box-office record for the Labor Day weekend, surpassing the record set in 2005 by \'\'[[Transporter 2]]\'\' with $20.1 million.<ref>{{cite news|author=Gregg Kilday|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/05/AR2007090500182_pf.html|title="Halloween" pulls neat trick at box office|work=Washington Post|date=2007-09-05|accessdate=2008-08-17}}</ref> It still currently resides as the top Labor Day weekend grosser.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/weekends/laborday.htm?page=LABDAY&p=.htm|title=Labor Day Record|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2008-08-17}}</ref> Zombie\'s remake has since become the highest grossing of the series, not adjusted for inflation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/general_music_news/rob_zombies_halloween_named_best_remake.html |title=Rob Zombie\'s \'Halloween\' Named \'Best Remake\' &#124; News @ |publisher=Ultimate-guitar.com |date=2008-10-23 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.trancasfilms.com/halloween-2007.php |title=Halloween A Rob Zombie Film(2007) |publisher=Trancas International Films |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>

Initially, Zombie has stated that he would begin working on a new original film, titled \'\'Tyrannosaurus Rex\'\', which was slated for a 2009 release date.<ref>{{cite web|title=UPDATED: Plot Details For Rob Zombie\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98Tyrannosaurus Rex\xe2\x80\x99!|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/11345/updated-plot-details-for-rob-zombies-tyrannosaurus-rex/|publisher=BloodyDisgusting}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2009/08/28/rob-zombie-describes-tyrannosaurus-rex-as-an-underground-fighting-movie/ |title=Rob Zombie Describes \xe2\x80\x98Tyrannosaurus Rex\xe2\x80\x99 As An Underground Fighting Movie |publisher=Moviesblog.mtv.com |date=2009-08-28 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.movieweb.com/movie/rob-zombies-tyrannosaurus-rex |title=Rob Zombie\'s Tyrannosaurus Rex (2009) |publisher=MovieWeb.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/rob-zombies-tyrannosaurus-rex-teaser-poster/ |title=Rob Zombie\xe2\x80\x99s Tyrannosaurus Rex Teaser Poster &#124; /Film |publisher=Slashfilm.com |date=2008-06-23 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Despite previously stating he would not direct a sequel for his \'\'Halloween\'\' remake, it was later announced he would be both writing and directing a sequel for the film, tentatively titled \'\'H2\'\'.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fleming |first=Michael |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117997402?refCatId=13 |title=Zombie making \'Halloween\' sequel \xe2\x80\x93 Entertainment News, Film News, Media |publisher=Variety |date=2008-12-15 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.robzombiemovies.com/halloween/2/ |title=Rob Zombie\'s Halloween 2 |publisher=Robzombiemovies.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Due to his decision, the film \'\'Tyrannosaurus Rex\'\' was put on hold until after work on the second installment for the \'\'Halloween\'\' remake franchise was complete.<ref>{{cite web|last=Turek |first=Ryan |url=http://www.shocktillyoudrop.com/news/8674-update-rob-zombie-returning-for-halloween-2 |title=Update! Rob Zombie Returning for Halloween 2? |publisher=Shock Till You Drop |date=2008-12-01 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> Zombie later confirmed that his version of \'\'Halloween II\'\' would have little to do with the [[Halloween II (1981 film)|original 1981 sequel]], but would instead focus on the effects that the events of the first film have had on survivor [[Laurie Strode]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/news/feed.asp?NID=23880 |title=Rob Zombie To Direct H2 &#124; Movie News &#124; Empire |work=Empire |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.fanpop.com/spots/horror-movies/articles/13492/title/rob-zombie-direct-h2 |title=Rob Zombie To Direct H2 \xe2\x80\x93 Horror Movies |publisher=Fanpop |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.therimofhell.com/2008/12/16/rob-zombie-to-direct-halloween-2/ |title=Rob Zombie to Direct Halloween 2! |publisher=The Rim Of Hell |date=2008-12-16 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> [[Dimension Films]] released \'\'[[Halloween II (2009 film)|Halloween II]]\'\' in North America on August 28, 2009 to 3,025 theaters.<ref name="release">{{cite web|url=http://shocktillyoudrop.com/news/topnews.php?id=9066|title=\'Halloween 2\' Takes Familiar Spot|publisher=Shock Till You Drop|date=January 1, 2009|accessdate=January 12, 2009}}</ref> Following that, the film was released in the United Kingdom on October 9, 2009.<ref name="UK">{{cite web| url= http://www.launchingfilms.co.uk/releaseschedule/schedule.php?sort=date&date=today|title=UK Film release schedule&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x94 past, present and future|work=LaunchingFilms.co.uk|publisher=Film Distributors\' Association|accessdate=September 17, 2009}}</ref> Dimension re-released \'\'Halloween II\'\' in North America on October 30, 2009 to coincide with the [[Halloween]] holiday,<ref name="rerelease">{{cite web|url=http://www.shocktillyoudrop.com/news/topnews.php?id=12424| title=TV Spot for Zombie\'s Halloween II\'s Re-Release|publisher=Rob Zombie|work=Shock Till You Drop|date=October 22, 2009|accessdate=October 22, 2009}}</ref> across 1,083 theaters.<ref name="LA">{{cite news|author=Ben Fritz|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-boxoffice2-2009nov02,0,4641634.story|title=Michael Jackson film \'This Is It\' performs well overseas|publisher=Tribune Company|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 2, 2009| accessdate= November 4, 2009}}</ref> The film was released on DVD and Blu-ray on January 12, 2010; the theatrical cut and an unrated director\'s cut, which Zombie says is "very different from the theatrical version," are available.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sonypictures.com/homevideo/catalog/catalogDetail_DVD043396341883.html|title=Halloween II (Rated) \xe2\x80\x93 DVD| publisher=Sony Pictures|date=November 16, 2009|accessdate=April 8, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sonypictures.com/homevideo/catalog/catalogDetail_DVD043396344433.html| title= Halloween II (Unrated) \xe2\x80\x93 DVD|publisher=Sony Pictures|date=November 16, 2009|accessdate=April 8, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sonypictures.com/homevideo/catalog/catalogDetail_DVD043396341876.html| title=Halloween II- BD|publisher=Sony Pictures| date= November 16, 2009|accessdate=April 8, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/34203/directors-cut-rob-zombies-halloween-ready-go|title=Director\'s Cut of Rob Zombie\'s Halloween II Ready to Go|publisher=Dread Central Media, LLC| work= DreadCentral.com| date= January 7, 2010|accessdate=April 8, 2010}}</ref> By the end of his theatrical run, \'\'Halloween II\'\' grossed a total of $33,392,973 in North America, and an additional $5,925,616 overseas for a worldwide total of $39,318,589.<ref name="overall">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=halloween209.htm|title=Overall Box Office|publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] |work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=June 25, 2010}}</ref> Compared to the other \'\'Halloween\'\' films, the 2009 sequel sits in fourth place, just behind the original \'\'Halloween\'\'.<ref name="Hallcom">{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/franchises/chart/?id=halloween.htm| title= Halloween film series comparison|publisher=IMDb.com, Inc|work=Box Office Mojo| accessdate= August 31, 2009}}</ref> Following the completion of the film, Zombie confirmed he would not make another sequel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.horrorbid.com/blog/blog1.php/2009/08/02/rob-zombie-talks-halloween-3-remake |title=Rob Zombie Talks Halloween 3 Remake |publisher=Horrorbid.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>
